text: dark malt chocolate and cocoa a bit roasty and smooth in the body. some harshness but also refined from others of which there are many. bittersweet with some tobacco.
Draft pours black with a brown head. Aroma of chocolate, toffee and grains . Taste is chocolate, coffee and grains

Large khaki head over a black body that left very nice lacing. Aroma of roasted malts compliment the dark fruit, raisins and raspberries. Flavor shifts away from the fruit a bit and focuses more intently on the malt character. Bittersweet chocolate, tobacco, molasses, a touch of coffee and a little smoke that is more noticeable in the aftertaste. Alcohol is enhancing, not overpowering.
Dark pour. Heavy body and flavor. Deep roasted malts, plum, tobacco, light bread. Maaaybe a hint of bittersweet chocolate on the tail end. An interesting and tasty brew.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of toasted, dark bread and chocolate milk, light herbs for the hops, light dough for the yeast, with toffee and soy sauce in the background. Head is small, fizzy/frothy, light brown, with some spots of lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is very dark brown. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Palate is medium to full, creamy, with a sticky. dry and slightly astringent finish. This is an excellent beer and probably the best Baltic Porter Ive had.
Pours dark brown with a minimal head. Aroma is coffee and cocoa. Flavor is rich like chocolate cake but not as sweet. Smooth mouthfeel and enjoyable.
Black pour with a small tan head. Aroma of chocolate, fudge, caramel, lightly vinous, light soy. Medium to full body, big dark malt flavors, thick. Good stuff.

Poured from 12 oz. bottle. 

Opaque, brown-black with a brown head and very good lacing. 

Aroma of cocoa, coffee, molasses, nuts, licorice, leather and a variety of fruit. 

Taste of roasted malt, molasses, chocolate, dark fruit, licorice, toffee and caramel. 

Full/medium body and medium carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle sample at a tasting at Max place. Thanks DSG. Black. Sweet cocoa and nuts, nutella-like aroma. Sweet and smooth with hints of roasty bitterness in the mouth. Full body, smooth, hot chocolate finish.

Bottle shared at a tasting at Maxs place. Thanks GothGargoyle for this bottle! Black with tan foam. Aroma of roast, chocolate, a bit of dark fruits, a bit of oxidation. Sweet flavor with chocolate, roast, a bit of dark fruits. Medium to full-bodied. Very nice, but could be fresher.
At Maxs place, Pours black with a beige head, aroma of chocolate, coffee, yeast, lemon, flavor is slightly sour, chocolate, caramel, toffee, cocoa, medium bodied

355 ml bottle. Pours a very dark brown with moderate tan head that settles quickly. Aromas of dark molasses, sugary dark fruit, and sweet roasted malts. Rich flavors of nutty dark chocolate with raisins, oily molasses, vanilla, black coffee, and roasted malts. Rich and oily. Good stuff.

Rating #2260 - 2015.12.16 - Beer #16 in the 2015 Craft BeerAdvent Calendar. Pours a Tarheel black with a weak bubbly tan foam. Aroma is heavy roast malt,lots of coffee, chocolate, and espresso. Taste is mild bitterness, medium-heavy alcohol character, lots of black forest cake, espresso, cocoa flavours and smokiness on the palate in the finish. Unreal brew.

Sample at the esbls.  In my tasting glass this was jet black with a tan head. Nose is licorice, dark ripe fruit, and rich caramel malts. Full in body with a rich creamy mouth feel. Flavor is really rich with the anise, plums, raisins, molasses, and chocolate all mingled tougher for a delightful taste. Finish is bittersweet. and the alcohol is well hidden. A great baltic porter and simply a great beer.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2016 600 rating! 355ml bottle from Denman Liquor store. Tasting with Jamey. Aroma is some spices, smoky notes, chocolate, roasted seeds, oily, leather. Taste is dark fruits, oily, roasted malt, chocolate notes. Roasted malt, leather, dark fruits, smoky aftertaste. Very good balanced beer, in which you cant find 9 ABV at all.

Pours opaque cola-brown with a 2-finger tan head. Aroma of coffee with a bit of char. Maybe some caramel too. Medium body, a bit oily. Finish is mild, with a touch of astringency. Coffee flavor with a bit of char to it. A sweet note underneath, maybe toffee.
Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass at the World of Bee in Pooler, GA. The appearance is black with a small tan head. The aroma is coffee with some cocoa. A really good porter.

BBD 2016. Pours black. Normal head volume, poor lacing and retention.

Outstanding nose of light roast, dark chocolate, raisins with plum notes, caramel and light molasses with a bit of caramel.

Light full bodied with a smooth texture that has a bit of creaminess. Slightly below normal carbonation level and is a bit low for the body. Light effervescence in the middle and prickly in the finish.

The flavor profile is quite outstanding. The 9% ABV is very well covered by the rich complex flavors. All the flavors of the nose appear, but mostly in blended fashion. Sweet molasses and caramel form the base with roast on the top. Bitterness is a hint in the middle and mostly roast based. The finish is a slow sweet fade with notes of chocolate, raisin and plum.

Wow, this beer shoots for and nearly achieves greatness. A phenomenally superior Baltic Porter, with an excellent coffee and sweet tobacco leaf aroma, nice ruby-brown-black appearance, but with a rather minimal head, looks very flat. The flavor profile is perfect, slightly charred roasted malt, predominantly still sweet and warm maltiness, as a porter ought to be. Some dark fruit notes and an alcohol sweetness, but no boozy tartness, very well done. Indeed very smooth and pleasant texture, with minimal carbonation. My only dissatisfaction that keeps me from going a full 4/5 stars with this beer is its lack of body, personally I would much prefer some additional foam and texture. Still delicious and I will definitely drink again.
Bottle from Bruisin Ales. Rich dark fruit and roasty coffee aroma. Great rich taste of dark fruits, leather, a little roasty. Clean fruity finish with no booze. Tasty.

Une robe brune sur laquelle flotte un anneau de mousse. Au nez, voilà une richesse fruitée liquoreuse dans une mélasse imbibée de réglisse et touchée par une fumée de cigare. Au goût, la mélasse est dominante, teintée par des malts bien tournés, accaparée par des saveurs de fudge aux noix et découpée par des fruits noirs qui ont bien vieillies. En bouche, jai limpression dun corps de moyenne densité avec un pétillement modéré à bas et une texture crémeuse. La finale est très mélasse noire, mi-amère ou mi-sucrée, assez forte pour lui mais conçue pour elle. Bon liquide qui nest pas beau mais qui fait le travail quil doit faire. Efficace.

Dark brown pour with a few beige bubbles for a head. Aroma of malts, caramel, lactose, chocolate and licorice. Taste of roasted malts, fudge, chocolate, lactose, slight fruits, hint of coffee, molasses and slight licorice. Full bodied, lower carbonation, velvety smooth creamy mouthfeel. Perfectly balanced and a nice lingering chocolate fudge on the finish. Absolutely delicious!

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2016 341ml bottle from trade with SlovakSniper. Aroma: chocolate, candied fruits, licorice, raisin. App: dark brush almost black, minimal to no head (brown), no lacing. Taste and palate: medium body, velvety  fruity, moderate carbonation, medium sweet finish. Overall: good but not huge fan of licorice at least when its that much but once it?s warmer it led present. Body feels a bit too thin as well but the texture makes it up. Do much better around 18C.Still something I could drink on cold days after shovelling. Not exactly todays weather though but still, this is highly drinkable. I guess I?ll update this rating a 3rd time soon.

Pours almost black with a thin off white head. Nose is malty. Taste is delightfully balanced. One of the best porters I've had.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Long time want. Great aroma of intense roast, peanuts, chocolate syrup, tobacco, and cherries. Tastes very roasty, some smoke and chocolate, dry nutty finish with some lingering dark fruit. Medium body. Some intense stuff here and pretty complex. Would love some more of this.

I think that most of the reviews have the tone of someone more concerned with impressing beer snobs than giving an objective opinion about the beer. 
(I will post the same comment with every review)

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared by Tom - thanks! Oh man, first whiff and you know its an elite beer. Good god. Dark brown pour. Rich aroma of nut, mild licorice, cold coffee. Taste is also very rich - similar to aroma with some caramel and raisin as well. Slick palate with some heft. This is one of the best, if not the best, porters Ive ever had. And one of the best made beers Ive ever had. Damn, this is spot on.
12oz Bottle in trade, awesome throw in. Dark black pour. Aroma is sweet, caramel, dark fruits. Taste is amazing, slightly dry but the dark fruits and sweetness are awesome. Amazing porter!

Tasted from bottle. Pours black with thin beige head. Aroma is caramel, licorice, bourbon, maple syrup and dark fruits. Taste is moderately sweet with mild to moderate bitterness. Flavors of plums, raisins, caramel, chocolate, maple syrup, licorice. Definitely one of the best Baltic Porters I've had. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle : For starters - its over carbed. Im over it - This head is frothy and obnoxious - but with patience, its more manageable. The head is khaki , and the brew is a dark brown in this glass. It retains fairly well - with very light spotting. The aroma seems like classic baltic - a heavy roast, mineral water, with a dark fruit bouquet. The flavor profile is nice - It begins with chocolate malts, dark fruits, with roasty notes moving through a bittering feeling that gets rounded out by a hint of booze. Its nice.

Bottle. Roasted coffee, chocolate and fruit aroma. Pours dark black with a small brown head. Medium carbonation. Fruit - cherry and strawberries, roasted coffee, cocoa beans - very complex. Full bodied with an oily texture. Well balanced finish with some sweet maltiness and a touch of bitterness. Excellent.

355ml bottle enjoyed @ home, thanks to Brian!. Pours pitch black with a long lasting average sized beige head. Aroma is heavy roasted malt, dark dried fruits like raisins and plums, liquorice, chocolate, coffee, caramel, earthy and a hint of smoke. Flavour is medium to heavy bitter and medium sweet. Full bodied, smooth and oily texture, soft carbonation. Finish is roasted, slightly burned, bitter and dark dried fruits. Very nice baltic porter!

Bottle into snifter. Aroma is dark fruits, chocolate, roast, plum, light soy sauce, earth. Pour is jet black, tan head. Flavor is light berries, brownies, cocoa, coffee, earth. Its quite a rich brew, quite nice.

Bottle. Appearance is black with light mocha head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is anise, dark fruit, and roasted malts. Taste is roasted malts, coffee, and bitter dark chocolate. Medium mouthfeel. Really enjoyed this, more like a RIS than a Baltic as it is more toasty and bitter, then sweet dark fruit, but its really tasty!
Lindo marrom escuro, com espuma escura não persistente. Baunilha, passas e cafe num corpo mediano. Otimo equilibrio. Recomendo

Looks like the calendar had some really good beers in it - but i smartly stayed away from that massive money pit. Solid aroma of chocolate, some sweetness and coffee, raisins, dust, hint of raspberries. Pretty tasty with a bit of burnt aftertaste and probably alcohol - faint but there. Maybe its more than faint but its tied in well with the bitterness. Deep roast and truckloads of malts, toffee, light medicinal stuff, charcoal, hints of citrus. I didnt find this particularly smooth nor did I enjoy the hard bite. It did leave my mouth heavily coated with beer load - probably the thing I enjoyed the most here is the lasting feeling like I ate an entire chapstick. Thick bodied. I really dont think I was in the mood for this but, really, that just points towards a general meh despite what is here. Just look a massive swig of the bottom of my glass and it was freaking excellent! wtf. oh well. Appreciate? Sure. Second purchase? Not a chance. Les Trois Mousquetaires Baltic Porter kills this.

Pours an opaque dark brown almost black color with khaki colored head. Roasted malt, some dark chocolate, and smoke on the nose; follows onto the palate. Full bodied. Finishes with smoke and roasted malt.

Aroma is raisin, caramel, toffee and slight vanilla. Toasted bread and oat aswell. Taste is a deep and rich maltiness with caramel , toffee and chocolate. Fine light tartiness on the tip that rounds the beer out nicely.smooth finish given how full bodied it is. Aroma is a deep black with a thin beige head that retains fairly poorly.

Bottle into stout glass. Black w tan head. Aroma just smells like chocolate velvet. Smooth creamy mouthfeel. Chocolate notes. Some vanilla. Like drinking black silk. Great porter. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from the Craft Beer Advent CalendarBlack color, small head. Some liquorice and dark malts in the aroma. Good body strength; chocolate flavor, a bit too much medicine (phenol?), moderately sweet, with some leather, and some alcohol warmth; a bit of roasted nuts too.Quite good, a bit weird.
Bottle - Dark fruits, dark chocolate and a nice sweetness. Deep jet brown with a decent brown head. Lots of dar roast richness, balanced dark fruit and none of the bitterness. Nice.

12 oz. bottle, pours black with a small beige head. Aroma brings out notes of roasted malt, some light cocoa and earthy notes. Flavour brings out a very earthy roasted malt that dominates the whole palate. Secondary notes exist in terms of light cocoa and coffee, but this is mostly earthy roasted malt. Complex and rich, with low residual sweetness. An extremely high quality baltic porter - one of the best.

Almost black pour, thin dark brown, rocky head. Big porter aroma, deep bitter roast, dark chocolate, espresso. Taste is well balanced starting with some sweeter malt and ending in a roast bitterness with some leather. Alcohol content is well hidden. Body was a tad thinner than desired, low carbonation.
Dark pour into glass. I dont see much head or lace. Burnt malt, tree, coffee, subtle citrus, toffee. Flavors blend nicely, taper off into a bitter coffee sticky malt/hop salad. Excellent.

Deep, dark brown, almost opaque. Virtually no head. Aroma of roasted malts, blackened toast, coffee, smoke. Taste is bitter, earthy, faint smokiness. Surprisingly light bodied, slightly oily mouthfeel, average carbonation. Finishes bitter, doesnt linger. Impressive.

355 ml bottle poured at home. Day 17 of the craft beer advent calendar. This is about as far removed from yesterdays beer as you can get. Pours black with no head and almost no carbonation. I had a hard time placing the aroma; I thought it was malt but Im not quite sure. Taste is quite complex. Has a roasty, malty flavor that has a nice bitter finish and a touch of alcohol. As hard as I found it to place the flavors/aromas, it works. This is a really good beer.

355ml brown bottle. Craft Beer Advent Calendar 15. Dark brown with a fast disappearing layer of beige foam. Nose has caramel, molasses. Taste - caramel, tobacco, dark fruit, chocolate. Bitter finish. Medium body, light carbonation. Quite rich and very nice.

CBAC day 16! Pours an inky black with little head and nice long legs up the glass. World class Baltic porter that almost makes this calendar worth the price of admission! Lots of dark dried fruits, raisins, plums and rich caramel with some light balanced booze throughout! Would have been happy with a calendar full of these!

2015 beer advent. Pours very close to black. Low, but not too low carbonation. Quite mild roasty flavours, you wouldn't guess this is a 9% alc beer. I think it is lacking a full mouthfeel texture.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
CBAC Day 16. Not a big porter fan at all. Nice pour, no head or lacing though. Sadly did not enjoy the taste and poured out.
Bottle into pint glass. Pours a very dark brown with a small brown head. Aroma is roasty. Taste is roasty. Good beer.

Appearance: opaque deep brown /black with only the faintest hints of lighter brown around the margins, short, short-lived beige head diminishing rapidly to a thin ring, no lacing. (4/5) Aroma: dark chocolate, toffee, dark roasty grains, boozy cherries, hint of smoke and leather. (9/10) Taste: moderate-strong sweet, moderate bitter. (9/10) Palate: full oily body, soft carbonation, medium duration slightly boozy finish. (4/5)

I usually find baltic porters a bit too sweet for my preference, but this one has the body and presence to pull it off. Alcohol doesnt significantly affect the flavour, but is definitely present in the finish and a pleasant warming. Definite slow sipper for savouring. (17/20)

355ml bottle pours black in color with a finger and a half of light brown head that leaves some spotty lacing behind. Aroma is chocolate and roasted grains with some alcohol. Taste is a roasted grain and citrus hop bitterness followed by a chocolate malty sweetness. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation leaving a pleasant sensation on the palate.

Bottle to tulip
Lots of caramel, licorice, soy, and molasses. Black with a tin tan ring. Dark chocolate, toasted malt, molasses and a hint of coffee and cherry. Very smooth for its alcohol content.

1100 rate! this beer has been on my WL forever! much thanks to springlicker (I think) for the bottle via trade. Favorite style and this is why.. aroma is roasted goodness; roasted cocoa, molasses? darrrk pour with brown lacing. Taste is smooth - toasted/roasted flavor with slight sweetness from molasses or dark fruit - some light alcohol burn at end (but no affect on taste). 2nd best Baltic! thx.

355ml bottle from 2015 Craft Beer Advent Calendar. Pours an opaque black with a small, short lived, chocolate brown head that leaves spotty lacing. Sweet aroma of roasted malt, dark chocolate, liquorice and vanilla. Sweet flavour of roasted malt, dark chocolate, dried fruit, liquorice and vanilla with a slightly bitter, warming alcohol finish. Medium to full body with an oily texture and soft carbonation. Excellent! A world class Baltic Porter for sure!

Pours black, moderate head. Aroma of chocolate, leather, pipe smoke, licorice.
Taste is chocolate, licorice, light smoke, so smooth, this is delicious.
A faint brown sugar taste. Body is a creamy mouthful with a coffee and molasses blend. Good Baltic porter.

Bottle, kindly donated by my Secret Santa, many thanks Clownoisseur. Shared with my daughter. Almost black color with huge beige head. Roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, licorice. Dark malt, coffee beans, dark chocolate, vanilla, licorice. Alcohol is evident, but not in disturbing way. Delicious.

Pour is deep black with brown around the edging when the lighting hits it right. Aroma is licorice. Taste is licorice. Party on Wayne! Party on Garth! If you dont get that, watch Waynes World. Bad licorice! ;) This is good licorice, though. Goes down smooth and easy, you wouldnt guess this was a 9% ABV. Nothing outstanding or overtly complex, but very drinkable and reasonable satisfying.

Poured from a bottle. 
Aroma is a balanced blend of roast and chocolate with a medium light leather and tobacco note. A hint of smoke with some light notes of plum, prune and raisin. Faint alcohol present. 
Pours a dark brown, not quite black, with a large, moderately thick mocha head that shows decent retention as it recedes. Medium light lacing and moderate legs. 
Flavor is slightly sweet, getting sweeter mid palate. Moderate chocolate notes with light roast and hints of tobacco and leather. Faint smoke. Medium light bitterness and faint alcohol notes. Light plum and prune with moderate raisin in the finish. 
Mouthfeel is medium full bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and low, but noticeable alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a pretty nice beer in both the aroma and flavor. Nice fruitiness that works well with the dark malt notes. Fruit esters and malt are both complex.
Subdued aroma of smoke, coffee and a hint of cocoa. Rich dark color with a lasting small tan head. Smoky chocolate taste with a creamy feel and a chocolate finish.

bottle from the rotter. pours nearly black with a reddish brown head that fizzes up then dies after ten seconds. Nose is super sherry and oxidized. strong dried fruit aroma, cherry skins. Taste is a sharp, stinging fruitiness with a ton of carbonation. Literally is stinging on the lips. Never experienced that one before. Taste is like a cherry fruit roll up with a light red wine and wood tannin type of flavor. All of this seems a bit off and likely because the beer is on the older side. Would like to re try this fresh

Bottle from bytemesis, thanks man! Pitch black pour with a light tan head. Nose has licorice, light peat, caramel and some chocolate. Taste is smooth, licorice, caramel, light smoke, ashe and some dark dried fruits. Good stuff!

355ml bottle, thanks to my Secret Santa rayg1!
BBE 12/15 - Pours pitch black with a small brown head. Aroma of licorice, roasty malts, dark chocolate, cocoa, sweet berries and hops. Taste is smooth, roasty and heavy with dark chocolate notes, hints of berries, licorice and cocoa. Finish is smooth, roasty and complex with some notes of berries and dark chocolate. Quite nice and balanced.

Bottle thanks to Bursprak. 

Pours pitch black with a medium brown head. 

Aromas of dark fried fruits, mostly raisins, chocolate, weak smoke, caramel locrice, malts.

Taste is dark chocolate, licorice, raisins, prunes, coffee, light roast, salmiak.

Bottle thanks to Bursprak. Pours black with a brown head. Aroma of dark raw grainy malts, sweet liquorice, chocolate, dark sweet fruits, caramel and some weak smoked notes. The taste has cocoa, dark malts, chocolate fudge, weak liquorice and very gentle roasted malts. Nice One!

Bottle thanks to Bursprak! Pours a pitch black with a smooth, brown head. Aroma has dark, slight smoky, smooth roasty malts, licorice, slight caramel. Taste is very smooth, medium sweet, lightly roasty bitter, coffee. Very smooth body and a medium carbonation. Good, balanced stuff!

355 ml bottle. Thanks tiong!
Pours black color with a small head. Aroma is very malty and roasty, lots of cocoa and dark chocolate too, maybe faint nuts also. Lots of cocoa on the flavor as well, roasted malts, subtle spiciness, hints of coffee. Rich and complex, very drinkable still. Excellent.
4316

355 ml bottle. Pours a pitch black colour with a small creamy head. Aroma of rich roastiness, nuts and strong cacao notes. Rich flavour of roastiness, sweet caramel, grassy bitterness, mild yeastiness, earth and spiciness. Almost full bodied. Creamy mouthfeel. Surprisingly good drinkability for a 9% beer. Great.

33 cl bottle @ lusikka, no BBE info found.
Aroma is rather mellow with some cocoa and toffee typical to English ales. Flavour has toffee, licorice and some herbal tones - feels like a basic English stout. Nothing special here, I wonder why this is rated so high.
Snowpacalypse 15 beer #2. Dark dark brown. Nice dark chocolate, light dark fruits, some roast, coffee, fruity yeast. Pretty nice on this snowy eve.
This beer is deep and rich. A full blooded roasty character is balanced. Tastes like a russian traditional beer from our friends at duck rabbit.
Bottle. Pours a black color with beige head. Roasty, toffee, malty, slight chocolate aromas. Roasty, cocoa, toffee, slight char, slight alcohol flavors.
Bottle at Brony Tasting, DC. Pale sour chocolate malt, funky odd sweetness. Lots of wort flavors. Didnt live up to expectations for me.
Bottle at the DC Tasting. Dark brownish black. Aromas of malt, chocolate, caramel. Tastes of caramel, chocolate, maple syrup. Medium-light body with a dry finish.
Bottle @ Travlrs. deep brown with a small head. Nose is very roasty. Toasted grain and donuts. Chocolate. Honey and coffee. Quite complex. Rich malts. Cocoa. Medium body, soft carb.

Pours very dark , almost black . Smell is slightly coffee, some roasted grains . Taste is bit bitter , chocolate , roasted malts . Good carbo , rather thin mouthfeel . Some harsh booze ( not much though )
Bottled pours dark with almost no head. black cherry bit of oak. OK but needs better body. The lack of arb hurts.

Pours black with a faint tan head. Somewhat thin. Less oily and slightly watered down version of a good Stout. Flavor is OK but not great. The dried fruit flavors had more of a black licorice taste. Very smooth with no harshness or bitterness. From what I had read I have been waiting for some time to find this and try it. I was somewhat disappointed as it didnt live up to the hype.

12 oz. thanks to Brian on this one. Pitch black with thin tan head. Great roasted notes with ash, chocolate and mils dark fruit tones. 
Texture of the brew as an ash quality that shows deep roasted notes that linger well after the sip. Body is on the fuller side of medium with mild charred oak in the finish. The best way to drink a brew is without any expectations. Willrunforbeer had this cellared for a long while and it stood the test of time and was a very nice drink.

From notes. 12 oz bottle shared 3 ways. Pours dark chocolate brown with a milk chocolate head. Aroma is dark dried fruits, chocolate. Flavor follows, chocolate, raisin, date. Bakers chocolate bitterness in the finish.
bottle. thick black with one finger head. malty with quite lot of roasty nut flavor. chocolate, toffee, anise, some caramel. bitter finish with a bit of booze.
Draft. Jet black with little head. Nice notes of chocolate, caramel, peanut brittle, roasted malt and coffee. Slightly thin. Very complex and delicious.

Bottle. Pours almost black with a slight dark tan head. Smells like sweet raisin bread. So many flavors with raisin, malts, roasted nuts, some hint of cocoa, plum, and a little bitter. Medium body with a lingering sticky finish of roasty goodness. Delicious and complex. My favorite Baltic Porter that I look forward to every year.
Smooth dark chocolate, and some roast espresso on the nose. Just great. Super smooth chocolate across the palate, and sweet roast finish. Medium bodied. Lingering espresso.
Pours black with a nice tan head. Char, chocolate, malt aroma. Taste similar to aroma with chocolate cherries mixed in. Good beer

Transfer from BA review on 3-22-13-

 Served on tap in a 10 oz chalice glass

 Appearance  Served a deep brown nearly black brew with a thick and creamy one finger tan colored head. The head has a nice level of retention, slowly fading over about 5 min to leave a moderate level of lace on the sides of the glass.

 Smell  The aroma is big of dark and roasty smells. A sweet dark fruit aroma of cherry and plum are mixed with dark chocolate and a good presence of a roasted malt smell. Along with these are some notes of a light caramel nature as well as a good presence of a boozy smell that overall creates a very warming smell.

 Taste  The flavor begins with a relatively healthy amount of dark fruit and a roasted malt tastes. Cherry, prune and raisin are all present upfront and are quickly met with other flavors of a dark chocolate nature soon after the initial tastes. As the flavor advances further the fruit grows slightly less intense with other flavors of some more roasted malt taking its place. Toward the end the darker flavors of chocolate and roasted malt are now most potent and are joined by a complementing smoke and alcohol taste which in the end leave a nice dark but still sweeter more burnt flavor to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the brew is on the creamier side with a carbonation level that is on the lower side of the scale. The thicker and creamier body are great for helping all the roasted, chocolate and smoky flavors of the brew to really stand out while the lighter carbonation, coupled with the creamy nature and the boozy taste at the end, make it a nice sipping beer.

 Overall  A good sweeter Baltic porter that is nice to sit back with and sip over a nice cool evening. A rather enjoyable brew and one to try if you get the opportunity.

Best enjoyed by 12/2014. 12 oz into a tulip. Pours a pitch black with little edging. Nose is chocolate, coffee, and roast malts. Hint of salted peanuts and dark fruit. Taste is deeply roasted malts and milk chocolate. Thick and coating. A no frills baltic porter. Just a smidge behind Jacks Abby but incredibly solid.

Super rich malty aroma with notes of toffee, chocolate, toasted bread and fruity esters. Dark brown with a tan head with good head retention. Flavor is malt forward and sweet. Dark fruit esters are high. Roasted malt lingers on the end and drys it out. Mouthfeel is full-bodied with medium low carbonation. Overall an excellent beer. A little too much roast for a Baltic porter though. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

First let's me start by saying that I am loving this beer. The only reason for the low score is because they put Baltic porter on the label. If you are going to declare a style it should taste like the style. Besides it being way to high in abv it also has way to much roast and more of a RIS flavor then anything else. I am loving the beer. But couldn't be labeled more incorrectly 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

20...10? Bottle.

Sweet rich fruityness, cocoa, smooth, velvety texture, complex, flavorful, great great beer.
Black with a beige head. Aroma is cocoa, molasses, vanilla, caramel. Full bodied, velvety mouthfeel, nicely balanced palate. Taste is chocolate, cocoa, lactic tang, sour cherry. Amazing.

Bottle. A near black body is topped by a small tan head that dissipates quickly. The nose is very raisiny, with a bit of raspberry, a little roasted malt, and some earthy bitter chocolate. Taste is moderately sweet and mildly bitter. In the mouth, the raisins are there along some tart cherry, roast, and unsweetened chocolate. Medium bodied and smooth. A very balanced roasty/sweet/tart finish. Initially too much raisin for my tastes but it opened up nicely and was very good.

12oz bottle from The Beer Store Wilson. Black hue, thick pour, zero visibility with fully lasting 1/4" frothy khaki head. Okay lacing. Milk chocolate and a hint of roasted coffee, as it warmed I got more of a dark fruit aroma. Heavy bitter coffee up front with a medium lasting milk chocolate finish. Creamy mouthfeel.

Bottle split at Bruces pad, thanks to Leighton, 27/03/14. 
Light black with a big tan head that quickly dissipates to a swirl and edgeing.
Nose is bitter dark fruits, lactic ring, soured dark berries, light smoke.
Taste comprises tarte dark berries, lactic tones, tangy dark fruit, light roast and hint of cocoa both of which are overidden by the lactic notes.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, drying close.
Ok and drinkable but this is infected.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Pours a dark brown, almost black. Aroma is smoky, roasted malts with hints of acidity and a light caramel sweetness. Taste is roasted, smoky malts with a very faint sweetness and a juicy acidity. Hints of black coffee. Palate is thick body, medium carbonation. Overall a very good porter.
36cl, American brew, thx to Nils!, complex Porter, roasted/malty and slightly smoked/spicy/fruity, very balanced, hazy, good head, very good brew

Pours a dark brown, almost black. Little-to-no head, minimal lacing. Looks a little flat. Aroma is subtle but nice. Roasted nuts, sweet molasses, hints of spice and alcohol. Taste is much more rich than I was expecting from the appearance and aroma. Nice toasty malt with plenty of earthy nut character. Some hints of bitter coffee but balanced by thick molasses. The mouthfeel is full, oily, slick and slightly under-carbonated. FInishes with a lasting sweetness and a moderate warming alcohol. Some rusty flavors in there as well. Interesting beer.

P: A black abyss capped with a full inch of frothy cappuccino head. Thick sexy garter lacing around the edge like hugging a succulent thigh coaxing you closer to the sweet treat that awaits you.S: Bitter chocolate, almond butter, smoky wood, charred grains and burnt molasses.T/M: Charred malts, stale coffee, bitter sweet chocolate covered berries, smoke, hints of cardboard, black pepper, black strap molasses and almond butter. Medium feel and vivacious.O: I have chosen wisely for my first Baltic porter. Sweet, smoky, semi bitter and prickly on the tongue. I will have to grab a six of this next time in our. Cheers! Serving type: bottle
from trade, first north carolina beer for me. decent for a baltic porter, but just not my favorite - slightly empty taste with some odd aftertaste.

On tap at Taco Mac. Nearly black with mocha head; nice sticky lacing. Aroma is chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, dark fruit notes and lactose. Taste is similar. Mostly getting the chocolate and roast along with some vanilla extract; was hoping for a bit more of the ripe fruit. Body is smooth and creamy. A touch thin with soft carbonation, so goes down easy. 9% ABV is well hidden. The dark fruit I was looking for starts to present itself in the finish as the beer warms (delicious). Good stuff.

Bottle shared in London - picked up in NC. Pours clear, deep brown with a frothy, beige head. The nose has some metal, generous roast, rusting metal. Medium sweet flavor, quite tangy, some sour cherries, a bit of roast, grapes, prunes. Medium bodied with fine to average carbonation. Sour finish, a bit of funk, burnt earth, lasting roast, touches of alcohol warmth. This beer seems infected. Shame. Still drinkable and interesting but not what it ought to be.

Bottle thanks to Leighton. It pours darkest brown with a small tan head. The nose is earthy, toasty, smoke, caramel, treacle, cola, earth, toast and roast. The taste is very tangy, berry yoghurt, earth, toast, jam, dark fruits, light alcohol and some acid burn in the background. Medium body and fine carbonation. Infected methinks. Dont taste right. Tangy.
UPDATED: MAR 16, 2014 Draft at Closed For Business. GAWDDAM! This is a great beer. I could drink this for a while.

Poured from a 12oz bottle I got in a trade. Aroma is big roasty coffee and chocolate. Flavors are coffee, roast, vanilla, caramel, and light hop character. Actually well balanced for a big porter. Great beer!

12 oz bottle into a pint glass.

A: Pours an extremely dark ruby color. The head is a one finger khaki shade, and its superbly creamy in texture even for the style. Retention is okay, too.

S: This seems to be very woody in its aroma, almost oaky, even. Theres also a great element of cocoa powder here, along with some smoke and tart cherries. What dominates the aroma is roasted, slightly charred malts - and thats a good thing. <3 roast. Really a nice aroma.

T: Like many good Baltic porters (the one Smuttynose makes, for instance), the predominant note is vaguely tart malt mixed with a charred roast. Meanwhile, the initial flavors are very chocolaty. Not quite a 4-level flavor profile, but it isnt far off from that mark, either.

M: It could use slightly more body, but otherwise, the crisp finish is very satisfying. Even still It seems designed more for drinkability than savorability, and its successful in that regard. There isnt a hint of alcohol anywhere on the palate, and the carbonation is rather low. 

O: A delicious and very worthy example of the style. While I did praise its drinkable nature, one is enough in a sitting. Id buy it again, thats for damn sure.

Big chocolate coffee and vanilla notes.
Looks like a porter. Pours a dark brown. nice head.
Very complex taste. Vanilla note is really big. Nice chocolate and coffee and roasty notes. But also stays true to the porter style having a nice metallic finish. I think this might have a bit more hops than other porters but thats ok. 
Palate is nice and smooth. A little agressive on the back of the palate.

Overall this is a really solid beer. Nice flavor notes and stays true to the porter style while being robust. A little more metallicy and with some more hops than other porters or stouts.

Bottle. Pours black with thin tan head and spots of lace. Aroma is roast, caramel, dark fruit, chocolate. Medium to full body, light carb. Taste of roast, spice, coffee, baking chocolate, notes of earth and faint smoke. Slightly warming. Top notch for a Baltic porter.

Bottle. Pours a deep brown-black with little head. Nice aroma of roasted malts, dark fruits, and alcohol. Flavor has all of the expected elements of a baltic porter - coffee, dark fruits, chocolate, a hint of yeast. The finish is subtle and complex, with fruit, tobacco, and earth notes. Very nice.
this beer was fantastic with hints of vanilla and roast character that was spot on not overdone for the style and not even a hint of 9% alcohol
(Growler from dvines) Opaque brown body with a thin brown bread. Nutty, chocolate, dark roasted aroma. Full bodied, velvety soft mouthful. Sweet, chocolate, dark fruity flavor.

Pours very dark brown with thin very brief head. Aroma dark caramel, molasses. Taste does change quite a bit as you go, initially a little bit of oxidation and metallic flavor intrudes but fades out. Caramel, a bit of ash dark cherries, cocoa, licorice and molasses all appear. A touch of umami. palate a bit thin but decent, does coat the palate well. Pleasant roasty finish. Pretty good, let it warm up some.
12 oz bottle. Pours a jet black, with a small tan head that fades quickly. Nose is malt and caramel roast. Taste is layered and complex, but never harsh. Velvety smooth. Delicious.

This beauty is a lot more complex than its Porter sister. Although they look virtually identical in the glass, nice and black with a mentionable but not unforgetable off-white head, the aroma here is dark chocolate, also very strong, plus dulce de leche, and a good dose of booze. The flavours open into a broader, multi-layered horizon, with bitter chocolates, caramels, salty fudge, chinese red vinegar, Dutch salty liquorice, plums, cranberries, molasses, kicap manis, vegemite... oh such a vast array, not sure whether a foreign stout or a baltic porter. The absence of roasts though confirm the style. This is a creamy, full-bodied beauty. 

I should perhaps single out the detail on the Estonian (?) touque/knit cap placed  on that misterious animal that figures on the labels of these great beers. The position of the touque reveals the true identity of this creature.

12 oz bottle, thanks to fletchfighters. Served at cellar temperature. I had never heard of the Duck-Rabbit before this. Pours deep, dark brown with off-white head that dissipates to a ring of bubbles that sticks around for the duration of this drink. Aroma: First thing I smell is cherries. Thats followed by some alcohol, which is followed by roast, which is followed by smoke (my wife immediately said "beef jerky," to which I replied "yeah! and band-aids!"). Taste: Moderately sweet, with surprisingly dry finish. Other flavors that come up once it gets in my mouth include marshmallow (full disclosure: I read a friends review, but as soon as I went looking for it the marshmallow was unmistakably present) and roasted nuts. Initially I wasnt too keen on this, but it definitely grew on me as the glass went on. Palate: medium-full body, slick texture that fully coats the inside of my mouth. Overall: Ive encountered a lot of beers that are awesome over the first few ounces but are hard to finish a full glass of. This one was the opposite -- the first 2-3 ounces were disappointing (I mean, not bad or anything, but the flavors didnt really seem to gel, and certainly didnt approach what the 796 people before me have averaged out to), but by the second half of the bottle it all sort of got there. At 2-3 ounces Id give this something like a 3.6. By the end its a 4. Im going to split the difference.
Tap to pint glass at the Vintner. Pours deep black with a cream head. Rich malty flavor of malt and oats thats perfect for the style. Definite alcohol burn. Love it.
Almost black body w/ khaki head. Dark roasted malt, smoky aromas. Coffee, burned toast, smoke & nut flavors. Medium bodied, full flavored.

Bottle into snifter glass, dark black with dark tan lacing (no real head). Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, smoke, kind of a red wine note and earthy hops. Taste adds notes of dark chocolate, dark coffee, raisins, berries, caramel, molasses and a faint vinegary-sour note. Medium heavy body, low carbonation, rich, soft, creamy with ashy roast finish. This is RBs #1 Baltic porter for a reason, enjoying this very good sipper.
Bottle, aroma is rich roasted malt and pine resin. Taste is nice roast and a bitter dry finish, medium bodied, sessionable

Dark stout black almost reminiscent of a stout but more lagerish (that sounds off but it is a porter). Not as much coffee/chocolate tones, still pesent. Dryer than you would expect. Hoppy but not overwhelming. Sour but not harsh. Almost black cherry-like in its sourness - especially in the aftertaste. Almost no head from the bottle which I think is good. The flavor offsets the alcohol very well.

Shared a bottle on the Zillies deck- kudos to them for amazing selection for a tiny town. Pours a dark brown and almost completely flat- lack of any head is a bit off putting. Nose is dark chocolate and earthy notes. Taste is super mellow- perfect for sipping on a chilly winter night. Definite sour notes in there- almost like a good sourdough. Cherry sweetness and almost no bitterness- but still well balanced. Solid, solid beer.  The fact that it is bottom fermented adds to interest factor- cant judge this book by its cover.  Taste definitely changes as beer warms to room temp- like getting two beers in one bottle.  Alcohol is almost too much- little bit reminiscent of a nice port.
Bottle from Lazy Dog. Aroma of chocolate and malts. Taste of chocolate, malt and oak. Great, great beer.
Bottle from Lazy Dog. Pours dark opaque black with a thin layer of toffee colored head. Aroma of coffee and roasted malts. Taste of coffee, chocolate, and roasty goodness.

Pours fizzy into a very dark brown with a tan head that resolves quickly to a tiny rim - leaving a glossy oil slick. Aroma is earthy malts and nuts - slightly sour. Just a hint of chocolate. Taste has real depth. Roasted malts give way to chocolate with coffee and a pervasive booze-backed sourness that lingers through the finish and beyond. The effect truly approximates the flavor of sour cherries. As this beer warms these flavors really open up. This makes for a distinctive beer with some real craft. Very enjoyable!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Smells of unsweetened dark chocolate. Pours a nightly black with little to no head. So smooth! You get the roasted/smoked taste with a silky smooth finish. This brew lives up to all of its expectations and more!

355 ML bottle

Black with a tad of ruby at the top. Just a collar of light brown head. Some spotty lacing. 
Great nose. Chocolate brownie, caramel dark fruits, licorice, somewhat port like, and lots of roasted malts. 
Lots of roast, bitter chocolate, earthy oak notes, coffee, slightly sour, and dark fruits. Nice stuff
Medium bodied, still chewy though, light carbonation. Great example of the style

No notches for dating.

A: pours a black ale with a single finger of fine, mocha head which dissipates to a thin and broken film. Spotty lacing.

S: Oh yes, this I like. malt, molasses, caramel, anise, licorice, brown sugar, chewy nose. Thick and delicious. Chocolate covered cherries.

T: Roasted malts, dark fruits, raisin. Graham. cocoa. sweet malts. did I mention the dark, sweet, complex and difficult to articulate malts? Long flavor finish for minutes on end. This is great, nitro would be insane. Chocolate covered bing cherry.

M: Medium body with high carb for the style. Dry finish.

O: Fantastic brew. Likely among my favorite baltic porters. Wish the carb was just a hare lower.

Serving type: bottle

05-16-2011
Poured black with a very minimal tan head. On the nose hints of chocolate, coffee and sweetness. On the tongue dark roasty malts, finishes with a smoothness and a small alcohol bite.

Bottle, thanks sevenhokie! Great aroma to start off with dark fruit and chocolate and a tiny bit of coffee. Pours black with a thin, light brown head and excellent lacing. Taste is chocolate up front with the dark fruit less prominent. Finishes velvety smooth with the hint of coffee coming through slightly. Chocolate notes linger on the palate after tasting. Really, really awesome beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle for 3 bucks. Pours black with no head to speak of. Aroma is licorice, a little fruity and some chocolate. Taste is similar but more heavy on the chocolate side, with a little coffee flavoring in there as well. Body is like most Duck-Rabbit beers, thinner than I like for the style of beer. Feels a little too carbonated as well. Overall another solid offering from Duck-Rabbit. This is a very good Baltic Porter but could be a little better.

Bottle 355ml.
Pours very dark brown with low light brown head. No lacing. Aroma is of molasses (slightly rancid), licorice, peat, nuts, raisins. Taste is of peat, roasted malt, licorice, old coffee, minerals, alcohol, burnt caramel. Palate: Medium-full bodied. Overall: Weird. Special. "Complex" but some of the aspects are not on the good side, i.e. the burnt rancid molasses.

Pour is black with a tiny dirty ring that leaves some lacing. Nose is really spicy with star anise in the lead along with licorice and other spices over a dark fruits base. Taste has a weird metallic quality and some light green apple. Otherwise it is sweet and roasty. Medium-full bodied with a smooth carbonation. I wasnt a huge fan of this one...

Bottle (12 oz). From AlexFields, thanks! Reddish brown with a small beige head and no lacing. Aroma is of peated notes, port, raisins, liquorice and molasses with light "garbage presence". Taste is of raisins, light/moderate sweetness, molasses, malt and a light (more than in the aroma) garbage presence. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Complex. Slightly "off", but still interesting.

pours unclear very dark brown with a small light beige cap, some retention and lacing. raisins, port, coca-cola, ormaybe more dr. pepper, hazelnuts, burnt caramel, umami, some garbage juice unfortunately. moderate carbonation - numerous small bubbles, slightly disturbing the mouthfeel, light to medium body - oily, assertive bitter coffee, grassy and mineral finish. nice.

At my place by myself. This was an extra, I have not heard of it. Pours suit black with pretty much zero head. Aroma is huge scotch and booze with some caramel and nutty malt. Not sure if I smell Baltic vinegar or it is in my head due to the word association. taste is caramel, vinegar tang, smooth chocolaty malt, but has that Baltic bite. Im not sure if I like or dislike the Baltic notes, but is is very smooth and tasty. One of the better Baltic porters I have had; I am normally a robust porter man.
Bottled. black, with pretty lace. Big chocolate nose, fudge, cocoa, meaty, mint. Sweet dark chocolate flavor with beef gravy and lots of umami, light soy, fruit. Very interesting, savory, and nice.

12oz. Pours near black with a mocha head. Aromas of roasted malts, dark fruit, coffee, and chocolate. Thick body on this guy. Flavor is chocolate, coffee, fudge, hint of alcohol, and a full finish. Awesome beer!!
Awesome baltic porter from my home state of NC, dark rich beer, pretty strong too, nice brew for xmas time

Poured from a bottle, very dark and thick. Small head and little carbonation. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt, dark fruit, cherries, and the taste follows the aroma. This is a great beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Plums and caramel. Sweet and full. Very nice beer. Very nice. Had at micro boss.

12 ounce bottle. Thanks Mike! Pours almost black with a very small tan head. Aroma of roast, chocolate, dark fruit, and smoke. Taste is roasted malt, dark chocolate, dark fruit. smoke, licorice, and a bit of alcohol. I enjoyed this very much! Wish I had more!!

12 ounce bottle from Timfoolery, aroma is chocolate, flavor is sweet , roasted finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
One of the best porters Ive had so far. Great chocolate, a little soy, roasty but not smokey, and very enjoyable.
A bold black pour with some brown head. A strong coffee aroma with some hint of whiskey. Taste is a nice balanced mix of chocolate and coffee, also with a hint of whiskey.
Pours jet black with no head. Aroma of chocolate, molasses and roast. Taste is chocolatey. Chewy dark chocolate brownie. Very nice Baltic porter.
From a bottle. Pours very dark opaque brown with no head. Extremely smooth. Tastes smokey, sweet, and sour. Smells like toffee, dried fruit, and spices. Medium body and low carbonation.

Tap. Pours opaque black with a trace of fizzy, tan head. Aroma is chocolate and roasted malts, light coffee, earthy notes, vanilla, toffee, plums, and raisins. Flavor is roast malts forward with supporting notes of chocolate, caramel, earthy hops, dates, raisins, and light woody notes; dry, ashy finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Draft at Taphouse/Queensway.  Dark and murky, as youd expect from a Baltic.  Rich!  Fun anise and cream flavors, this is FAR too drink for a 9% ABV beer.  (#4966, 3/17/2013)

12 oz bottle poured into a Hair of the Dog tulip. Deep aromas of dark fruits, coconut and a hint of roasted malts. I pick up more ripe figs than anything else. Pours a  nice and dark with a nice tan head with very little retention. Carbonation dies quickly. Taste is sweet with some soy and all those dark fruits. Lingering sugars, and fruit on the tongue, subtle roasted malts, medium carbonation, a little creamy. Dont pick up much hop bitterness. Overall Im not a fan of the dark fruits... brings back nightmares of Dark Lord. As it warmed up it got a little worse in my opinion.

Acquired in a trade from bytemesis. Thanks. I was amazed by this beer. It pours a deep brown. I could believe the mouth feel. so creamy. Malty taste but balanced. Slightly sweet. Yet balanced. A perfect beer for me.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Total Wine-Vienna, 3/17/13


Aroma: The aroma has roasted malts, some dark fruits, liquorice, and a booze

Appearance: Pours an opaque dark brown-black color with a thin beige head and spotty lace

Flavor: The taste is has some sweetness to it, lots of roast, and a boozy hit to the finish

Palate: This one is medium-full bodied, it drinks fairly smoothly, and it has a lengthy, hot finish

Overall Impression: 
This is a pretty interesting beer.  It has is an excellent example of the style and a really well-made beer.  I liked this one quite a bit.

Bottle from 08ish.  Pours black with thin, white head. Chocolate nose with licorice, date, plums and raisins.  Chocolate and roast, raisin and dry.  Tasty, solid.  Darn good.  Aged really, really well.

Location/Date:Bottle on February 28th, 2013.
Appearance: Pours motor oil black with no head.
Aroma: Aroma of licorice, faint caramel.
Taste: Licorice, caramel, faint bitter.
Palate:Medium body, slick, lingering aftertaste. Covers alcohol well.
Summary: The top rated Baltic porter, this is some potent stuff.  Duck Rabbit as always makes a tasty brew, I better sip it.

Thanks to MaxwellDeus for bringing me the top-rated Baltic Porter on Ratebeer (as of this date). Dark chocolate malt intensive, with some rum and perhaps even candy sugar. Appearance is black with messy, bubbly mocha head. Flavor starts with subtle chocolate character, then a crescendo into rich, malty boozy character. Palate is medium, oily and soft. Pretty good stuff.

Classic Duck-Rabbit - extremely avoidable.  My brother has a theory that each brewer has a taste that flows through all their beers...  D-R has that taste for me, and it just doesn't do anything for me.   

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Brick Store Pub. Inky black pour with a frothy white head that lasts forever and laces all over. Roasty, nutty, smoky and tobacco aroma with hints of earth. Flavor is pretty similar with a certain dry and powdery mouthfeel and bitter chocolate finish. Pretty Good.

From bottle to tulip. Pours a deep black-brown. Malty aroma, maybe some soy sauce. Not again duck-rabbit. This has started to turn just like the last Duck-Rabbit beer I have had. Only drinking it 2 months after the enjoy by date. Oh well. still drinkable, just a slight bit sour. Definitely some chocolate in there too.

Edit: After reading some other reviews it looks like Duck-Rabbit has had some bottling problems.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2014 12oz bottle, with no notch on date strip, poured into a Avery nonic. 
A: The beer is a deep dark brown color, with a moderate tan head that fades slowly. Thick lacing is left on the glass at first, but only spotty lacing after the head dies down.

The aroma has a very pronounced dark chocolate note, plenty of dark roasted malts, a little hops and coffee, and some dark fruit. It also has a hint of molasses.

T: The taste has a slight bit of sourness, but otherwise the off-note is much diminished. Otherwise, the aromatic components are repeated in the flavor, with the addition of a little smoky and earthy tint. The bitter-sweet and slightly smoky after-taste ;ingers for a good while and features chocolate, coffee and dark malts.

M: Full bodied and smooth, with somewhat high, medium carbonation. A light harshness and warming from the high ABV. 

O: Rich, fruity and distinct version of this style may not appeal to all baltic porter fans.

(Review tweaked with better smelling 12 oz bottle on Halloween, 2014).

Tap. Pours opaque black, small brown head, nice lacing. Aroma is dark roasted malt, tobacco, coffee, anise. Flavor is the same, medium sweet, anise finish. Full body, creamy, light warming finish. I was really looking forward to this one and it just didnt do it for me. Oh well.

Refrigerated 12 oz. brown bottle poured into a snifter.  Pours black with large dark brown hightlights.  Little lacing, medium/thin body, low carbonated, and aweful sour aroma.  Taste is off balsamic vingar.  Off bottle I suspect.
Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. Aroma is shit and piss. Maybe some vinegar. Taste is more of the same, but maybe a little more chocolate. Bad.
Midnight black. No head. Aroma is roasted chestnuts, walnuts and chocolate. Taste is malty and sweet with a lot of nuttiness. Some chocolate and coffee with birch at the finish

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2013 Had two of these from 2009 in 2013.  The first I loved.. smooth, malty, chocolately.. with some funkiness.  The last I had about a month later, tasted like a sour coin that someone shoved up their arse.. I had to pour it out.  Whether it had aged too muc h or what.. I dont know, but I will go with the middle ground.

Color is black with a tan/brown head. Smells like an imperial stout to me. Mouth feel is medium bodied with ample carbonation, even after four years of cellaring. Tastes of  roasted malt, molasses, slight smokiness,hay and maybe a bit of dark chocolate. Overall an excellent beer, definitely the best porter Ive had to date. The alcohol is very well hidden.
roasty, herbs, earthy, brown, cloudy, brown foam, heavy cloying sweetness, full body, creamy, long finish,

From a 12 oz bottle shared at home.  Pours black with a tan head.  Rich caramel in the nose.  Chewy mouthfeel.  Flavors of roasted malt with hints of toffee.  Smooth, slightly boozy finish.  A real fine porter.

Opaque with almost no head. Aromas of licorice, cocoa and coffee beans. Bittersweet chocolate flavors accompany notes of dark fruit, coffee and licorice. Not overly bitter, shows some restraint on the roasted malts. Almost slick feeling on the palate. Very easy to drink given its 9% abv. Nice stuff.

12 oz. bottle from Southern Season.

Ar:  Fairly roasty aroma, rich chocolate.
Ap:  Pours a deep, thick black with a very small light brown head.
T:  Very rick, deep roasted flavor.  Chocolate, fairly sweet; mild finish is a touch acidic.  Fairly moderate alcohol on the finish with a bit of roast.
P:  Very thick, a bit oily with fairly assertive carbonation for a big porter.

O:  Really nice.

12oz bottle----> snifter.  Pours an inky black with little to no head.  Aroma is licorice and soy with some oak.  Taste follows aroma with a bitter bite at the swallow and alcohol with a bit of dark chocolate.  Pretty thick palate with enough chalkiness to let you know its still a porter.  Reminds me a little more of an impy stout, but still a great beer.

One of my bigger wants for a while and I was happy to get it as an extra in a trade.  Glad Im getting a chance to try this now.  Best by 12-12 bottle served in a snifter.  Ink black pour with a short lived light brown head.  Aroma is soy sauce and white glue.  Taste is vicious like a merlot, with cola and cold coffee.  Thin in the mouth with a drying finish.  Acidic. Im sure this bottle sat too long and probably under suboptimal conditions. Would,like to,try a fresher one.

Bottle from Justin. Aroma is light roast, cocoa nibs, some soy, and slight licorice. Flavor is more focused on soy and roast/smoke. Very full flavor with an exacting palate. The "best" Baltic porter and the best baltic porter I've had.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle shared with Timfoolery. Roasty chocolate smell with a dark brown appearance. Very full flavored. Tasted of chocolate and a little hint of soy sauce flavor. Very solid brew.

Bottle. Poured into a goblet. Nice big light brown head on top of a near-black body. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, roasted malts. Taste is the same. A bit overly bitter. But nice dry finish that really lingers.

4th July 2011Opaque black beer, good light brown head. Softish palate and a tiny bit of dry. Creamy malt, mild dark character. Nice fruits - strawberry with a little cherry and raspberry. Mild dark chocolate undertone. One of the fruitiest porters Ive had in many a long yonk.

From notes - Sample pour of deep dark with tan head.  Nose is sweet malt, caramel, smooth, toffee and burnt sugar.. Lightly roasted.  Flavor is fantastic!! Sweet caramel all over, burnt sugar, light roasted flavor, but intense and heavenly.  Theres a reason this is rated the way it is.  Medium to full body with light lacing.

Roasted cocoa, espresso, and a whiskey-like booziness.  Dark brown to black, with a minimal khaki head.  Taste is bitter, with boozy characters that fume in the sinus cavity, along with dry roasty, and bitter hoppy flavors.  A medium-bodied porter, with light carbonation, and a very boozy finish.

12oz bottle poured into glass. Dark creamy pour, very little head with good carbonation. Aroma carries hints of dark chocolate and roasted malts. Flavor has hints of charred woody characters that lingers long on the palate. Very tasty and interesting.
Bottle. Nose is extremely inviting and amazing. Great roasting and toasty notes in there. Taste has much of the same elements, but is super smooth and easy to drink.

Pours an opaque black with one finger ruby/tan head with with light ot moderate lacing.  Roasted malt with hint of coffee, dark fruit, and vodka like booziness to it. Sweet up front, but acrid and bitter with the alcohol presence.  Medium body with light to medium carbonation. Long, smooth bitter and vodkalike finish.

Right off the pour, the alcohol notes hit you out of the glass. Not tame at 9%, it smells like it should be 14%. It comes out jet black, letting you know it means business. However, the taste is rich and smooth, with the heavy malt presence trying to tell you it doesnt even know what a hop is, and will kick your ass if you try to explain it.

Bottle, thanks Joel.  Dark brown/black color medium head with some dissipation.  Nice cocoa, caramel, coffee notes for the aroma.  Actually powerful aroma.  Some wood notes too.  Nice cocoa tastes with some caramel in the background.  Alchohol warms you.  Medium/heavy body  Nice.

Pours a deep ruby reddish brown. Aroma of dark syrupy malt. Taste is burnt roasted malt with a smokey bite that mixes well with a sweet finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thin skim of off-white foam coating the surface of a deep, dark brown opaque body. "Lacing" and "retention" are two words you probably dont need here. The aroma is a mix of dark roasted cereals and sweet lactose. In the mouth, this porter is very smooth and slick with vibrant carbonation that you feel at the back of your throat. Lots of great roasted flavors jump out - bitter coffee; dry, dark chocolate; lactose sweetness. Finish is a lasting milk sugar sourness with some smoke.
Bottle->snifter.  Jet black with faint head.  Powerful aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, dark fruits.  Flavor is complex, roasty and bitter.  Medium carbonation, good mouthfeel.  Excellent porter.
My favorite porter and maybe my favorite beer.   Midnight black, great taste.  Its so great that I wont have another porter for at least a month after my stockpile of this runs out.

Deep black body.  Thin khaki head.  Spotty lacing.  Nose is full of milk duds, dark fruits, mild roast.  Flavor is similar with a prominent milky-chocolate, roast, and prunes.  Medium to full bodied.  Smooth on the tongue.  Big but manageable.  A nice beer, but I prefer the additional complexity of the true Scandinavian porters (Sinebrychoff and Ølfabrikken).

Bottle. Dark pour with thin white head that recedes quickly. Aroma is really super fruity, some vinous notes, dark chocolate, plums, interesting. Taste is fruity as well, dried figs, lots of dark chocolate. Palate is thin and light bodied, very little carbonation, very dry finish. Not sure if this one is supposed to have more carbonation or not, but it was really nice.
This is by far the best porter I have ever had. absolutely incredible.  Go get some!

Pours a syrupy black with tan head.  Aroma is mollasses, semi sweet chocolate and a light roastiness.  Very tasty beer once it opened up and some of the metallic notes went away.  One of the best of the style.
A bit sharp and boozy. Took a while to open up. Good rich flavors inthere though, pretty solid brew
Purely amazing in every way you can think of. If you get a chance to have this beer DO

Bottle. Appearance: Black with a very quickly dissipating beige head. Aroma: Roasted malt, bitter chocolate, dark, ripe fruit (raisins, plums, prunes), alcohol Taste: Robust, dark roasted malt, prunes, bitter chocolate, and cocoa and some alcohol on the finish Mouthfeel: Medium creamy body with mid carbonation. Overall: very, very good showing. I'm generally not a huge fan of the dark fruits characteristics in this style but it is well done for the style. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Ported from BA

A- Opaque black, head fades almost instantly
S- Coffee, burnt/roasted malt
T- A lot of coffee, somewhat sweet, some roasted malt, fairly sour finish
M- Almost completely flat, decent consistency
O- I dont know if I got a bad bottle or not, but this one seemed a bit funky. The finish is quite sour, which I wasnt really expecting, and the coffee flavor is a bit overwhelming.

Serving type: bottle

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. Notes of chocolate, tart apple, roasted malts. There is a slight sourness, maybe do to oxidization. The sourness really detracts from the roasted malts and the maltiness.

A: Black with a beige head that fades after a few moments, leaving a nice lace ringlet on the glass.

S: Roasted malt, bitter chocolate, dark, ripe fruit (raisins, plums, prunes), alcohol

T: Robust, dark, with flavors of roasted malt, plums or prunes, bitter chocolate, and cocoa. This beer is pretty tasty :)

M: Medium feel. good carbonation level. a bit of a sticky, chewy aftertaste. ABV hidden pretty well.

D: I definitely recommend this beer, though one is plenty for me on any given occasion.

Bottle (thanks to Markwise). Pours black with a small brown head. Aroma of sweet roasted malts, sweet coffee, resins on alcohol. Full bodied, roasted bitterness, coffee, chicory, resins, sweet dessert-wine. Complex and good!

Via trade with Unclerudy.  The aroma is fruity, sweet dark chocolate, lightly roasted coffee.  The appearance is deep brown/black, light tan head.  The flavor is like the aroma, but the dark choolcate really jumps out, fruity, light roast, some molasses, very nice.  The finish is slightl alcohol burn (the only place the the alcohol is noticeable), roasty, pine needles, resin.  Medoim/thick in body.  Excellent.  Very well done. Thanks, Mike.

Draft to pilsner (2011 vintage). Looks good; dark with low carbonation and thin lacing. Smells good too; malty and boozy. Tastes very good; malty with a nice dry finish. Great stuff, and drinks like a lower abv beer.

12oz bottle. Poured a dark brown color, probably close to black but not quite, with a tan head. Aroma was chocolate notes, roasted malts, touch of coffee and toffee. Flavor was chocolate malts, roasted notes, with toffee and a touch of coffee. Alcohol is pretty well masked as this was quite drinkable. Enjoyed.
Sampled at the 2012 American Craft Beer Festival.  Pours black with a lot of malt in this brew.  Interesting, but not for me.

Ive had family in north carolina trying to track this down for me for years.  Aroma is roasty, metallic, and dark chocolate.  Tastes are dark fruits, molasses, bitter cocoa, coffee, caramel, and leather.  Finishes metallic with slick medium palate.  Covers alcohol well - slight background warmth.  Very nice.

Its been a while since I had a beer from the Dark Beer Specialist. Ive been a fan of Baltic Porter since first my first Baltika 6.  North Carolina is a long way from Saint Petersburg.  Their version of Baltic Porter is a dark brown pour, full bodied with a definite chocolate and roasted malt flavor.  Enjoyable and very pleasing.  I am happy to have tried a Baltic Porter straight outta Farmville.
Aroma of chocolate and dark fruit.  Pours black with very little head.  Taste is Sharp and sweet with roast nuts, chocolate and hazelnut coffee.  Decent porter.

Awesome beer. Pours opaque and aroma of mostly chocolate malt.  Soft and velvety tastes like chocolate and balanced with equal coffee and raisin like fruitness. Slight hop bitterness up front but then it just gets sexy in your mouth.  really well balanced awesome porter. Duck Rabbits best i think.
Nothing too remarkable, but it was totally drinkable for sure.
bottle i got at hawthornes, a great place, and enjoyed at pumpkin, another great place. barnyard, frothy, sticky, brown, salty, spruce, light, nuts, white, cheese, chocolate

Thanks to GT2! Smells of strong alcohol and raisins, even plum or blackcurrant or something a little fruity. Theres also a heavy smoky aroma wafting out of the black dregs. Pours jet black, amber on the edges with little head. Taste has lots of black, roast and smoke malt with a heavy mix of alcohol. Heavy on the palate. Follow through is a hint of bitter and hint of sweet that hangs around the back of your throat like syrup. Amazing beer. 330ml bottle.

Bottle. Black with lighter ring and deep tan big bubble head that dissipates immediately leaving only a lot of legs. The aroma is fairly clean with mostly lactic dark roast malt and very good quality espresso acidic notes.  The flavor is lactic tart rich sugar dark chocolate malty and finishes bitter. The mouth feel is impressively lively with big prickly bubbles and a sticky but quickly clean almost astringent character. It lasts and lasts, alcohol in particular.  After drinking a bunch of the local lesser known offerings in Charlotte I have to say duck rabbit and this beer are easily the most impressive.  Marvelous beer.

Originally reviewed: 11/24/09. Bottle poured into my pint glass. Pours a very thick deep endless black. Theres a thin tan head on top at the pour, but this disappears quickly. No lace whatsoever. Scents of alcohol, roasted malts, nuts, molasses, and warm syrup. 

The mouth is very creamy. Nice thick, slightly chewy body. Alcohol presence makes itself know right away in the flavor. Slight astringent zip there, but this dissipates. Flavors of syrupy pancakes, pumpernickel bread, dark chocolate, and even a touch of cold coffee in there. This has been one of the more elusive DR offerings for me, as I see to keep missing its release. Not this year. This is really good. Definitely one of their best beers. Recommend.

This beer is quite good.  The aroma is a sweet vanilla? malty mixture.  For such a big beer is has a surprisingly light body (not to say the body is light).  The flavor is big and malty, hints of roast, coffee and maybe some molasses syrup? Just ever so slightly...  Maybe a little bit of wood as well.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2016 opaque black with a bubbly tan head. great soft velvet full body with medium-full carbonation.

aroma: some astringent minerality, dark malts, herbal hops, diacetyl, and intense carob and chocolate.

taste: rich soft chocolate, cherry forward fruity complexity, metallic sour minerality, and herbal hops.

Very good beer. Pours very dark with a tin tan head that stays around. Aroma of mostly chocolate and malts. Soft medium body. Taste of some malt, chocolate, some coffee and a little fruit. The taste of malt and chocolate are balanced with the slight coffee and the slight dark fruitiness. The first taste of malts and slight hop bitterness are perfectly balanced with a sweet chocolate taste to make a perfectly balanced porter.

Pizzeria Paradiso, Alexandria tap ($6): I dont feel like writing a review, but here it is: Roasted malts. Alcohol. Awesomeness. Would I know this is a Baltic Porter based on the European examples I have sampled? No, not really. This tastes nothing like some amazing Baltic Porters Ive had. Is this good? Yes. Yes, it is.

Pours mahogany-tinged black into a shaker. Tan micro head with excellent retention recedes to skim surface. Medium bodies with dark chocolate and alcohol soaked pit fruit upfront. Lasting sweet milk chocolate and resin finish.

Bottled. Pours almoust pitch black and with a 1 fingers high tan head with fair lacing Nose of roasted malts, chocolate plums, raisins and smoked notes. Sweet flavor with chocolate, dark fruits and again smoked notes + some alcohol too. Medium to full bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. End up dry with malt bitterness an alcohol notes. An excellent brew.

Subtle aroma but a beautiful pour appearance with strong but comfortable alcohol tones and a warming mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a keg to a tulip glass. Pours  a nice dark black with a small light tan head.  A great aroma of roasted malt with a touch of alcohol. Has a medium body taste and the alcohol is definitely there. Tastes of roasted malt,  dark chocolate however i could not pick out the cherry.  Overall a great beer.

Poured into a tulip glass. Pitch black with almost no head.

Smells like Im holding the grains in my hand. Burnt and roasted malt blended perfectly.

Big and bold flavors. Lots of burnt malt, nicely balanced by roasted malt and a sweet note of chocolate.

Crisp but smooth and creamy. Medium body. A joy to drink.

Dark and deep with a great balanced flavor and an amazing smell. Great job!
Pours an opaque brown, smell is of roasty malt. taste is of coffee and is tart. not sure where that tartness is coming from.  doubting the quality of this bottle.

12oz bottle, received in trade from ASUBeer. Thanks! Pours a jet black color with a tan head. Aroma is roasty, dark fruits, cherry, plum. A little heavy on the palate with smooth carbonation. Flavor is sweet, roasty, malty, bitter chocolate, more cherry, raisin, a little alcohol, with a bitter, roasty finish. Very interesting.  Curious to see how it ages.

Pours a dark brown/black with lighter frothy brown head. aroma is very strong dark roasted malt notes with some nuttiness. The alcohol notes definitely seep through on this one and provide a warming feel to this beer. The flavor is more of the dark malts along with some dark chocolate notes and a bit of cherry. There is a slight tartness to this beer that finishes with some nice malty nut character to it. This is one of the best porters I have had so far.
Pours a deep brown, tan head. Aromas of malt and coffee, roasty nose. Smooth moutfeel, with flavors of toffee, coffee, roasted malts and dark fruit. Nice porter.

Thick and black in color with thick tan lacing and head. Great aroma of both coffee and toffee on the nose that present themselves on a medium full aspect. The palate is fairly large and lends itself more towards a stout than a porter, however, every beer is entitled to its place. Definitely a beer to drink in colder weather as well as a beer to enjoy through simply sipping or as a dessert.
Pours a deep dark brown with a large fluffy brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, dark fruit, and sugar. Flavor of roasted malts, dark fruit, and chocolate. Alcohol is very well hidden. Very good.

Big thanks to GAManiac.  Deep brown, almost black with yellow-tan head erupting from the surface.  Aroma is big dark fruits, faint roasted malt, brown sugar, and a wisp of smoke.  Flavor starts dark fruit, molasses and morphs into chocolate, cocoa powder, roasted malt/coffee melting across the tongue.  Lingers on.  Nice full feeling on the palate.

Draft From beerlicious iphone app:  Licorice aroma, Black in color with a minimal brown head.  Light bitterness to start, finishes with same but a light sweetness as well.  Medium creamy dry body. Average Carbonation with a bitter finish

2009 Bottle.  Pours the same as most dark beers.......dark.  Small brown head that hangs around a bit.  Nose is briney, salt water, licorice and sour milk.  Also some wood, nuts and horseblanket.  Complex to say the least .  Flavor is bittersweet, with the sweet winning out in the front but giving way to the bitter for a strong finish.  Mouthfeel is smooth, creamy and long lasting.

Bottle. Pours black thin brown head. Strong roasted malt aroma. Caramel and dark chocolate. Taste is mild sweet. Full body, high carbonation, tingly roasty finish. Can definitely find the high alcohol in the finish. This beer will put hair on your chest.

Black pour dark cherry hue thin off white beige head thin ring...... Aroma of licorice, dark fruits, roasted malts, vanilla and chocolate ..... Taste is roasted, chocolatey, vanilla, dark fruits, light licorice with a nice oily and thick balanced mouthfeel ... Finish is roasted, chocolatey and lightly bitter .... Outstanding stuff

12oz bottle from JCB, thanks Jason! Pours a very deep and dark brown, mostly black colored body with a thin, fizzy, dark brown head that dissipates quickly and leaves a light lacing. Aroma is fairly malty sweet with lots of plum and raisin dark fruits, molasses, dark and milky chocolate, a light cherry, and a moderate roast. Some slightly smoky leather, a touch of licorice, and a light vanilla. Flavor is similar. Somewhat cloyingly sweet initially with lots of figgy, raisin, plummy dark fruits. Plenty of molasses, milk chocolates, and dark chocolates with a moderate roast that increases nicely towards the end. A touch of licorice, some leathery smoke, plenty of raisin dark fruits, sweet malts, and the increased roasts as this finishes pretty sweet and malty, but the roasts cut the sweetness nicely and dont keep this cloying like it seems up front. A touch of acidity with the dryness with some vanilla creeping in and just the slightest hint of alcohol warmth. Lengthy aftertaste following a full, slightly syrupy body and a light carbonation. Overall, a really complex baltic porter. Lots of dark fruits, chocolates, molasses, roasts, and a nice acidity. A bit too syrupy to put this over the edge for me, but it stayed well balanced and I liked it nonetheless. Nice beer.

12oz bottle poured almost black with mocha colored head that lasted for a little while. the aroma of roasted malt and cocoa and subtle hints of coffee. the flavor was very good the alcohol is masked very well. the flavor of chocolate and coffee are very well blended with the roasted malts. very good baltic porter.

Opaque, tan head that shrinks to a thin rim. Smells sweet and dark chocolatey. Coffee, chocolate, malt, delicious. A little smoky. This is perhaps the best smoked Baltic porter Ive had. A wonderfully rich, creamy beer.
On tap at Tyler in Carrboro,  NC. Pours with a nice reddish hue. Slightly sweet.  A bit weak on the finish. Overall a fantastic porter.

Bottle, courtesy GT2, thanks buddy! Pour is black with a small tan head, little retention/no lace. Aroma of raisins, roast, coffee, dark fruit. Taste is roasty, raisin heavy, cofee, fig, slightly sour. Palate is slick, average carbonation, roasty finish.

Black pour with small tan head. Little bit of lacing. Smoky (alder?) aroma with hints of chocolate, coffee and alcohol. Sweet toffee taste with vanilla notes, and an acrid chemical bite. Very tart from that. Might be the astringency from too many roasted grains, but I dont know. Could be a much better beer without that very tart bitterness.

Bottle from Capones. Pours black with tan head that lingers around the side of the glass. Nose is smoke, dried fruit and tobacco. First sip is roasted malt with milk chocolate and chicory. Nice mouth feel. Finish is sweet. Best Baltic porter ever.

Denmark, Aug-Sept 2009. Another great bottle from fonefan. Pours an oily pitch black with a very small dark brown head. Lovely intense  aroma of roasted malt, coffee and dark chocolate. Sweet roasted malty taste, licorice, chocolate, vanilla. Very nice

Bottle from Beverage World in Fort Oglethorpe, cellar aged for over a year to see if the "balticness" would smooth out a little. Pours very, very dark brown with a chocolate milk head. Aroma has a lot of caramel, molasses, some soy, some chocolate and some smokiness. Taste brings caramel, molasses, some smokey meat flavor, some salt. Quite smooth. Not too alcoholly for sitting. Finishes with sweetness, some bitterness, somewhat thick. Not nearly as rough as my memory of the intial tasting of it was.

Bottle shared by mtjoseph.  Deep, dark brown color that borders on inky black.  No real head when I poured this, but there was some spotty cinnamon colored bubbles appearing on the surface.  Rich dark chocolate, burnt sugar, and some smokiness in the background.  Fairly sweet smelling.  Interesting and complex palate for this beer.  Sweet and acidic with neither being too overpowering.  Chocolate, toffee, with some dried cherries coming in mid palate.  The cherries give this a slight acidity.  Finishes with a nice dose of chocolate and some lingering acidity.  Really interesting, but Im not sure if it completely works for me.  Still really quite good.

Bottle per thome50 leaving it at our house.  Pours thick, jet black, with a frothy brown colored, espresso-esc head.  Big, sweet aroma of just a ton of chocolate, sugar, roasted malt, and some smoke masked behind everything.  For a baltic porter, this is quite full bodied.  Some sweet chocolate, little bit of boozy heat, some dark fruit skin (Cherry?) and just a tad of smoke.  Some real sharp acidity with this too, which seems strange for the style.
