Sticky upfront in the mouthfeel, then the acidity cuts right through it.  I dig. Thanks for leaving this bonus at our house Justin.
Excellent. Sweet roasted malt nose. Great balance. Dried fruit, coffee, toasted malt.

Malzig-herber, in Teilen schokoladiger Antrunk. Das Malz wird im Mittelteil eher nussig, Geringe herbe, das Malz wird dabei ein wenig breiter. Trotz des Alkohols süffig, ein wenig hopfig. Dabei bleibt das Malz hinter seinen Möglichkeiten zurück, außerdem ist das Bier recht trocken, vor allem im Abgang. Minimal alkoholisch im Nachgeschmack, sonst herb-schokoladig. Nett! 8/11/10/11/9/11
Non il mio stile di birra che preferisco, questa birra ha un eccesso di amaro e liquirizia fastidiosissimo.

Pours black with a light brown head that took a few seconds to develop. Little lacing. The aroma has a lot of cocoa and chocolate syrup, some roast and dark fruits, a bit of cola and a touch of smoke. The beer really opened up as it warmed. The beer tastes medium sweet, maybe a bit above that. Theres a lot of chocolatey cola flavor and more dark malt fruitiness. The finish has a mild herbal note and a bit more smoke. It started out a bit thin, but the warmth helped fill things out. Its a little sticky but not too bad. This is a good Baltic Porter, but I was expecting a bit more. Its just a little sweet and heavy on the chocolate syrupy flavor. I still like it, but its not a world beater.
12 ounce bottle pours pitch black with moderate carbonation.  Aromas of raisins, caramel, dark fruit, and choclate.  Tastes of raisiins and figs hit the palate with a nice malty coffee finish.

Best by 9/13.
Ar: Raisins and burnt caramel, with some wood, cherry, molassas and chocolate.
Ap: Black pour, opaque, medium light brown head with good retention.
T: Up front some alcohol heat with flavor of dark rum and sherry. Really bold raisin and fig flavor with a touch of coffee and chocolate. Lingering rum, cherry and cocoa finish with warm alcohol.
P: Medium-full body with medium-high carbonation - richness of body is cut by carbonation and finishes dry (just a touch too dry, but splitting hairs)
O: A delicious baltic porter - deep dark fruits with warming alcohol and plentiful maltiness make this a true winter fireside beer - the fruitiness really underscores the rich maltiness of this beer, and the roast is a nice complement that does not go so far as to turn this into an imperial porter/stout-type beer.

Bottle @ home. Deep black appearance with almost no head. Roasty, slightly burnt tar, somewhat boozy, dark malty nose. Dark fruits, roasty, burnt rubber, light anise, deep malty flavor. Roasty, chocolatey, taraftertaste. Boozy, asphalt flavor has me wondering about the hype around this beer.

Bottle thanks to fletchfighters. Have wanted to try this one for a while. Pours black with smallish tan coloured head. Big aromas of dark fruits, spice, treacle and a hint of alcohol. Very full aromas. Really good. Tastes is probably not quite as good. Very sweet with plenty of alcohol on the finish. Medium to full mouthfeel. Good stuff.

Another bottle shared by Matt last night. Thanks! Beer is black and forms a decent head of small brown bubbles that leaves some lacing on the glass. Carbonation is OK.

Beers aroma is slightly sweet but has a definite smokiness to it. Nice.

Beer is medium bodied and mildly smokey. Forward a little sweet and the back is bitter with grains and roast. The smoke character is minimal but its really good. I enjoyed this beer a lot. Drinkability high.

Serving type: bottle

Poured from a 12 oz bottle.  Aroma is dried fruit, maybe prunes/figs, some molasses and chocolate.  Taste follows the nose but with just a hint of soy sauce and some smokey flavor in there too.  A very nice brew.

From bottle. Great rich malty aroma, chocolate and licorice, molasses and coffee, oak and vanilla. Light winy acidity and a bit of carbonic gaseousness and mild hop notes. Dark black opaque with thin cocoa-brown lacing head. Medium heavy body, just shy of oily, with alcoholic warming and medium carbonation. Starts sweet with soy sauce and mild acidity. Molasses, chocolate, vanilla and oak, licorice and lots of sweetness. Not cloying, and actually finishes quite tart and bright. A very nice porter, fairly complex with nice taste profile. Smooth sweet after.

Thanks to forgetfu for sending me this bottle. This is one I have been wanting to try for a while. 

The beer pours a black color with a tan head. The aroma is chocolate, roasted malt, dark fruit and some charred notes. The flavor is roasted and charred malt, with some chocolate, coffee and alcohol. The beer is fairly boozy, but very enjoyable.

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
Black as night, doppelbockish on the nose- very sweet.  Head that runs away.  Thick, chewy beer in a good way- very lively and full.  Wonderful beer

Reviewed from notes.

Poured into a tulip glass. The pour brings a dark brown body with a tan head. Nose is pretty complex with some dark fruits, roasted malt, chocolate, and a tad bit of booze. The taste is dark fruits and brown sugar as well as a bit of chocolate and roast. Good feel with a tad bit of booze. Good beer all around and a solid offering from them.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-10-2010

(12oz bottle courtesy of ewright!!).  Pours near black-only some red hue is noticeable when held up to the light-with minimal khaki head.  Aroma has dark chocolate, some cherry or strawberry and some light coffee.  Taste has some roasty bitterness, but it is beautifully balanced by a sweet malt backbone.   The bitter and sweet go back and forth on this beer.  Medium bodied with an oily texture.  Finish is a bit dry.  What a great beer.  It doesnt drink like 9%abv either.

pours a pretty jet black with a thick tan head. lots of lacing. aroma is boozy caramel, raisins, dark fruit, cinnamon, and spice. i like the spice at the back end. taste is just a bit of a letdown from the aroma, heavy caramel, spices, raisins, and sweet malts. heavy mouthfeel, pretty drinkable for this abv though. overall a pretty good beer for this style. im a fan.

12 oz. bottle. (Multiple times)  I cant believe I havent rated this yet.  Pours dark brown almost black with a medium sized beige head.  The aroma has dark sweeter malts, dark fruits, soy, molasses with a hint of coffee.  The flavor matches the nose without any disappointment.  Big dark malts, molasses, soy, coffee, chocolate.  Medium plus body, somewhat syrupy.  This is one of my favorite porters out there.  I need more this year.

Poured the bottle into a snifter.  It had a mark on the 10 hash so i am guessing this is a little old.  At first this had a very sour nose and i almost that it was infected.  I let this warm up a little and man am i glad i did.  The aroma is that of dark chocolate, molasses, and cherry/berry and totasted malt.  The appearance was a med brown mostly diminishing head.  There was almost no lacing.  It is dark brown in color of course.  The taste is very unique.  I get notes of dark chocolate, cola, molasses, and a little vinous qualities to it.  It has almost a syrupy mouthfeel with soft carbonation.  It has a slight roasty bitterness to it.  Overall it is not a bad beer once it warms up.  I am not sure if the sourness is normal or not and would love to try this again fresh.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2011 The beer pours a very dark black, hardly shows any brown in the light. The head is avery dark brown, but only rises about a finger if that, and is gone quickly. While the head is there, for about 30 seconds, it is nice and creamy.
The lacing is very light. 

The aroma is too light, wish it was more pungent. All that comes through is some smokey coffee, maybe a tiny bit of pork. 

The taste shows off lots of malts on the front, kind of surprising after the aroma. There is chocolate and coffee on the front, and as it fades there is some bitter smoke. Its a unique taste, a lot more smokey than most baltic portes Ive had.

The feel is medium, decent drinkability for 9%.

Overall, this beer is pretty good, but not a baltic porter to me, more like a smoked porter.

Date: 1/19/2010   Source:Capital Ale House - Downtown   Lots of roast and chocolate in aroma. Black with small tan head. Big roast and chocolate profile in flavor with moderate grainy astringency. Light woody sourness. Medium to full body. Finish is medium, moderately bitter with hint of sourness. Very tasty.

12 oz brown bottle.

It pours a dense, dark brown bordering on black. The head is big and multi colored tan. It looks very nice.

The smell is fruity, sweet, and roasty, very typical of the style.

The flavor is perhaps a bit too sweet, even for the style, though its taste is more or less spot on. Big roasty notes accent the dark fruit flavors and the heavy sweetness. There is a slight tartness that could be a bit more subdued.

A sweet example of the style, but a decent one.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-23-2010 02:10:52
Poured from a 12.  Porter Black with a good head.  Nose is roasty malt and a little metalic.  Taste is chocolate malty goodness.  Very smooth on the palate and a great finish

12 oz bottle from PA. Pours a deep black color with subtle roasted notes complemented with an apparent licorice aroma. Medium body with a really smooth and velvety slick mouth feel. Great roasted notes are balanced with slight chocolate, licorice notes. Extremely drinkable especially for the 9% ABV. You can in no means pick up on the alcohol in this beer. Beer careful and enjoy, this is an awesome brew! Overall: (A)
Bottle pours black with a small brown head. Scent is roasted and dark chocolate with a whiff of smoke. Taste is chocolate, wood and roasty.

I dont know too many Baltic Porters, but i would say that this was exemplary of the style. Dark pour with a thin read head and an aroma of alcohol. Taste was smooth with a alcoholic finish in the end.

Bottle via Illini08.  Thank you mucho.  Pours dark and oily looking sporting a deep brown head of suds.  Nose was very smokey and sensual with superb dried fruit notes woven into the smokiness.  Flavors bring back some of the smoke yet not as much as the nose let on..the fruit notes arent really there much though I do get some berry flavors..the body is about medium..I was hoping for a little more ooomph here as it seems theres something missing...though Im not exactly sure what it is. The roasty/smokey notes are nice, but maybe a bit more aggressive hopping or a touch more sweetness would bring out the flavors more...maybe its too cold.   It is balanced though and focused and coherent and the alcohol is completely hidden all pro-like...but that being said, at the current moment, the flavors just arent popping out like I want them to.  Well see...Ill be back when it warms.  Ok, im back...after giving my son a bath and reading a few bed time stories, the beer has warmed to around room temp.  Flavors are a little more pronounced...some chocolate has entered the picture..maybe a hint of the dried fruit noticed in the nose..theres a somewhat metallic/tinniness going on, but not really all that distracting.  The roast is a little more pronounced as well...and a milky lactic touch in the finish.  So, definitely opens up a bit as it warms.  Pretty decent baltic porter and very deceptive when it comes to the alcohol level...but the flavors didnt blow my mind like I wanted them to.

A: The pour is almost black with a modestly sized tan/off-white head.

S: This is going to sound strange, but this beer smells strongly of powdered cheddar cheese (like on Cheese Chex Mix). Theres also licorice, roasted malt, roast, and ash. Definitely a dark fruit aroma, too, like prunes.

T: Lots and lots of licorice and prune juice. Its overly sweet and sugary at points. I pick up some metal, and there are also fruit skins and quite a bit of roast and ash, which at least help to mitigate the sweetness.

M: The body is medium with a low to medium level of carbonation.

D: Not an enjoyable drinking experience here. Some really weird and off flavors.

Poured into a mug.

4.0 A: Black color. One finger of thick creamy light brown head. Average retention and not really any lacing.

4.0 S: Oh boy is this nice. Lots of roasty and burnt aromas in this. Big chunk of roasted barley, smoke, bittersweet chocolate, and molasses. Touch of raisin and prune fruitiness.

4.5 T: The first thing I notice is a tangy boozy sweetness, almost like lactose. Behind that there is again a good roasty toastiness, smoke, chocolate, and molasses. Some tobacco notes as well to complement raisin and plum fruitiness. Big bold flavors without being overdone.

4.5 M: Medium to heavier medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Very good creaminess and pretty smooth despite the tanginess.

4.5 D: DRs RIS disappointed me in how harsh it was. This could very well be an RIS and I enjoyed this one a hell of a lot more. Really good flavor profile and mouthfeel make this one good enough to come back to again and again. I wish I had another one.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-01-2010 04:45:25

Bottle courtesy of bin2, thanks Ryan.  Aroma is roasted malts, coffee, and some dark sugar.  Pours black with a 1" dark tan head which isnt well retained, leaves spotty lacing.  Really nice flavor; roast malts, coffee, caramel, and molasses up front.  Roast and hop bitterness finish up the taste, with a lingering (but pleasant) coffee flavor.  Medium-heavy body, goes down silky and creamy.  Excellent porter.

Bottle shared by MrPickles...thanks Andy! - Pours dark as hell with a thin brown head. Smell is tons of molasses, but with sweet brown sugar, soy sauce, honey, a touch of roast, and a bit of heat. Nose is maybe a little too sweet, but its flavorful. Taste is a lot of the same. The honey is dialed up more, and its more roasty--especially on the finish--but molasses rules the day. Overall, its just a little too sweet for my tastes, but its enjoyable in small quantities. Slick and smooth, without a ton of carbonation. Nice, but I couldnt drink a lot of this.

Bottle.  Pours a deep dark black with crimson highlights and a medium sized deeply tanned head.  Sweet roast, chocolate, cool stone fruit on the nose.  Rich and velvety, lots of smooth roast flavor coming through over the lightly sweet cherry and plum flavors.  Slow warm finish with bread pudding and caramel on the finish.  Very nice.

Bottle. 12 oz. Pours pitch motor oil black with a thin, creamy beige head. Aroma of chocolate, bittersweet cocoa, espresso beans, roasted malt, sugary cream, and toffee. Slight vinegar notes. Full, yet rounded and supple, bodied with an oddly tart, slightly smoky palate. Finishes with bittersweet cocoa notes. Excellent Baltic porter.

Review from notes sampled 12/14/2007
12oz bottle received in a trade with limesmut. Thanks again

Poured a dark brown/black with a tan/brown head that disappeared gradually. Smell is roasty, figgy malts, and a bit of alcohol. Taste is roasty malt with a lactose type sweetness mixed in there. Thick mouthfeel that coats the taste buds after each sip. Respectable brew from Duck Rabbit, I wish I could get their stuff locally.

Received in trade from KarrHeel03 and Revisited 12/13/2009

Pours a solid black with a good sized tan head that dissipates quickly to a ring on top and minimal lacing. Smells of dark chocolate and roasted coffee up front, touch of hops and alcohol hidden underneath. Taste is rich with chocolate and dark fruits. I imagine sour cherries and black currant as I sip this one. It proves to be quite sweet but the burn of alcohol in the finish mixed with a distant hop bitterness keeps it from being cloying. Creamy almost syrupy mouthfeel, thick body, light carbonation. I think I enjoyed this a lot more this time around. I have another bottle that I think will age for a while and revisit in a few years. My score reflects this most recent tasting.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2011 12oz bottle shared with the tallahassee crew, pours dark with little lacing, aroma is sweet, a little roasty malty, this is quite good and drintable at 9%. Great stuff from Duck Rabbit, now if only those wraskly rabbits would come to Florida.....
Thoroughly enjoy this dark, smoky but clean porter.  Notes of cocoa, maybe a little coffee? with some other interesting malts. I very much enjoyed it.

Black with a deep tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, rich dark fruits, some coffee, chocolate, and light molasses.  Flavor is full of roasted malts, light chocolate, light coffee, molasses, dark fruit, and a faint smoke note.  FInishes with an ample amount of bitterness.  Would love to have a few rounds of this one.
Black colored brew with a nice brown head. Dark fruits and tangerine in the aroma. Flavor has tangerine, some mocca and coffee and some soy and saltyness. Smooth texture. Ok.

Bottled. The aroma has dark fruits, tangerine, some roast, some coffee. Black coloured beer, with a good creamy, beige head. The taste is a bit bitter and sweet. There is dark fruits, tangerine, coffee, roast and soy sauce. Quite fruity for a baltic porter. Medium-full bodied. Smooth mouthfeel. Nice.

Just about opaque black pour with a thin, quickly dissipating head. Aroma is lots of coffee, bittersweet chocolate, caramel, and bitter dark roasted malts. Definitely some boozy notes in there as well. Flavor has an odd sort of tanginess from the flavors melding together. The dark malts, coffee, and booze combine with a pretty strong touch of dark fruits to create a very unique flavor. Im not really sure if I like it or not. Palate is par for the style, rich and full bodied. Its certainly different than most other Baltic Porters, but I dont know that different is better in this case. Im a little disappointed in this one, to be honest. Not really the flavor I was expecting, and entirely too boozy for 9% ABV.

Bottle from Adam: pours a deep, opaque burgundy with a thin brown head. Roasted, toasted malts,  coffee,sweet dark chocolate, esters, toffee. Really rich malts and thicker mouthfeel. Perfect balance. Alcohol is masked quite well making this extremely drinkable. Outstanding first experience with this brewery

Black pour with a small dark brown head.  Left almost no lace, head faded in quick fashion to nothing.  Aroma was rich milk chocolate, almost melted candy bar like, a light roast character was thrown throughout.  Flavors were big and rich, cocoa, light coffee ground and a light char presence.  All mixed together for a world class porter.  Carbonation was medium to soft leaving a silky smooth mouthfeel.  Viscous.  Excellent stuff.  Will buy another 6 to stow.

12 oz bottle from GAManiac. Pours thick and black with a small mocha head. Big aroma of roasted malt, vanilla, alcohol, coffee oak and caramel. The flavor is lots of rich bitter sweet chocolaty roasted malt, slightly acidic coffee and some alcohol warming. Medium to full body with mild carbonation and a slightly thin, oily mouth feel. I got very excited for this when I smelled it, but a bit disappointed with the flavor and mouth feel. Still a great beer, lots of rich malty flavors and very smooth.

2010 Bottle.  Pours black with a large, frothy, tan head.    Nose of dark fruits, roasted malts, cocoa, heavy cream.  Medium slightly creamy body, with notes of molasses, roasted malt, dark fruits, light metal.   Could use a little more body and the alcohol shows a little in the finish.  A great after dinner sipper.

Pours black with dark brown head.  Aroma has a little alcohol, a nice roasted malt flavor with a little alcohol heat and bitterness at the end.  Medium mouth feel, maybe a little slick at the end.  This beer is good!

I poured this 12 oz bottle into a snifter. This is a sledgehammer of a beer, thick, viscous, and so dark that I swear the lights dimmed in the kitchen when I opened it. It raised a surprising 2 finger head the color of chocolate mousse, though that quickly dissipated to lacing (and may simply have resulted form the secondary fermentation in this 2009 bottling). This beer raises aromas of chicory, licorice, fennel, and anise, and complements those flavors with roasted chestnuts and a powerful, up front sweetness not unlike sweetened condensed milk. Overall, then, this is a lot like Vietnamese coffee, with competing abundances of bitter/roast flavors and sweetness. Its not my thing, but even I can recognize that it is a fine example of the style.

Bottle poured a clear dark brown nearly black with a small lingering brown head. Aromas of licorice, bitter chocolate, light coffee, light carmel and alcohol. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry warming finish. Flavors of licorice, bitter chocolate, light coffee and alcohol with a smooth dry warming lingering licorice finish.

This was a little too much of one flavor for me. Mostly an alcoholic sweet raisin taste. A very subtle roasted nut flavor is dominated by the sweetness of the beer. Sweet throughout and in the finish. Lingering alcohol taste. Very thick and oily.

Bottle poured into a snifter.  Dark black with thin tan ring of foam, and a purple tinge when held up to the light.  Aroma is fantastic, molasses, caramel, roasted malt, and fruit (raisins, cherries, plums).  Taste is a bit of a let-down based on the aroma.  Taste is bitter and a bit like soy sauce, with a bit of cloying sweetness at the end.  Mouthfeel is oily smooth with medium carbonation.  Smells better than it tastes, was a bit disappointed, but the aroma is worth the price of admission.

bottle. pours black and heavy with tan head.  nose is sour apple and slight chocolate.  taste is bitter soy sauce with a crisp apple finish.  this is without a doubt the best baltic porter ive ever had.  if sold around here, i would buy this.  nice beer for MN fall and winter.

Bottle. Poured into my CCB tulip glass a dark brown color with what starts as a 1/4 inch dark tan head that quickly settles to form a tan collar around the glass. The first aroma I smell is that of roasty coffee mixed with milky chocolate, slight tobacco, but overall a very mellow smell. Swirling to get a better smell creates some nice lace around the glass. The alcohol is pretty apparent in teh first sip I take but also dark fruits, roast, coffee, chocolate, and a touch of leather. Medium/heavy mouthfeel and pretty creamy. Slightly dry finish. Nice sipper.

Bottle the my friend Rich. Pours black with a thin layer of brown foam. nose is rich chocolate, coffee like roast malts, dried ripe fruits, and sweet malt. Taste is sweet malts, roast, coffee, chocolate covered cherries, and almost a tartness but still sweet. Bitter and oily mouthfeel. intense dark brew. good.

Bottle courtesy Josh (thanks!).  Sweet, dark malt and molasses on the aroma.  Raisin as well.  As the beer warms a roasted, slightly smokey aroma comes out of the malt.  Taste is dark and luscious malt with molasses.  Very subtle roasted character in the flavor.  Sweet alcohol/raisin notes toward the finish.   Thick and velvety in the mouth.
Slightly charred oak and bark Cola brown, thin tan head, some lace. Bark, molasses, and raisin flavor. Full body, blood consistency, somewhat fizzy. A little overrated, but good.

Bottle from Vintage Cellar.  Very dark brown pour that looks all black in the glass.  A thin tan head develops and sticks around on top.  Creamy aroma with milk chocolate, lighty roasty notes, and molasses.  Pretty tasty beer here.  Awfully smooth and easy drinking with a slick coating settling on the palate.  A lot of sweet dark fruit flavors that I didnt pick much up of in the aroma.  Molasses, chocolate, caramel and toasted nuts and grains round out the flavors but the dark fruit is what sticks with me.  No complaints from me this is solid stuff.

Pours dark brown with nice tan head that dissipates quickly leaving a thin lace. Nose of malt, dark chocolate, vanilla, and coffee. Flavors of espresso, smoke, plum, light hops and toffee. Other than a thin mouthfeel, this is a very well balanced brew. Medium finish. A top 5 porter in my book. Cheers.

Bottle with many thanks to Pollack. Pours black with reddish brown head. Nose of roasted malts, chocolate, vanilla coffee and bourbon. Taste is initially sweet chocolate, vanilla and coffee with little bourbon kick and velvet mouth feel. Excellent.

From a 12 oz into a pint glass.  Pours a dark black but slightly opaquey as many lagers are.  Lots of head but little lacing; a few errant bubbles frozen on the glass.  Aroma is sweet like a Starbucks (more like a Thai) iced coffee, with a lot of sugar.  Mouthfeel is very good; clean yet sticky.  Taste is full of coffee and roast.  Plenty of alcohol flavor and syrup to go along with it.  Very good beer but a bit too sweet and sticky for me.  I think of a baltic porter as a bit lighter with less alcohol and it shouldnt leave my mouth like I just ate pancakes at the Waffle House.  Other than the alcohol and stickyness it really has some great flavor though.

The pours is deep and dark, similar to any good imperial stout, with a thin medium chocolate brown head. The aroma has just a bit of crisp sweetness and the slightest touch of booze. The flavor, however, is richly sweet, with flavors of bittersweet chocolate and molasses, and an underlying bitterness akin to a lightly roasted coffee. The mouthfeel is silky smooth. If it were any sweeter, it would almost seem syrupy with how little carbonation it has, but the smoothness works with the flavor to create a rich, decadent, but smooth drinking experience.

Pours black with a thick, but small head.  Aroma smells delicious of nicely toasted malt, hops and some anise.  Taste is pretty full bodied and complex with chocolate malt and coffee very well balanced by hops.  Very nicely done porter.

12 oz bottle acquired via trade. This was a lovely beer, opaque brown with hints of ruddy red and a pretty tan head. Big whiff of dark fruits, toffee, some roast and a little bit of booze. Initial flavor is of roast and chocolate, fades into some plum and vinous notes, minimal booze. Nice thick mouthfeel, moderate carbonation. This beer really makes me want to go visit my grandparents so I can sample more of what North Carolina has to offer in the beer realm.
Not much to say.  Beautiful roasty flavor with a velvet feel and a burnt toast finish.  Nice biting start, but the aroma is slightly deceitful with a sweet nose.

banana, bubblegum, butterscotch, clove, cooked vegetables, cough drop, ginger, licorice, raisin, rotten eggs, soy sauce, skunky, smoke, vanilla, woody  AROMA

 TASTE
 PALATE

Your overall score quantifies how much you enjoyed all the beers elements combined as a sensory experience. Was this a standout beer? Were your expectations met? Did the beer go well with your food? Would you recommend this to a friend? This isnt about how well the beer conformed to its style definition -- its about a measurement of your own appreciation.

Jet black pour from bottle obtained in trade from SpencerDB (many thanks Spence!!).  I agree with previous; the smell is so very unique, a perfect blend of beef jerky, chocolate and alcohol.  Taste is bitter chocolate and alcohol, with a warm finish.  Very unique and very excellent!!
Bottle. Black. Beautiful balance of malt and alcohol. Delicous sourish dark malt flavour.

TOP 100 TICK HELL YES!  Just kidding, I dont care that much.  12oz bottle.  Pours black in color with a one-finger tan head that fades to a ring. The aroma is pretty nice: roasty, chocolatey, and earthy with anise and maybe even whiskey notes.  The flavor is dominated by coffeeish roasted malts along with dark chocolate and a slightly vinous component, dark cherry, and licorice.  Tasty stuff.  Slick and silky on the mouthfeel with fairly full body and low carbonation.  Really solid stuff overall.  One of the better Duck-Rabbit beers Ive ticked.

Pitch black color. Freshly roasted espresso beans and dark chocolate exude from the nose. The mouth is smoother than silk. Heavenly. Caramel and dark chocolate mingle amongst coffee notes. A bit on the sweet side. Not authentic at all, IMO, but brilliant nonetheless.

Bottle, pours black with a beige head.  Nose is sweet, some powdered chocolate, vanilla.  A bit thin in the mouth, of course chocolate, some mild coffee, and a thoroughly unpleasant sour component that clashes horribly with the bitter coffee and light malt.  I do not get this style.
Bottle, $2.35 from Wine Warehouse, Charlottesville. Pours BLACK with a dark brown frothy head. Metallic coffee in the nose. Flavor is a slightly sweet rich chocolate. Tasty.

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with James. Pours pitch motor oil black with a thin, creamy beige head. Aroma of chocolate, bittersweet cocoa, espresso beans, roasted malt, sugary cream, and toffe. Slight vinegar notes. Full bodied with a tart, slightly smoky palate. Excellent Baltic porter.

12 oz Bottle split with Pat. Pours a pitch black body - ive never seen a porter this black - like thick coca cola syrup. Aroma is surprisingly very tart with small notes of vinegar. Mouthfeel is velvety smooth and complex. A burst of flavor - roasted sourness, wood, bread and slight vinegarette.

Pours a dark brown color with an off-white foam head.  Has an amazing aroma.  One of the best ever.  Roasty aroma with hints of dark fruit and caramel.  Sweet caramel start with gentle bitters in the middle.  Nice maltiness to it.  And the every so important velvety chocolate finish.  Recommended by Leafs93 and supplied by Damico.  What a beer.  Worthy of number one rating on RateBeer for Baltic Porters.  Cant wait for the next one.
The aroma is awesome, like beef jerky and BBQ with the roasted malts. The flavor of smoke, roasted malts, and soy sauce at the end. The color is dark, black chocolate.

12 oz. bottle thanks to beerman 6686 pours very dark brown almost black and  meduim to thick with a thick brown head aromas are of roasted malts coffee and chocolate with a hop back bone off setting and taming the massive malts taste is of the same smooth and creamy with lots of lacing I am sure glad to have gotten my hands on this cheers

Have had this only once, and its been a minute unfortunately as I remember this being incredibly bold, strong, and exceptional.  Big coffee flavors, remaining smooth.  Dark chocolate, dark cherry, all blended perfectly.  A slight hint of booze that melds well.  Goddamn!

Bottle:  Poured a black color with a nice head.  The aroma was roasted malts, dark fruits, and dark chocolate.  The flavor was somewhat fruity (rasins), roasted coffee and dark choclate.  Overall, an excellent Baltic Porter.
12oz bottle into 16oz shaker. Pours a dark brown with medium white head. Aroma is of roasted malts. Mouth feel is thin with excellent carbo. Flavor of dark malts with smooth crisp finish.

(12oz bottle via IP trade with BA wagenvolks) pours near black with medium tan head that fades quickly. Nose of rum raisins, vanilla, chocolate syrup, black olives, licorice, and lightly sour fruits become evident with swirling of the glass. Taste of semi sweet chocolate chips, fudge, raisins, dates and figs. Creamy soft carbonation, extremely flavorful palate duration, and lots of fudgey flavors that stick around. Medium thick body. An excellent Baltic!!

Pours deep brown, almost black, opaque, and topped with a light tan head which dissipates into spotty/swirly lacing from the 12oz. bottle courtesy of dkachur (thanks, Dan!): Solid nose of malts, roast, dark chocolate, black coffee, drying nutty hints, campfire smoke, molasses, and whole plums heavily soaked in a bucket of alcohol. Full-bodied and deep; vanilla bean and malty sweetness nothing close to cloying- offset by some mild, bittering pumpernickel toast. Funny, how the aroma emits plum notes, but the taste is of lighter fruits- starfruit and tangerine, maybe? Or more of black cherry flavors. Ashy throughout, a bit perfume-y tasting, and lightly carbonated. Drinkability: After dinner drink, an enjoyable sipper. Pairing: Smoked foods, chocolate cake, chocolate chip cookies. Rebuy: Would be nice to revisit. #448 on 13052010, DG.

Pitch black dark tan head good lacing, not very sustained, but easily remade...  roasty aroma w some dark fruits present some slight choc and coffee... roasty choc bitter coffee smooth, a fruity sweetness... warming, medium full body, not so much in the mouthfeel... outstanding....

Bottle from a trade with SuzyGreenberg. Pours very dark brown color with light brown head. Aromas of roasted malts, dark fruits, licorice and some smoke. Flavors of roasted malts, sweet dark fruits, molasses, licorice and some smokiness. Medium to full body with soft carbonaion and a velvety mouthfeel. Thanks Ben.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2012 I have come to this beer again and o what an experience. The other half of potbeercollege has blessed me with two more bottles. Boom this stuff is bomb. I dont get the fruits i claimed riginally but the rest is pretty on point. I mean this is a huge malt bomb with more complex flavors of t0asted and toffee flavors blowing up huge on top of touches of darker liquors and more. Drink this every day and "your very flesh shall become a great poem!" THE DARK BEER SPECIALIST BLOW IT UP HUGE AGAIN! Thank you Jack for setting me free once more!  I get way more 3 and Bottled. Been looking for this. (Thanks to the Eepiest). Black beer with very thin and disappearing orange tan head. Aroma is roasted coffee chocolate, rasberry sorbet dripple desert sauce stuff, and booze. All reminiscent of those booze ball chocolate candies (maybe rum balls, maybe Canadian Whiskey.) Flavor is electric semi-sweet and bitter delicately trailing off into a full roast trap capturing your attention and reaching back for more. Beer leaves a light oily but sticky candy sweet touch on lips and tongue and gums. Really a beer experience. Couldnt be much more pleased!

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2017 Sampled on draft at Smokin? Joe?s in Pittsburgh PA this beer poured a black color with a huge creamy brown head that lingered forever and produced great lacing. The aroma was sweet, malty and had notes of licorice, chocolate and light floral hops. The flavor was roasty and fairly bitter with elements of port wine, licorice, chocolate syrup, vanilla, malted milk, floral hops and coffee. The finish was long with floral hops, vanilla, licorice, coffee and cocoa lingering. Amazingly full bodied, creamy and smooth. Excellent.

12 oz. bottle via trade with JCB- thanks again, Jason!  Pours a super dark opaque brown with a creamy tan head that leaves some film on the beer and a ring around the inner edge.  Aroma of dark chocolate, dark fruits (especially plums, also red grapes and cherries), smoked wood, roasted caramel malts, molasses, and not much alcohol to speak of.  Flavor of roasted malts, dark chocolate, dark tart fruits (cherries, red grapes, and a lot of plums again), molasses, licorice, and a little campfire late.  Dry, roasty, kind of tart finish.  Medium-full bodied, with moderate carbonation and a slick, oily mouthfeel.  Wow, this kept getting better as I was drinking it.  Exceeded my already high expectations.  Best Baltic porter Ive ever had.

Bottle from footbalm.  Thanks eric!  Pours black with a small tan head.  WoW!  Aroma on this is awesome.  red wine, fruity, rich dark chocolate, plum booze.  PLUMS.  awesome.  Boatload of roasted malt, chocoalte, some graham cracker, and more pitty fruits and molasses!  far exceeded expectations.  This is straight up great.  I need some more of this.

Bottle with Craig, who kindly supplied this beer (cheers mate) consumed at my gaff, day three tasting 10-04-10     Pours black with a creamy textured light beige head. This is soft in the mouth with a slight tangy fruitiness. Quite a velvety mouthfeel, its smooth with warmth from the alcohol showing, creamy chocolate starts to show, its a nice beer.     A7 A4 F7 P4 Ov14  3.6

UPDATED: APR 9, 2010 Another thanks to Adrian for passing along this black beauty.  There is an odd silhouette on the label of a camel wearing a balaklava.  It smells like a fine imperial stout, with scents of toasted grain, esters, and coffee filling up the nostrils.  There is plenty of rich, smoky espresso flavor.  Some sweetness, but not too much.  Notes of iron and herby hops.  Well-balanced and interesting on the palate.  It seemed more like a coffee stout than a heavy porter to me, but why quibble?  This is an imperial brew, and a very good one.

12 oz bottle pours dark brown with light tan head.  Aroma of cofee caramel and mild treacle. Rich deep chocolate and caramel sweetness with a touch of roasted nut.  Nice bitterness.  THick mouthfeel and the lively carbonation is a bit harsh in the mouth.

12oz bottle from bruisin ales. pours black, with hints of burgandy, and a thin, sandy brown head with a tight ring of lace. aroma is outstanding with with notes of roasted malt, campfire smoke, dark chocolate, and black cherry with hints of plum, toffee, mocha coffee, and toasted nuts. flavor is simply wonderful, like the aroma on steroids, with massive roasted malts, pumpernickel toast, and bitter chocolate up front balanced by tart black cherry, cigar ash, smoked wood, and burnt coffee beans with a touch of vanilla and brownie crust. palate is medium bodied with light carbonation and a lovely, bitter, roasted malt finish that truly brings out the beauty of this beer. overall, one of the best baltic porter ive tasted.

Draft at Birreria Paradiso.  Sweet, creamy and rich like D.R. likes to do it.  Smooth, almost vanilla tones.  Blows away any geographically authentic version.  Opaque black with a brown head.  Rich!  Some sugary alcohol warmth, as to the style.  Wouldve guessed this was 7%.  Very impressive.

A deep dark porter with a thin dark brown head. An interesting aroma os smoked wood, olives and chocolate. In mouth, a bitter chocolate, overlyed with peaty notes, dark fruits, crisp and dry, light sweetness. On tap at Pizzeria Paradiso, Feb. 27 2010.

I am so glad that I started a trade with Emacgee a year ago and that I was able to trade for this one finally. Deep red-brown pour with a dark brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, dark fruit, cocoa. Taste is all of the aromas magnified. Once again, thanks Ethan. Having wanted to try this for the last year, I can say that it was worth the wait. This is one of those beers that you would like to drink quickly because it is so tasty, but respect it and savor the flavor as long as you can. It is a wish it was here in Illinois beer.  For a third and final time, Thanks Ethan.

Dark brown/black pour.  
aroma is dusty chocolate, booze, roast, bakers chocolate.  
Flutter of dark fruit, Flavor is Fruity, dark chocolate roast out the fucking wazoo.  A ton of fruits, prunes, plums, a bit of molasses, deep and rich.  perfect to style. Yum

Big ups jblauvs. Nearly black pour with a small white head. The aroma is very sweet- dark fruit, roasted barley, bakers chocolate, and mild coffee. The flavor is very lactic and dark fruity with huge roast. The complexity isnt phenomenal, but the flavors that are present are properly proportioned and simply incredible. The palate is thick, rich, velvety, and fully effervescent. A damn fine example of a damn fine style.

Thanks to jblauvs for this one. Black pour with reddish tints on the edges, small head. Aroma is definitely of a baltic porter, and it is really nice. Notes of roasted malt, bakers chocolate, coffee, a flutter of dark fruit, cocoa nib, and molasses. Flavor is so perfect for the style; the lactic, fruity notes that complement the roast, chocolate, and coffee are impeccably balanced. Mouthfeel is very smooth and extremely drinkable, but still full of flavor. Excellent brew.

The beer poured very dark with little head and had an aroma with coffee and chocolate notes and some fruitiness.  The flavor was rich, sweet and boozy with a very big coffee presence enhanced by chocolate and caramel notes and some roastiness, very complex flavor.  The palate was thick and warming with alcohol.  Overall a really big porter, but a little too sweet for my tastes.

Deep pitch black coloured body with a fully opaque body, a very thin tan head and the legs of a deep bordeaux, making for a nice look! Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, bitter nuts and a bunch of alcohol - oh yeah, some deep fruits too. Full-bodied; Deep roasty flavours with a lot of sweet vanilla and lightish fruits at the front of the palate - odd and nice at the same time. Aftertaste shows a more refined and deep roasty taste, a ton of milk and lactic qualities and some strong vanilla too - not so much coffee or chocolate though. Overall, a very nice baltic porter - great for the style, and showing a bit of a milk stout quality, which isnt common for the style. Id definitely recommend this, and was very happy to sample it, but at the end of the day, Id still prefer a Zywiec Porter! I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Chevy Chase Wine & Spirits in Washington DC on 15-February-2010, sampled at home in Washington on 03-March-2010.

12oz bottle. Pours dark brown with a tean head. Aroma is of chocolate, dark fruit, vanilla, and lactose. Taste starts off very chocolately, with a decent amount of lactic notes. There is also vanilla and some very dry, dark fruit. Very dry malt base underneath it all. Alcohol is present and takes a few sips to get used to. Lingering taste of chocolate and alcohol. Mouthfeel is medium, but very drinkable. Nothing spectacular, but it is good.

Pours deep brown/black with thin tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, coffee, and some fruit.  Taste up front is chocolate, coffee, dark fruit sweetness leading into a smoky and roasted finish that is very smooth.  Not overwhelming, but an extremely well balanced brew, no alcohol taste, and goes down way too smooth.  Great!

Bottle thanks to craftbeerdesign. Pours black with a decent foamy dark tan head. Aroma is dark and suggestive of cola or, perhaps, Dr. P. Medium plus body with mild carbonation. Flavor is very dark roasted malt with very dark fruit. Sweetish it is. Subtle dark and complex aspects. Finishes towards concentrated dried plum.Very clean and extremely sippable.

Huge thanks to Matthew for sharing this bottle with me and Emily.  Just a great malty, chocolaty, raisiny beer with just a touch of roastiness on the end.  I really need to get a 6er of this next time it rolls around.

On tap at Beneluxx tasting room in Philly.  Pours jet black with a nice mocha head that dissipated rapidly.  Aroma is of roasted malts, coffee, smoke and chocolate.  Extremely smooth mouthfeel, goes down easy.  Taste is sweet with a hint of bitterness towards the end.  A fantastic beer that tops my list.

pours dark brown with a ruby hue and a small tan head. aroma is roasted malt and a bit of tartness. mouthful is light and refreshing before the roasted flavors take over and weight the palate down in  dried fruit & coffee. finish has a bit of tart that seems to be part of the style signature... at least for me. very nice!

Wow, I think this is the best porter I have ever had in my life! Thanks go to nflmvp for the bottle. The color was a dark black but a little reddish at the edges where the light hits. The taste was a little sweet, malty and very close to the regular Duck-Rabbit porter. I savored every drop of this awesome brew.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-05-2007 19:42:43
Tap at Pizzeria Paradiso.  Dark brown with an edge head.  Aroma of anise and milk chocolate.  Great body.  Flavor also has milk chocolate, and roasted coffee.  Interesting.

pours a deep opaque brown with subtle ruby hues and a thick and creamy dark mocha head.  decent retention.  aroma has bitter chocolate, dark fruits, milkiness, roasty coffee, and defintie alcohol.  flavor has chocolate, loads of dark fruit and hints of espresso, tobacco, bitter hops and smoke.  mouthfeel is thick and creamy...sticky sweet at first and then dries out into a bold, lingering roasty finish that warms.

Pours a deep, slick brown with little head.  Strong aromas of black coffee and cacao.  Lush, creamy palate shows off the dense, rich chocolate and mocha.  Some nice woodsy notes as well as a little hint of acidity from the hops that show very little in the way of bitterness but do cut the strong malts.  A complex, well-built porter and an instant favorite.

Bottle from craftbeerdesign.  Thanks Geoff!  Nose is thick with chocolate, coffee, roast, dark candy.  Color is a velvety dark brown - very glossy.  Flavor is as it tastes.  More tart from dark chocolate, but perfectly balanced and absurdly drinkable.

12oz bottle.  Pours a deep viscous coffee brown with a thick tan head, some spotty lacing.  Nose of coffee grounds, cocoa dust and a hint of vanilla.  Flavor holds some black licorice, tobacco, bittersweet chocolate, and a hint of booze on the back end.

Bottle (thanks to TURDFERGUSON for this one, and shared with Tweety)...  Poured black with a khaki head.  Thick, full palate with a lots of yeast and fruity ester flavors going.  Roasted malts and a sweet balance to the big, alcohol flavor.  Slightly oaky with a grainy finish.

A good beer, though much like other baltic porters, so maybe hyped a bit. Chocolate, roasted malts, prunes, charcoal and finishes bitter and some tartness. Interesting beer, nice body. Wish I didnt get a whole pint of this, it was a little overwhelming.

Slightly water dark brown, almost black pour with light brown two finger head that fades quickly.  Slightly sweet with roasted malt.  Bitter coffee and alcohol dominate.  A bit heavy while lacking a bit on the flavor.

A Drunkard Tasting.    Very black with a minimal,tan foam. Pecans, Black Current, and chocolate in the nose. Heavy  sweetness to start, but finishes slightly sour. Full bodied, oily feel, long finish,  The Black currents continue, but the chocolate has changed to a roasted coffee.  A little sweeter than expected, other than that no real complaints. Well Done!!

Bottle thanks to suzygreenberg, an amazing extra to get! Pours black as black can be with a nice dark brown head that dissipated quite quickly. Aroma is amazingly full with notes of roasted malt, acidic coffee and chocolate. There is a slight undertone of alcohol on the nose. The alcohol is much more present in the flavor. It begins with roasted malts and coffee and the alcohol grows throughout. Beer is amazingly smooth and a bit thick.

Probably the best baltic porter Ive ever had. This poured a dark brown, but not quite straight black, with some decent lacing. The nose has some strong sweet malts, caramel and some light coffee. The taste is fairly sweet with caramel and dark fruit. The body isnt that heavy but it still feels almost like youre drinking syrup. Some light pine-like hops are also present but not overwhelming. This also hides the alcohol extremely well. Very well balanced beer and probably the best beer from this fledgling brewery.

12oz. Bottle. Had heard good things so I thought Id give this brewery a try and this one lived up to the billing. Murky black pour with a small layer of tan foam that doesnt last long. Interesting complex nose that is vinous, with notes of dark cherries, licorice, wood and cocoa. Shockingly smooth on the palate, it has a rich creamy texture with a mild level of carbonation.  Contains a strong chocolate malt flavor with some subtle dark fruit character and a well balanced layer of background bitterness.  This one is relatively fresh and there is no heat at all, pretty impressive job of hiding the 9%.  The aftertaste lingers on the tongue and makes you want to take another sip. Will definitely have to try a few more of their beers.

12 oz bottle pours a dark thick brown with a big dark tan foamy head that ultimately thins out pretty quick. Aroma of alcohol, licorice, chocolate, dark toffee, and bitter roasted malts. Tastes of dark fruits, licorice, mild bitterness, and toasty maltiness. Very smooth and rich. Well balanced flavors that certainly stand up and make themselves noticed as it warms. This is one porter I really enjoyed unwinding with after work by the fireplace - looking forward to my next visit with this winner.
Draft: dark black with a thick, creamy tan head, aroma of roasted malts, taste is malty, slightly sweet, some coffee, full bodied, an excellent beer

Thanks Durhambeer.  I dont know what I would do without my supply.  This beer is a great example of a Baltic porter.  When poured it is thick and a very dark/black color.  It has a nice brown head that sticks with the beer.  The nose is sweet with hints of vanilla and roasty-ness.  The palate is thick and luxurious and velvety.  I love the taste of this beer.  There the maltyness with hints of vanilla and coffee flavors.  The flavors melt in your mouth and it is hard not to share this beer.  I wish it were available year round.

Bottle courtesy of DeputyAndy.  Pour is black with beige head atop.. fades prettty quickly.  Aroma is espresso, funk, and slight booziness.  Taste is rich cocoa, espresso, with a hot tart taste in the finish.  Awesome stuff.. cant taste the 9% at all.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2011 Pours a pitch black with a dark coffee mocha head. Nice coffee notes in the nose with some deep woodsy spice. Taste is very dark chocolate with just a hint of bitterness at the very end. Finishes very smooth. Hides alcohol very well.
Bottle. Dark pour some brown head. Best baltic porter Ive had so far. Aroma is of dark fruits, and dark malts. Velvety smooth texture great beer.Abv not apparent, not even a slight warming.
From a bottle poured black with a small brown head.  Nice smokey toasted malt flavor with a lasting finish.

Waited too long to try this.  Had the BA version at the ORF tasting which was phenomenal and this was no let-down.  Malty aroma with chocolate notes and slight coffee.  Taste is full bodied and delicious.  Malty, chocolate, nice carbonation, smooth but punching on the palate.  Just a great brew.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours very dark.  Hints of earthiness in the nose along with a sharp scent of roasted malts.  Pretty woody.  A little sweet in the beginning.  Very nice intense roasty bitter finish.  Very nice stuff.

Rich malty aroma, chocolate and hints of coffee, with traces of creamy vanilla on the nose.  Pours black with a thin tan head.  Rich dark malt flavors, coffee liqueur, dark bitter chocolate in the flavor, very smooth.  Excellent baltic porter!
Very sweet and rich. Big creamy tan head. Roasty. That tart/sweetness in a porter/stout really signifies the Duck Rabbit style for me. Very enjoyable beer.

Bottle from Secret Santa.  Thanks Santa!  Very dark brown, nearing black, pour with tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, some wood.  Basically smells absolutely awesome.  Flavor is deep rich chocolate, lightly creamy, with wood notes.  Some smoke and fruit.  Very rich.  Really complex and well crafted.  Stunning.  The quintessential Baltic porter.

Pretty delightful stuff, and fantastic at the price.  Nose of chocolate and coffee.  Dark brown, almost black, and almost opaque, with a very small tan head.  First impression of coffee, chocolate, bourbon, and some hop notes at the end.  Marvelous velvet silky oily mouth feel.  Remarkable for a porter and remarkable for the price.

On tap at Capones.  Thick opaque black color with no head.  Aroma of roasted malts, dark chocolate, and molasses.  Flavor is complex-roasted malts, dark chocolate, molasses, and dark fruit.  Definitely a sipping beer.  Velvety on the palate.  Just wonderful!

12 oz. bottle from City Beverage in Winston-Salem.  Thick, dark brown to black pour with a very thin and quickly fading tan head.  Aroma of dark fruit, coffee, and a bit of smoke.  Dark chocolate flavor with a hint of fruit tartness (possibly blueberry).  Oily, slick mouthfeel.  Some warming alcohol detected.  Worthy of the praise it receives.
12 oz. bottle.  pours a pitch black, light head.  Great flavor considering the alcohol content.

Bottle  Pours a great dark brown with a tan head.  The disapates quickly, and laces well.  Has a good aroma of raost, alcohol, and malts.  Has a moderate carbonation.  The flavor is excellent.  Sweet and sharp.  This is what I think of when I thinkbaltic porter.  A hearty touch on the heavy side winter brute.  Well blended.  Has a medium to full body.  The texture is thicker.  Has a great finish and a wonderful aftertaste.  I waited a while for this one and it was as good as advertised.

Just one of those beers when you thank whatever you dare to believe in for creating craft beer. An alcohol tinged roasted malt and chocolate nose rise from an Imperial Stout like body and a dark brown, puffy quarter-inch head. The flavor is where this Baltic really brings it home. The taste is equal to dark chocolate covered raspberries and plums and a heavy cocoa aftertaste. An absolute beauty of a body and soft mouthfeel that hides the alcohol well, rounds out this delicate brew. Buy this beer whenever possible!

12oz bottle, best by October 2014?  Pours black with thin brown foam that fades to a thin layer, almost no lacing.  Aroma is barely there, mix of booze, dark chocolate and stale coffee.  Very sweet up front, molasses, cocoa powder and some faint licorice notes, just a hint of bitterness.  Subtle is an understatement, too smooth for 9%.

bottle thanks to emacgee.  poured black with a nice tan head and decent lacing and legs.  aroma was chocolate, dark roast, whipping cream, and some nice alcohol.  flavor was dark roast, alcohol, small piney bitter, and what seemed to be an ever so small presence of smoke.  body was medium with low carbonation and very smooth.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of malts, chocolate, light coffee, light molasses, roasting, and slight soy sauce.  Poured pitch black in color with a medium to large-sized, creamy, dense, brown head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Very slightly sparkling.  Flavor is medium to heavily sweet.  Tastes of chocolate, malts, light roasting, slight soy sauce, black-strap molasses, and hints of tobacco and vanilla.  Medium to full body.  Syrupy, smooth, then lightly dry texture.  Soft carbonation.  Chocolate, malt, slight roasting, and molasses finish is lightly dry.  9%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

12oz bottle served in a snifter. Pours very dark brown, nearly black, with ruby edges. A thin layer off quickly dissipating mocha colored head forms on top. The nose is full of dark Belgian chocolate, some cocoa powder, and hints of grass and booziness. The flavor is blackstrap molasses, dark chocolate, some woody esters, and a boozy character that develops as it warms. Rich and sweet but not sticky. A very good beer that would do well to warm you on a cold night.

This pours a dark ruby tinted, jet black color.  A minimal head of brown foam forms and quickly fades.  Lacing is fairly minimal.

The nose is full of sweet maltiness.  Light notes of chocolates and coffee are present, along with some hints of dark fruits.  A slight booziness is also detected.

This is a huge porter, as in flavor-wise its almost more like a barleywine.  It has a huge level of sweet malts.  Very good presence of dark roasted coffee.  Milk chocolates and dark chocolates combine with a lacto-like sweetness.  This is all attempted to be balanced by the roastiness of the malts, but the sweetness is slightly more prominent.
This is very tasty!

This is medium-bodied with a light-to-medium level of carbonation.  It is very smooth drinking, with little creaminess to speak of.  This is fairly true to style though, so no real surprise.

This one is delicious and easy drinking.  At the halfway point though, Im already starting to feel the 9.00%abv.  Not one for sessioning, but very tasty.

355 ml bottle. Dark body with a big, rust-red head that disappears. Aroma of sweet, roasted malt, chocolate, liquorices and some alcohol, very lovely and complex. Flavor is complex as well. Sweet, roasted malt, chocolate, liquorices, some alcohol and a subdued bitterness. Very nice indeed.
Bottle thanks to mcbackus: Poured a black brown with a light brown head. The aroma is chocolate, roasted malt, and dark fruits. Taste is bitter bakers chocolate and roastedness.
Pours with a black body topped by a thin head with some lacing.  Its sweet and malty with lots of raisin and bourbon notes as well as a slight sourness.  Full bodied, smooth and a touch warming.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2012 Gorgeously dark brown/black pour with a lasting, frothy head.  Aroma is immense and full of sweet plum, roasted malt, and a bit of smoke.  Flavor is equally bold with notes of cappuccino in addition to the aromatic elements.  Palate is quite smooth with a slight alcohol bite at the back.  It may be picky, but dropping the alcohol 1% would have made this almost perfect.  The flavors and richness push towards that of an imperial stout, which makes me wonder, but ...
Certainly one of the most enjoyable Baltic Porters I have had the chance to experience.

Thanks Ucusty for this treat! Pours black with a fizzy disappearing orange head. Aroma is chocolate, maple syrup, dark fruit, and a touch of roast. The flavor is very rich and fruity, with a little tang. Also sweet, with orange, strawberries, and plums. Some chocolate flavor as well and a nice roasted malt quality in the finish. Almost no bitterness. A great flavor in a great beer. The mouthfeel is fantastic too. Thick and velvety smooth. Like molasses. Loved this beer.
Beautiful. Glorious mouth-feel and beautiful color. Keeps its head quite nicely. Much better than their Milk Stout in my opinion...

Dark brown pour, thick looking, thin tan head dissipates quickly. Lots of chocolate in the aroma, roasted and smoked malt, and some lactic acid. The flavor is both bitter and sweet, mostly chocolate, caramel, coffee, some burnt malt in the finish.

From a bottle into an English pint glass.  Pours quite dark with pretty much no head, but the ringlet is dark brown.  The flavor is quite sweet and a bit sour, almost like lemon flavored molasses.  The finish and exhale are deep roast and dark chocolate malts.  The aroma is sweet with an alcohol burn and overall reminds of various fortified wines.  With some warmth a solid touch of smoke comes through as well.

Bottle from Ohiodad I got in November 2006 in a trade, Im excited to see how the beer has aged.  Pours an opaque dark brown color with a very minimal dark tan head.  Aroma is  raisin/bourbon dominated with a slight note of toasted malt in the background.  Slight smokiness if the nose as well.  Flavor is extremely sweet, lots of raisin- like a barleywine.  Seems past its prime in the flavor.  Very slick on the palate, another sign of age/infection (I think its age more than anything).  I liked this beer the first time I had it, but its not very representative of a baltic porter at this point in the aging process.  And as a side note, I stored the beer in my cellar (which is kept at 60F).

Bottle, very special thanks to danielcurtis81 for sharing on the eve of his wedding. Pours pitch black with thick but quickly fading brown cake-like head. Nose is dark roast and chocolate malts, some sweetness similar to lactose. Taste is similar to nose with an overall acidic feel to it, a little sour, but smooth and easy to drink. Very pleasing on the palate. This is a great porter!

Bottle.
Absolutely pitch black. Miniscule beige head.
Aroma dominated by heavily roasted malts and a whiff of dry hops. Cold coffee, and some chocolaty sweet burned sugar etc in the baackground Hint of oaky brandyliike alocholy sweetness.
Ditto for flavor.
Full body, moderate carbonation, dryish mouthfeel.

Bottled (thanks [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */). Very dark ambery brown, quite 95% black, opaque colour with small brown head. Aroma is roasted, mild toffee, some tobacco as well as mild dark chocolate notes. toffee, liquorice, and ashes. Also quite much fudge in it. Fudge and big chocolate with some mild roasted malts/smoked wood in the finish.

Another huge thanks to daknole.  A huge, malty brew.  Lots of malt, tobacco, kinda burnt wood, and some bitter, dark chocolate on the nose and flavor.  A big bitter rush in the finish is fantastic, and leaves a great dryness.  One hell of a beer.

Bottle, big thanks to Ibrew2or3 for sharing.  Poured black with a dense, creamy beige head.  Nose is full of roasted malt, chocolate and smoke with a softer note of vanilla.  Medium to full bodied with an oily mouthfeel and soft carbonation.  Flavor is slightly sweet with chocolate and rasted malt, slighty boozy and slightly acidic.  This beer is extremely smooth and drinkable.  Excellent!

[2284-20090618] 355mL bottle. Heavy roast aroma is sweet. Dark brown black body with a quick creamy tan head. Very full roast flavour with a long sweet burnt roast finish. Full body. Boozy but hidden in the burnt roast.
(w/ DuctTape, jerc)

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2010 2008 bottle.  Rated 08/09/2009.  Big thanks to Duck Rabbit for bringing this to Georgia!  Pours pure black with a small tan head.  Light lacing.  Big roasted aroma...malts, chocolate, coffee, and dark fruits.  Big flavor that follows with more of the same roasted coffee, chocolate, and tons of dark fruits.  Sour and tart note on the finish.  Rich, creamy mouthfeel with low carbonation.  An amazing brew, amazing baltic porter.  Not sure if I like this or the Sinebrychoff more.  Gonna have to do a side-by-side comparison in the near future.  Cant go wrong with either.  One of my favorite beers!
2009 bottles.  Fresh is best with Duck-Rabbit, dont worry about aging.  No sourness when fresh, last bottle Im having here in early February is picking up a tartness in the taste.   There is also some consistency issues with this beer...Ive had a few over the years that were off, even beyond the sourness it picks up over time, as well as one that was completely flat and not very good at all (guessing it wasnt capped properly).  This loses a lot of its luster as you get to the bottom of the glass.  Overall incredibly flavorful, and packs quite a punch, feels like 11%, but I think its a little over-rated.  I do prefer Sinebrychoff Porter, but this is also an excellent example of a Baltic Porter, and one I will enjoy each year it comes out.
Pours a deep ruby brown. Nose is huge chocolate, sweet sugar, vanilla ice cream. Roasty malt flavor, sweet chocolate, more chocolate, vanilla. Big full mouthfeel. YUM!

bottle thanks to alexsdad06. Poured very dark brown to black with nearly no carbonation or head? not sure if it was supposed to be that way but I enjoyed it anyway.  Aroma was roasted coffee, alcohol, lots of chocolate.  Taste was whiskey, chocolate, very sweet, cherries. Super smooth. Good stuff.

pours black or a very dark brown. Aroma is  rather boozy with notes of chocolate, coffee, and caramel. Flavor is very weird for a baltic porter in my opinion much sweeter than what I am accustomed to. Notes of alcohol, almond, fruit (raisin and fig), coffee and chocolate are ever present. In addition to the afformentioned flavors I also detect molasses. The lingering flavor after a swallow is better than the initial taste.

Pours very dark with a small brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, fruit, coffee, and chocolate. Alcohol is lightly present in the aroma. Taste is of sweet with malt, molasses, chocolate, and coffee. Alcohol is not present in taste or finish. Body is medium with minimal carbonation. Finish is dry. Very drinkable and nice.

Enormous thanks to Durhambeer for this one!
Pours black with the old espresso swirl head and a small lace. The aroma is roasty coffee molasses and chocolate, simple and straight forward but absolutely awesome and enticing. The flavor has an amazing start with chocolate with some cherries and some coffee. Sweet but not cloying at all. There is a little burnt maltiness and a but of alcohol which both play nicely in the balance of this beer. Very cordial like! Very viscous!
Shakeyfest 09. Thanks again Andy! Nice chocolate. Slight wood. Very thick. Low carbonation.

Bottle thanks to Jake65.  Pours a near black brown with thin tan head the recedes to the edges quickly, minimal lacing.  Aroma strong of coffee, toasted and roasted malts, chocolate, and lots of spices and alcohol.  Flavor matches pretty well, but comes together for a nice balance and an enjoyable brew.  Nothing out of this world, but pretty good.

12 oz bottle courtesy of a GAManiac trade. Thanks, Grant! I continue the Duck Rabbit Trek.. just this and one more to go! Pours a very dark near black pour, fairly thick, ruby edges, fair light brown chocolate milk head that laces some, stays at a small layer. Aromas are a nice chocolate base, sweet and semi sweet mix, with coffee, roasted malts, a touch of caramel, a light dark fruitiness of plum and muted cherries. Initial is farly heavy bodied, throwing chocolate, a bit bitter, with roasted malts, a caramel malt sweetness combined with plum and cherries come through stronger, dark fruits are plentiful. Fairly rich and decadent, a bit cakey, but the dark fruits come out after the chocolate (The other major element of the beer in my opinion). A bit creamy and heavy bodywise (Not a bad thing), Finish is a bit sweet, with fairly good roast, and some decent dark fruitiness coming out even there. A pretty good brew overall. Smooth and rich.

Near black in color. Looks like blood spilled on the table cloth. Thick and chewy feel. Scents of dark chocolate, lightly roasted malt, dark ripe fruits and a hint of treacle. Full flavors with rich, lightly earthy malt, dark chocolate, rum soaked fruit cake and touch of coffee. Finish and linger have a bit of dark malt bitterness and some light fruit. A rich and hearty brew.

12oz bottle from Chucks Fine Wines.  Black pour with a huge tan head.  Smoky aroma with chocolate, coffee, molasses and lots of dark fruit.  Raisin and molasses flavor up front with chocolate and a semi-dry coffee finish to balance out the sweetness.  Tasty stuff.

Bottle split with curly to pop his baltic porter cherry.  Very dark brown pour with good brown head.  Chocolate, sweet dark berries, anise, oak, vanilla nose.  Flavors dont quite hold up as well, but huge rum soaked fruit, milk chocolate, bitter chocolate, and gets sweeter as it warms, some woodiness.  Sweet but not cloying, medium body with almost no real traces of alcohol.  Very tasty, but maybe just a little to rich for my personal taste.

Solid black with a medium sized brown head that eventually fades. Toasted malt, choc., vanilla, ripe dark fruit, and some hop citrus spice aroma also. Taste is more of a bitter dark chocolate and coffee with a thin feel. Alcohol is slightly warming but very well balanced. Also it seems like there some hop citrus and cocoa in the finish.
Aroma of wood and smokey chocolate notes.  Flavor of chocolate, bourbon, and wood notes with a still weird smokey tone to it.  Just OK to me

2009-06-18. Black body with a modest brown head that fades. (3+) Aroma has a good amount of dry roast but it is not overbearing. Modest notes of dark fruits are pervasive and pleasant. (7+) Flavour is similar, mild roast, lots of dark fruit character, good amount of nondescript bitterness balances it nicely, light lingering roasty cocoa. (8+) Smooth medium bodied palate is lightly carbonated. (3+) Rather good. I suspect it is a bit more assertive when fresh but it has held up rather well in the cellar and is quite pleasant.  Bottle approximately a year old, via trade with TheCheeseman

Bottle via trade with Boutip. Pours a rich deep brown with some large cola size bubbles. Spicy pepperoni and chocolate to the nose, with some smoke, coffee, rich roasty malt in aroma and taste. Well carbonated and dry. Incredibly good, need to get some more!

Bottle. Pours an almost complete black, small tan head that dissipates rather quickly, leaving a fleeting wispy head around the edges. Aroma is subdued roast coffee, chocolate and in the background some alcohol. Flavor is right away bitter-sweet, roast coffee, bakers chocolate, malt, a touch of dark fruit and just a touch of alcohol. Bitterness on the finish, but mellows rather quickly.

355ml bottle from a trade with the cheeseman. pours black with a small tan head. dark malt aroma with toffee and caramel. nice dark beer flavours with caramel and toffee, some coffee, some chocolate and some dark fruit. it smoth and drinkable but not overly complex. good but not mind blowing.

12oz bottle at matt7215s place, his bottle, thanks for holding onto this one for me Matt. Pours a nice viscous dark brown, barely translucent with a tiny mocha head. The aroma is huge on the soy sauce, also rich burnt caramalt and toffee, leather as well as anise. Not amazing but nothing too off-putting. The flavour is full of the above mentioned aspects working well off of eachother as well as some residual sugar and a fuller mouth-feel. Surprisingly fizzy, though thankfully this doesnt spoil the show. A tad astringent and with okay balance but not escaping the realm of a very sweet beer. No fruity esters as one would expect from a beer made with lager yeast. Not my favourite Baltic Porter, though I still quite enjoyed it. Nicely done though I dont fully comprehend such a high rating.

bottle, via trade with ddchmela, black resinous pour with a strong vinegar, stewed prune and raisin aroma, flavor has a lot of very old balsamic vinegar, parmesan cheese, soy, chocolate, fig and lasting finish, great beer, thanks Dave

Bottle from BelgianBeerGal (Thanks!)  Dark black pour, almost no carbonation.  Aroma was sweet malts, and rich boozy chocolate.  Flavor was roasted malts,  tobacco, vanilla, and boozy (with a little smoke) on the finish.  A very good and well balanced beer!

Small, creamy, tan head with a little lacing.  Great body and great taste.  Sweet, yet zesty bitterness as an aftertaste. Wonderful chocolate color and a chocolate flavor.  I would definitely drink it again if someone placed it down in front of me.

Pour is a viscous black color with a brown head.  Aroma of tart cherries with a ton of chocolate and malt.  Flavors are bold and unrelenting with chocolate and a fruity tartness dominating.  Very good and very drinkable.

Thanks to Brigadier. Pour is awesome black with nice brown head. Aroma is chocolate milkshake, slight alcohol, Smooth malt, and light raspberries. Flavor is chocolate, coffee, with a complex malt finish.  Hops are subtle but balance it all so wonderfully.  Great beer!
Bottle thanks dave.  Pours black with tan head.  Dark licorice smell.  Very cocoa-like.  Very smooth feel to it.  Awesome.
Bottle from bu11zeye. 2007 vintage. Black with a tan head. Nice aroma is tobacco black malts cocoa. Medium body. Light oxidation in flavor with black roasted malts and dark chocolate.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Jun 2007 Bottle thanks to xnoxhatex! Pours a lovely uniform obsidian with a frothy beige small head 4.5.  Nicely oxidized rich malty aroma, sweet dark fruits, touch of raisin, dark chocolate, coats the nostrils, molasses, some milkiness 8.5.  Rich syrupy first taste, lightly fruity, touch of grains/grassy, chocolate syrup, not overly sweet.  Clean finish.   Great body, syrupy but with fantastic fizzy carbonation, not too sticky.  Great beer.

Bottle thanks to frumptydumpty, about two years old.  Opaque black with creamy, medium, burnt brown head.  Aroma is roasty, a little smokey, oxidation but not too intense, chocolate, slight sweetness.  Sweet roast flavor, some oxidation, raspberry, other fruit, slight alc, chocolate, quite tasty.  Medium and syrupy body.  Amazing, this was good fresh and is fantastic aged.

Bottle from the cooler-behind-the-cooler at Chucks Fine Wines. The beer pours nearly pitch black with a medium brown head that dissolves to a film eventually. Stringy lacing on the glass. Aroma of dark chocolate covered raspberries and cherries plus a bit of coffee. Rich and smooth body with flavors of coffee, caramel malt and tart fruits. Nice chocolatey character throughout. The finish is moderately bitter coffee balanced by sweet malt. Very good, possibly the best Baltic Porter around.

Pours black with a very thin head even with a rigorous pour.  Aroma is roasted malts, some mild fruit notes, and some alcohol...muted, yet still present.  Flavor is very smooth...roasted malt, dark fruits, a bit of smoke, hints of chocolate and smoke, and just blends together beautifully.  Palate is very nicely done...this one drinks very easily.  Nice offering...great Baltic!
Poured black with a brown head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Lots of flavor. Hint of smoke and caramel in the finish.

12oz bottle from weeheavy. Poured into a snifter, nice little mocha colored head that faded quickly. Black in color. Aroma of brown sugar, maple syrup, lightly roasted malts and some dark fruits maybe. Taste is roasted malts, dark fruits, maybe some grapes or raspberries? Unique flavors that I cant put my finger on... maybe some kind of licorice root or even ginger root. Sweet taste overall. Light, easy to drink texture. The nine percent is hidden well. Nice sipping beer as the commercial description says. Overall a nice beer. Thanks jon for sending this one to me!

The first time, not knowing about the fruit taste, this was almost a drain pour.  Just plain weird, as though there was a bit of raspberry or even grape syrup mixed in.

Second time around I warmed to it a bit, as the fruit does really meld well with some nice roastiness and a great mouthfeel.

A nice beer, and a unique beer.  Not sure there is much more to it though.

Single bottle purchased at Chucks in Chagrin.  At first sniff (pre-pour) it was clear this was not the usual porter.  It smells of dried strawberries (my favourite dried fruit.) Upon further nasal inspection, it has some blueberry, fig and raisin notes.  This aroma is very fruity, amazingly so in fact, given that it all smells natural, not processed, artificial or added.  Appearance of this one is a nice black with a thin dark mocha head on it.  The flavor is outstanding.  I dont know if this fits into what I expect from a baltic porter, it isnt really bitter, dry or that roasty.  This is smooth and fruity with a finish of coffee and chocolate.  God, this is fantastic.  The flavor this amazing fruity flavor, dried strawberries again, and just melts right into this gentle bitterness and rich malty flavor.  I need to get my ass to North Carolina for some of this brew, it is top notch.  Normally with a 9%er I am expecting some serious flavors, something that I need to slow down with an takes some chewing to get into.  Not this, it is the perfect level of complex yet enjoyable.  Fruity and hearty, and fan-fucking-tastic.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2009 Bottle courtesy of WeeHeavySD and opened as a late b-day present to myself.  Pours near black with a filmy brown head.  Aroma is deep roast, but with a strong and surprising dark fruit presence.  Flavor likewise has beautiful dark cherry undertones to the coffee/chocolate base. The booze is present only as a slight warming in the finish.  Much less sweetness than expected, but its not missed.  Amazingly balanced.  I really, really want more.

#200 rating! Bottle courtesy of Antzman-thanks! Pours a dark brown/almost black with a thin tan head. Has a roasty, sweet, fruity aroma with hints of liquorice, plums,raisins, cherries and chocolate.  Creamy texture flavor is a rich dark chocolate with berries that has an excellent finish and aftertaste. A very complex beer with a lot going on. Simply delicious!

Bottle. Aroma of sweet roasted malt, raisinets, deeply roasted coffee, huge earthy hop notes. Flavor really expands on the coffee notes, really rich, dark coffee, joined by the earthy hops as well as an increasingly nutty character. The sweet malt at times threatens to overrun the whole scene, but thankfully never does. On the superb side of things.

Bottle courtesy of JCB.  Pours black with a small light tan head.  Aroma of sweet roasted malt and a touch of booze and smokey meats.  Flavor of sweet malt and some smokiness in the background.  A touch of vegetal notes.  Pretty tasty, slightly on the syrupy/heavy side.  This is pretty decent, but I dont think its a 4+ beer.  A little on the sweet side.
7/4/8/4/14 (3.7/5)

Great pour! Could smell the fruitiness as soon as the cap was popped! Molasses,dark fruits,raisons, coffee that then melds into Huge Cherries!!!!!! With hidden chocolate tones as well! WOW!!!! Flovor is out of control!  Strawberry Ice cream, ripe bananas, and chocolate!  This is a banana split with strawberry ice cream beer! Almonds, nuts, and cream slip in almost unnoticed  as they are mixed in with the other flavors. Finishes with subtle licorice and fruit cake. The bitter hop finish is just enough to keep you wanting more... as is the alcohol! I could drink this waY TOO FAST!

Courtesy of Papsoe. It is pitch black with a light brown, creamy head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, licorice and dark fruit. The mouthfeel is nice and fat. The flavour has sweetness and notes of roasted malt, licorice, dark fruit, chocolate and preserved berries. It is a very pleasant and well balanced Baltic porter.

12oz bottle thanks to MrChopin. Pours black with brown edges and thin tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, sweet sugar and molasses, coffee and bitter chocolate. Flavor is sweet with roasted malts, chocolate, caramel and some light coffee. Mouthfeel is medium as it smells thinner if that makes sense. It smells like an imperial stout but tastes like a porter. Really complex and a nice sipper.
Smelled of roaste/almost burnt malts. Poured midnight brown, zero head. Had a real roasted/burnt malt flavor with a real twang in the finish. A bit thin. Not impressed based on the high marks.

Bottle thanks to tronraner.  Notched 9/08.  Dark dark black pour with a quick tan head that leaves no cover.  Nose is a bit thin, cold coffee grounds, some fruitiness, cocoa, anise, and maybe alcohol that is thinning it out.  Nice body of sweet lightly roasty malts, heavy coffee, some chocolate and more anise underneath.  Would just love it to have a touch more in the aroma.

Bottle via TheBeersom.  Thanks Matt.  Pours a deep black.  Quickly settling head.  nose is thin and is mostly of cold coffee.  Body is surpisingly medium.  quietly sweet and then smack!  nearly soured coffee/spoiling fruit with some anise hints. A quick one.
Black in color with a medium sized brown head. Aroma is of chocolate, cocoa, coffee and booze. Taste is heavy in chocolate and coffee, with rich dark fruit, licorice, and alcohol.

Bottle from 07 acquired via trade with blipp.  Pours a silky black color with a faint ring of brown foam.  Smells of bakers cocoa and barley.  Tastes like deer blood, mild coffee, dark cherries, caramel, and black licorice.  Succulent, but not quite what the RIS offers.

Bottle, aged about 1 year.  Pours a pitch black beer with a medium tan head.  Aroma is super sweet malt and chocolate.  Flavor is sweet, mostly tasting of chocolate and a dark fruit, malt character is still ther and the hops finish it with a nice bite that is bitter and dry.  Alcohol is well hidden, mouthfeel is decent.  Awesome beer!
