Big old thanks to ucusty for this one!

Pours a nice black with ruby amber hues and tan head.  The aroma has notes of sweet malt, dark chocolate, coffee, caramel, anise?, and maybe some soy sauce?  The flavor has lots sweet malt, dark fruit (prune), coffee, caramel, a bit burnt sugar, and port. The mouthfeel is pretty normal.  Overall, this is good stuff!

Bottle from Greens for $1.50 which I would say is not a bad price, not a bad price at all for this quality and tasty brew. Soy sauce and molasses aroma. The flavor is prune and molasses again. The fruit flavors fade into a roasted coffee and bittersweet chocolate.  Creamy smooth texture. The finish is a bit hot and alcohol which barring that would make this one fine beer.
Bottle. Tastes of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and tart cherries. Also a parfume like taste that does not fit. This knock it down a few notches for me.

Draught @ Brick Store. Pitch black. Brown head. Luscious looking. Lots of up front cherry notes. Tar, asphalt, coffee, bold and rich. Creamy, velvety mouthfeel. Lovely body. The coffee, chocolate, cherry blend in the aromas and carry right on through into the flavors. More coffee than expected. An excellent rendition of a style that has generally underwhelmed me.

2008 Bottle - Thanks Ibrew2or3 - Pours a thick black slurry with a minimal tan head...aroma is dark fruit, chocolate malt, pumpernickle bread?...flavour is bold and smooth, toffee, charred wood, almost a bit of barrel, finishes with a vanilla kick, fun fun beer...

Thanks to biggcb for the bottle.  This was the 07 batch with a year, maybe two, on it.  Aroma is chocolate and the dust before the rain. Pours darkest brown with a thin dark head with a distinct reddish hue.  No lace.  Flavor starts out as chocolate and espresso, with a subtle but unfading malt presence behind it.  Sipping my way through the glass, caramel, toffee, and vanilla emerge, some cherries, a bit of leather and bitter melon on the end.  Its all very mellow and understated.  Theres never a real wow moment, but a very long lasting yum.  Warm, thick, full-bodied on the tongue.

Very intense for a porter. Pitch black and full-bodied, I cant even begin to list all of the flavors. Grape, banana, cherry coffee, Brazil nuts, and many other flavors all mix together for a sensory explosion.

12ozer thanks to bmartin08 in the NP10. Pour is oily black with a juicy, thick brown head. Aromas of roasted malt, sweet fruits, chocolate, and a hint of alcohol. The flavor is somewhat sweet. Chocolate and malt come in strong in the finish. Very smooth and viscus for a porter. Another great brew.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: 12 oz bottle via trade with mreusch. Pours an opaque black with a brown head that soon dissipates to a fine film. The aroma is big and bold with coffee, chocolate, dark fruits, licorice and  a touch of alcohol. The flavor, like the aroma, is complex and bold; dark chocolate covered raspberries on lightly burnt toast comes to mind. This is quite an impressive explosion of flavors. The finish is long and biter-sweet with licorice and walnuts. The mouthfeel is smooth with a little bit of grit on the back end. Overall: Ive been trying to land this one for a long time and it did not disappoint. One of the best porters that I have ever sampled. Thanks Matt.

Pours a dark brown body almost black with a small, tan head that settles quickly to a thin film. The aroma is really nice and shows notes of dark chocolate, toasted caramel, coffee, and dark fruits. The flavor follows and is very malt forward with the dark fruits soaked in chocolate followed by roastd coffee and creamy caramel. Really nice flavor combinations. Medium-full bodied and smooth with an almost creamy texture and perfectly carbonated. A nice long finish with bittersweet chocolate left behind that makes you want to come back for more. Just a great baltic porter. I need to get more of this stuff.

On tap at The Brick Store. Pours opaque black with a thin, tan head that leaves lots of lace. The aroma is intense - fruity, roasty, with a noticeable bit of alcohol. There are notes of sour cherries, coffee, and licorice. This beer has a huge, pulpy nose - great. The flavor starts with some roast and lots of fruit - mainly cherry, but subtle banana and raspberry, too. Chocolate abounds here, too. The malt profile is chewy with sweet caramel and fruit towards midpalate. The middle of the tongue finds some earthy, tarry hop bitterness and lots of rich molasses and chocolate - all with a subtle acidity. The finish is full and bittersweet - mostly sweet - with a fruity chocolate aftertaste and warming alcohol. The mouthfeel is quite rich and full in body with some acidity and subtly biting (though somewhat soft) carbonation. Overall, a very unique dessert beer that is big and incredibly complex.

Smell is roast, chocolate, cream, coffee, malts, sort of moch like. Look is pretty black with brown tinges and a light beige head.  Nice feel.  Smooth so easy to drink.  The flavors are roasty, malts, coffee, some alcohol, and chocolate.

Bottle.  Huge aroma of sweetness, chocolate, soyishness, and some roast.  Black body, with a small but very pretty brown head.  Flavor is powerful, sweet-tart, fruity, chocolate, and cannot fail to make an impression.  Lengthy finish, where the alcohol begins to show its presence.

Thanks OldGrowth!  Black pour with a tan head that lasts only moments.  Nose is delectable with cherries and vanilla.  It is very sweet.  Flavor is rich offering wood, alcohol, coffee, and chocolate covered cherries.  Feel is amazingly thick and smooth if a bit powdery with a bit of fizz.  This is an incredible beer.  I cannot imagine a better porter.

Thanks retorp for the share. Pours a dark black with a nice beige head.  Nice yellow lace upon swirling. Aroma is dark chocolate, vanilla, with some noticeable coffee pieces. Flavor has roasted character and some bourbonyness. Velvet and sweet; I could get this as an everyday beer. It does share a lot in common with an imp stout.

12oz bottle from bhalter8. Pours a dark black color with tannish one finger yellow head that settles slowly and provides ample lacing on the glass. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of dark chocolate, roasted coffee, dark ripe fruit, toffee, caramel, prunes. Flavor is also sweet and malty with notes of dark ripe fruit, dark chocolate, sweet caramel, toffee, ripe dark fruit, molasses, honey, and hints of spice. Generally medium body with a pleasing coffee and phenol finish.

Bottle from nearbeer. Thanks. Poured an opaque black color. the head was brown with an orange tint. Pleasant aroma of chocolate, dark fruit cake, and coffee. There was also a whiff of anise. Full bodied and and slightly sweet. The sugars were tempered somewhat by the ample roastiness. Molasses, chocolate, orange peel, and coffee flavors with a warming alcohol effect. Good beer.

[Bottle] Pours pitch black with a very small, soapy beige head. Aroma is quite sweet, lots of malt, some roasty bitterness hidden back there, a touch of chocolate, vanilla, and some coffee. Mouthfeel is rich and smooth, and somewhat oily. Gains a little astringency toward the end that is accompanied by a little bit of tartness. Flavor matches the aroma pretty well. Alcohol is barely evident, except for a little sweetness in the aroma.
Very dark and oily for a porter.  Pours black with a small amber head.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate, roasted malt.  Flavor is great but I am thinking Impy while drinking it.

Pours a deep, rich, opaque sable, nearly black, with a thick, dark tan head that dissipates slowly. Rich aroma has good coffee and smoky tones, and an overtone of miso or salted fish. Flavor has the same fishy/salty overtone, but is still pleasingly smoky with hints of roast coffee, unsweet chocolate and hops, and a nutty undertone. Texture is thick and smooth, leaving a whisper of sweetness in the lively aftertaste.

Bottle courtesy of kmweaver. Pours black with a small mocha head that diminishes to a thin ring and a few islands of bubbles at the surface. The nose is a big sweet blend of roasted malt, chocolate, tart dark fruit, coffee, tobacco and alcohol. Full-bodied and oily-slick with fine carbonation and a roasty, mildly tart/acidic finish. The flavor follows the nose with an emphasis on the dark roasted malt, tobacco and tart dark fruit notes. This is an interesting and tasty brew. Thanks again for sending it my way, Ken. :)

2007 bottle. Pours near black with a tan head. Sweet chocolate aroma with roasted malt, caramel and dark fruits. The flavor brings a heavier roasted note than the aroma with a touch of fruit and smoke, as well as some chocolatey sweetness. Nice and long roasty finish.

Coutesy of Storm. Black with medium beige head. Sweet aroma with loads of roasted malt, coffee and chokolate. Flavour is very sweet and full bodied with plenty of roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Soft mouthfeel. Nice.

Pours smooth, black and oily.  A thin tan head emerges as the strong aroma fills the air.  The nose is pungent with milk chocolate, dark fruits, and coffee.  The taste is complex, constantly evolving as the beer warms.  Raisins and licorice become more apparent as the beer nears room temperature.  Hardly a porter, it should be called an imperial stout.  An excellent beer from a company who knows how to brew dark beers.  A+

Pours a motoroil colour. Chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt in the nose. Taste matched the aroma with a touch of dark fruit and possibly licorice as it warmed. Very solid. I have wanting to try this for two years and it did not disappoint.

I guess Im just against the grain.  I can appreciate a roasted, dark beer, but I dont think it is heaven on earth.  How is this not an impy stout?  Midnight black.  Tons of coffee and chocolate in the nose.  Flavor matches the nose.  Very oily.  Good, burnt finish.  One of the smoothest beers Ive had in the dark beer category.  Sigh, five more to sip through.

Poured from a 12-oz bottle. Best enjoy by date of 10/09. Appearance was black with a thin brown head. Smell was all over the place - either that or I was imaging things. Thought I detected chocolate, toffee, burnt grain, raisins, caramel and molasses. A sweet carbonated taste of roasted malts, cofee, dark fruit with a bit of an alcohol finish.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2011 355mL 2008 ed. Pours a motoroil black with a cappuccino head. Insane lacing. Aromas of molasses, dark chocolate, salt water, and loads of chocolate malt. Taste is lots of coffee, unsweetened chocolate, roasted malt, espresso. Ends with a sour, tart, acidic taste. Thick bodied. Oily mouthfeel. 12/9/2008 7/5/8/4/16=4.0 355mL 2010 ed. Pours near jet black with a healthy mocha brown head that sticks around for a little. Not much lace. Aroma is very rich and full impending of what may be a sweet stout: big milk chocolate, licorice, peat, barbecue, soft warming alcohol, smoke meat. Taste up front is heavy on black cherries and milk chocolate. Palate unfortunately is just massively chalky and papery/cardboardy. Unbelievably tannic. Really just terrible palate. Hopefully this is a bad bottle and I can re-rate soon. 1/18/2011 8/4/6/2/14=3.4

This thing has the appearance of a good imperial stout. I was very impressed. Opaque, and a nice thin chocolate colored head sitting on top. Whoa, this made my Saturday night, forget the ladies, right guys!? This beer is too one sided for me. It is all about the roast. I don’t think the description is misleading. I am actually glad that I didn’t pay for a 6-pack and found this in a mix-a-six section of Green’s. The beer has a weak aroma of roast. It also has some sweet aroma, but not much. I am not impressed because this thing is not that pungent to me. I am not sick, so it is not my nostrils.  I can say this is a nice creamy beer. The alcohol really comes out with the roast which is a nice combo. I like this roast taste. I just think it is too one sided. There is some slight coffee, and chocolate taste, but the damn roast is taking over my life at this moment. The sweet flavor really comes out at first, but the other flavors quickly kick in. Overall, I think the beer is nice, but just focuses too heavily on the roast. As for a "sipping beer" I don’t know I need something a little more harsh to stop. I would say that for a Baltic Porter, and I have only had 2, this was the better one.

12oz bottle. deep dark black color with a small dark tan head. wow. huge aroma of dark chocolate and coffee. taste is silky smooth and full,  big chocolate and roast. this is delicious. almost too sweet at first with just a taste of alcohol in the finish that comes out as it warms. great sipper on a cold winter night. gift from my daughter home for the holiday.
Pours dark black with minimal head.  Aromas of chocolate and molasses.  Thick and full bodied.  Smooth finish with hint of alcohol, excellent as typical of duck-rabbit seasonals.

viscous pour.  opaque black with little lacing under a small creamy brown head.  chocolate, graham cracker, molasses aroma.  flavors of chocolate, molasses, and licorice.  full bodied.  alcohol is well hidden.

Bottle 355ml. @ home.[ Courtesy of Secret Santa ]. Clear dark dakr brown color with a large, creamy - frothy, good lacing, fully - mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, chocolate, date fruity, vanilla. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and heavy bitter with a long duration. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light to moderate alcoholic. (010908)

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2016 GABF 2008. Near-black brown, thin brown skim. Complex aromas and flavours, with earthy coffee bean, woodsmoke, cigar box, vanilla all playing across the palate. Burnt malt, vegemite, prunes, and black cherries. Heavy oily mouthfeel, liquid velvet. Interesting acidic tartness in the finish. Truly marvellous complexity! This required several samples.
Bottle re-rate 2016: not as over-the-top as I remember. Still very delicious.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle.  Poured a dark brown/black with a small tan head.  Aroma of smoke, roasted malt and coffee.  Flavor of chocolate, cherries and alcohol, with a smoke finish.  Great beer!

Bottle from suttree.  Thanks!Pours like a liquified dark Baltic night with an olive green head.  Aroma is a rush of chocolate coffee cocoa milk with roasted nut creme added.  Wow!  Total assault of roasted chocolate cocoa powder, cherry, and alcohol with hint of smoke in the finish with every sip.  Perfect texture that leaves the battered palate screaming for more abuse.  Absoluely delicious; lives up to and jumps over the hype.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Thanks to BMan1113VR for giving me this bottle. Pours a thick dark black brown color with a medium sized light brown head. Very thick pour. Nose is mostly beef jerky and some sweet berries, slightly smokey, just tasty. Taste: red fruit, meaty teriyaki, sesame seeds, smoke, just thick and chewy. A delicious beer.

Thanks to Hank1980 for the bottle!Pours black, bubbly tan head. Nose is smoke and salt, with fruit and lots of roasted malt, some minor chocolate. Alcohol is more noticeable in the flavor, as is the fruit, which is nicely balanced by the coffee. Decent body, oily and a little clinging. Good stuff here, if a little straightforward.

Courtesy of cigarcitybrew.
Pours black, off-white head.
Aroma is fruity (raisin), grainy, some nice caramel notes.
Taste, alcohol is noticable. Some roastiness, cofee and grains, add some nice chocolate malts in the mix and this is one fine Baltic Porter.

huge black pour, big billowy mocha head. Aroma is big on chocolate, coffee sweet roasted malt, alcohol, and some licorice. Flavour is big on the chocolate also, with a tinge of alcohol, the finish is bitter and chocolatey, wth some great licorice notes that linger in the end. very very nice, but i would consider this more of an impy stout than a porter, but holy hell this is delicious.

Black with medium head. Nice roasted malt with lots of dark fruit. Finish is quite sour and a bit metallic to boot. I’d usually write this off as a bad bottle, but this is the second time I’ve tried this beer and have had similar experiences. It’s almost like the dark fruit went a bit too sour....

Thanks to Jeff for this one. Pours very dark brown with a thin khaki head. Sweet malt nose, dark fruits, cherry, chocolate. Heavy and sweet on the palate, faint burnt chocolate character, but not overly roasty, just kinda sits in the background. Flavor picks up a chocolate dipped cherry sweetness with a lingering bitter finish. Small hints of sweet tobacco show as you breath out. Bold and very complex, but still very drinkable.

On tap. Pours almost completely opaque black with a small tan head that shows good retention and a little lacing.

Dominant smells are roasted chocolate malts with a bit of burnt coffee and some dark fruits.  Some licorice and vanilla sweet in the background as well.

The taste is a drier, hoppier version of the smell.  There is still the big roasted malt character up front with some sweetness of vanilla and dark fruits.  But its the finish that really stands out with the hops leaving a dry espresso bitterness into the aftertaste.
Mouthfeel is creamy and smooth with a bit drier character than most baltic porters I have tasted.  Not a lot of carbonation in this one.

This is my favorite Duck-Rabbit brew and is a great Baltic porter all the way around.  Highly recommended!

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2008 Damn this is one fine beer...wow one of the best porters I have ever, ever had.  Black ass pour wtih a quick fading brown head.  Aromas of molasses, soy, chocolate, coffee, syrup, candi sugar and deep malts hit the tongue. Flavor is sweet, thick, rich, syrupy...full of molasses, chocolate, and dark sweet dried fruit.  Simply a world class porter and I  need more ASAP!

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2016 Bottle via mcbackus on his way to 100 trades.  Better than ever imagined.  Pours cola black with nice carbonation and a tan ring around the edges.  Huge syrupy aroma of chocolate, molasses and roasted malt.  Silky mouthfeel. Strong flavor with candied fruit, raisins and currants.  Sticks to your ribs.

Thanks to wagenvolks for the bottle!  Poured into a snifter.  Black with slight brown highlights.  Minute brown head that fades almost immediately and leaves no lacing.

Aroma is rich boozy chocolate with soy sauce, molasses, and sweet cream.

Flavor is considerably more complex than the aroma.  Sweet chocolate graham cracker up front, with accents of licorice and molasses that carry it to a beautiful finish with just the right amount of roast.  Perfect balance of sweet and roasted/bitter.  A little smokiness and a subtle booziness.

Medium-full body with lowish carbonation.  Very chewy and a little sticky.  Finish is long and fulfilling.  Great beer.

12oz. bottle Thanks to OldStyleCubFan, my summer santa. My first try at a baltic porter, really enjoyed it too. Pours opaque black with a thick light brown head that slowly fades over the course of consumption. Mocha, roasted malt, dark cherry and red wine in the nose. Pleasantly sweet and malty. Flavor has notes of dark chocolate, sweet caramel, cherry, dark fruit/figs, molasses, red wine, some bitter roastiness and lactic sourness at the end. Nice creamy body. Enjoyable, another one OSCF send me that nearly tops my list. Thanks Santa!

Dark brown with no head but good lacing.  the aroma was fruity: smelling of dates and cherries with hints of tar, yeast, licorice and chocolate.  Bitter throughout.  Medium-full bodied with a syrupy texture.  A very good beer, but not quite my style.

The aroma of the beer is amazing - smells like tropical fruit with a hint of dark pitted fruits (plums, raisins). One can also smell hints of tar and RED, yes i do mean RED licorice. It is a bit yeasty to the nose as well. 
It pours with virtually no head and the body hue is dark brown. The initial flavor is lightly sweet, but heavily yeasty. The finish is a bit salty. All in all though, the beer goes down smooth. 
The body feels medium to full on the palate, and the texture is syrupy. The carbonation is soft. I really enjoyed this beer! A great ending to a great night!

Bottle thanks to ucusty. Pours thick, with a small, off-white head. Very dark brown body. Aroma of dark fruits, tar, liccorice, cherry, yeast and chocolate. Taste is yeasty, with some initial soy sauce, then chocolate, butter scotch, some oxidation as well. Syrupy with light bubbles.

12oz Bottle. Berry heavy roast aroma, combining with clean alcohols, rich brandy-like complexity and all around malty delight. Pours deep black, with a blackberry liquor corner and a rim in deep tan. Flavor develops deeply. This is rather remarkable. The qualities of this beer are rather diffuse. Its got fantastic roast character, great alcohol nuances, good caramel maltiness, and a crispness that keeps it lively. Fruitiness rises from the roast, alcohol or lagering. Although, the yeast product profile seems more ale-like, which might make this unusually complex. Palate is bright, crisp, dry and balanced. Nice beer. Its got some of the quite complexity that demands a more deft palate to completely appreciate, but the roast character melds with alcohol and fruit so well to make this stunning at any level. Thanks for sharing Piper!

Thanks Santa! Very dark brown/black opaque, head foamed up full but dissipated quickly. Huge rich roasty aroma with some dark chocolate, and a chocolate milkiness. Flavor is also heavily roasted, full soft velvety with a dark bittersweet chocolate finish. Rockin!
Bottle.  Pours a black beer with a brown head.  Sweet chocolate roasty smoked malt.    Nice etoh soft mouthfeel.  Very good.

Black with a good tan head.  Nice roasty & earthy flavors.  Slight alcohol at the finish, but not too much.  Not sure if I like it more than their regular porter, but it’s close.  Can’t drink quite as many of them as the standard.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Sample via piscator- been wanting to try this for awhile- thanks Kris!  Pours very dark, little head or lacing. Nose- powerful nose with many flavours hitting the nose- spice and plums , smoke and roast.  Taste- full bodied and vinous.  Little bit boozy in a good way.  Black licorce, oak and roasty malts.  Smooth drinkiing that coats the mouth on the way down.  nice stuff

Poured from a 12 oz bottle. Almost black with a tall dark brown head. Aormas of smoke chocolate. Taste of cholate and roasted malts that begins somewhat sweet but turns to an acid/sour taste. Strong alcohol burn. Somewhat disapointing, but willing to give it a second chance at a later time.

Poured a very dark brown almost black color. Aroma was mainly of roasted malts and coffee. Flavor was very smooth chocolate/malt flavor with a linger alcohol tinge. Good. But not as great as expectations.

bottle thanks to turdferguson.  pitch black pour with a thin caramel colored head that dissipates rather quickly.  thick roasted malts and chocolate on the nose with a very slight alcohol background.  not as thick as i was expecting but still a very nice mouthfeel.  big chocolate flavors in the front that turn into a nice dark chocolate almost fruity flavor finish.

bottle.  (notes)  Pours a scary dark thick brown with a big head of dark tan foam that clears away pretty quick.  Smells of alcohol, dark toffee, and heavy, bitter roasted malts.  Tastes of dark fruits, raisins, mild bitterness, a great toasty malty flavor.  Very non-aggressive and smooth.  Well balanced, flavors filling out more as it warms.  Very smooth and even on the palate with medium carbonation.  Very enjoyable and unique porter.

Bottle. Huge roasted malt aroma. Additional aromas of licorice, chicory & light tobacco smokiness. Pours a deep dark brown with very slight tan head. Taste is molasses sweet with licorice, heavy roastiness, caramel. Some bitterness lingers on the palate well after indulging. Overall nice beer

Bottled sample via radiomgb, shared with oakbluff. Black in colour with low to moderate carbonation. Aromas of vanilla and chocolate fudge, along with red berry fruit, licorice, and a bit of booze. More vanilla, chocolate, and red fruit in the mouth, along with molassas, caramel, and a bit of pink pencil eraser. Medium to heavy in terms of body, with a slightly acidic finish. Very nice.

Big thanks for OldStyleCubFan for this one!!  Pours dark black with a wonderful aroma of cocoa, coffee, and licorice.  taste starts out with a heavy coffee flavor, and has notes of smoke, wood, dark fruits, and licorice.  Finishes both bitter and smoooth.  Very thick mouthfeel.  Medium-high carbonation.  Big, impressive beer.

Bottle:  Jet black pour with a tan halo of a head.  Big espresso notes come strong from the get-go...notes of chocolate, vanilla, dark fruits and a smokey/woodsy tone present as well.  This is really quite intense on the nose in a wonderful way.  Nice body to this, starts of silky and slowly thins out a bit and allows the full range of flavors to shine through.  Though somewhat boozy, this is massive in terms of overall flavor...notes of mocha espresso, black cherries and dark malts.
Wonderful stuff.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with hellbilly.  Pours black with a very thin brown head that completely disappeared after the first sip and left no lace.  Pleasant aroma of malt and chocolate, a bit subdued actually.  Thankfully this beer is more flavorful than the aroma suggests with lots of malt, molasses, and some dates as well.  Very boozey in the aftertaste with a bit of a burn.  Good stuff.

Pour was dark brown with a quickly dissipating head and no lacing.  Weak aroma of sour milk and chocolate.  The flavor was right hook to the jaw...bold presence of chocolate, some bitter coffee notes, some mild lactic presence and a huge boozy alcohol burn.  This beer is definitely bold and aggressive, but it almost left me feeling like they were trying a bit hard and the beer was bordering on a mess of flavor.  Thanks to eaglefan538 for the bottle!

Bottle from kp. Thanks Keith! Pours yellowish black with little head. Sweet aroma that smells a lot like coffee syrup (or whatever that stuff I experienced in Rhode Island was called). Some grain, coconut and tobacco notes also in the aroma. The aroma is much more complex than the taste, and is the kind of aroma you want to just sit there and take in. Taste is sweet-bitter in that order. Starts off with sweet maple, chocolate and coffee notes and moves quickly into coffee ground bitterness. Decently balanced. Alcohol is very warming.
a nice smoky baltic porter.....I think it is darn good...but lacking a bit in total complexity....ehhhhh not worth trading for in my opinion

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2009 12 oz. bottle - pours jet black and big chocolate colored head that fades quickly; creamy layer along the edges and minor lacing; aromas more robust than expected and not of the standard baltic porter; thin body and strong flavors of chocolate and roasted nuts; alcohol is obvious and overall a very stout-ish beer; sweet finish and overall not that impressed; got a few of these in trades, so will be nice to revisit
Updated Rating 11/27/09: sampled this again a while back (10-08 bottle); thin, black and flat; sweet and roasty with lots of candy; super dry and thin body; way too sweet for me; after several times sampled, id say this is similar to the bourbon county stout for me as a beer i just dont see what the fuss is all about

This is an awesome looking brew poured into a tulip glass. 

Dark, dark, dark. No light whatsoever escapes. A rich, cocoa colored head slowly builds as I pour this. I end up with about a half inch thick of creamy, milkshake like foam, which slowly settles and leaves a ring around the edges. As I swirl the beer, tiny bits of foam stick to the glass, and you can see the legs slowly slip down the side of the glass. Very impressive!! 

Aroma is fantastic. Espresso, toffee, chocolate milk, slightly alcoholic, a bit of fruitiness, almost like a dark chocolate covered cherry cordial. 

The taste doesnt disappoint. Milk chocolate, cappucino, slightly bitter from alcohol and coffee flavors. 

Rich, smooth, velvety mouthfeel, with a definite alcohol burn. Lingering bitter aftertaste leaving you with a nice warmth all the way down. 

Overall this beer completely lived up to my high expectations. A bit rich for more than one at a time, but slow down and savor this one. Delicious. Dont pass it by if you see it on the shelves

sampled at DLD - Pours black with a thin tan head.  The aroma is of dark roast malt, chocolate, and some dark fruits.  It has a robust flavor with, for the style, a surprising amount of dark fruit flavors to go with the roast malt and coffee.  Its sweet, full bodied, and finishes dry.  This beer is really excellent.  More please.  Now please.

Thanks to Eclectic for this bottle. Pours out black with a moderate brown head. Aroma of chocolate, sweet fruits and slight alcohol. Taste is very complex with a nice full mouthfeel. Notes of dark fruits, namely black cherries, some chocolate ands a nice smooth warming finish. A top notch brew.

A gift from my parents from Asheville: Poured a very dark opaque black colour with large brown head. Thick, creamy, chocolatey, intense coffe flavors. Like the darkest of the dark roast. Aroma is strong of roatsed malts and alcohol. Toffee, nuts and thick carmel. Excellent beer, hope i can get my hands on this again sometime soon.

12oz bottle. Pours black with brown highlights, very small light brown head, specks of lace. Smells sweet and dark fruity with a hint of sweet chocolate. Tastes of sweet, dark fruits, slightly toasty malts and maybe a little chocolate. Lingering flavors of toasty malts. Pretty thick body, moderate carbonation. Pretty damn good.

Bottle courtesy Durhambeer. Pours thick black with a thin tan head. Sweet chocolate, roasted grains, and hop aroma. Taste is thick roasted grain, sweet malt, cognac and a hint of cherry. Finishes thick and chocolaty. Just an outstanding baltic porter that works as an after dinner drink or just a great sipping beer.

Bottle courtesy of Hellybilly...Thanks!!!  Im a bit surprised by the mixed reviews here.  Rich deep brown color with 1/4 inch cola head, this beer invites you with roasted Columbian coffee beans and sweet belgian chocolate.  Sweeter than most, but still complex because of its molasses characteristics.  Creamy texture that coats and soothes.  A very good beer.

Black with a thin brown head.  Roasted malts and chocolate aroma.  Flavor had more roasted goodness, brown sugar,  slight coffee,  chocolate, molasses. Finishes a bit chalky,   like most DR beers Ive tried.

A Mes rate: Bottle at Toms UGT Pt. 2.Deep dark brown with a thin beige rim. Sickly sweet with cloying plasticy caramel. Heavy roasted chocolate and just way too sweet for me. I wanted to like this I really did but it just did very little for me.

12oz Bottle - Gravity Beer Market, Olympia, WA 
Aroma  Huge Porter aroma.  This was tick with dark malts in the nose.  Great Aroma.   
Appearance  Dark Brown in color, Nice head and clear. 
Flavor  Great Porter flavor, Had some sweet coffee in the beer.  This was thick and wonderful.   
Palate  Nice Mouthfeel, great texture with a good dry finish. 
Overall  One of the best Porter I have ever had and I love these beers. Had flavor t give and did not come across huge was a subtle beer for the late night last drink of the night beer.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Bottle, courtesy tronraner. Pours a deep black, with brownish highlights. A dark reddish brown head. Decent lacing. Aromas of rich roasted malts, vanilla, licorice, chocolate, dark candy, and brown sugar. Delightful. Roasted coffee flavors; very malty. Vanilla, caramel, brown sugar, molasses, raisin...a symphony of flavors. Rich, smooth, warming. Very easy to drink at 9%. Texture is chalky and requires full appreciation. Simply sublime.

Thanks for the bottle, Duane, good until August of 2008. The body is perfect black with an orangeish brown head. The aroma is strong coffee with some anise hints and molasses. The taste has some very sweet molasses. There is also some light coffee and a tart cherry finish. This has a boozy finish with an overall smooth body. Nice smelling, but the tartness really did not balance well with the rest of the beer. Some friends that know their stuff tell me that the tart finish comes from molasses that has gone bad. Maybe this one is better when fresh.

Bottle at DP 4 ME weekend of t-shirt banter tasting. Alround rating: Roasty, chocolate, fruity, alcohol, rum soaked plums, acidic and oxidised dark fruits. This is more like how a roasty beer should taste.
Bottle at Magic_dave6s disco dance tasting. Black ruby, thin beige head. Rubbery with malt, chocolate malt. Mouth is fruity, molasses, salty, malty. Finishes burnt salty malts. Good.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2010 Bottle at Toms Glasgow tasting 2 ... march 08 ... Deep black ... yeast roast malt little meaty ... vine fruits again lots of meaty ...lots of roast ... little tart 3.8.... bottle at fin april 10 ... black ... thin tan head ... roast malt ... little coffee ... little sourness in the nose ... vine fruits and dark malts ... litttle chocolate ... little red wine 3.7

12 oz, pours dark with very thick tan head. Smooth mouthfeel with nice hints of roasted malts and licorice. Nice chocolate after taste keeps you coming bak for more.  A real nice treat, thanks fiver29.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2008 Bottle from Ucusty pours black with a thick tan head.  Smells like alcohol, roasted malts, and licorice.  Tastes like licorice and a complex array of malts.  Finish is smooth and silky.  Very tasty.

Bottle. As sweet as this baltic porter is, it is not cloying  balanced by roasted malts and licorice. Opaque brown pour with a frothy, but short, head that diminishes quickly. The enticing aroma is sweet with molasses and caramel. There are strong notes of roasted malts and licorice and hints of sweet chocolate and plums. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet and lightly bitter. Dry, bitter finish. Medium body and watery texture with a middle-of-the-road carbonation. The body was less full than expected and perhaps that is one of the reasons this seems like a dangerous drinker  clean throughout. Very nice, indeed.

12oz bottle: Pours deep brown, nearly black with a swirly tan head.  The nose is sharp with lots of sweet chocolate and sugary raisins.  Notes of plums and cherries as well.  The body isnt as chewy as expected, I am assuming to the lagering.  Bitter chocolate and cherry juice are upfront, with a second surge of fudgey chocolate, vanilla, coffee and nuts.  Finishes really sweet, almost cane sugar sweet.  Interesting and complex.

Poured from a 120z bottle and is a dark amber black with a small tannish whie head that leaves a sticky ring at the top of the glass. 

Very malty roasted aroma with some chocolate notes as expected. 

Chocolate notes are strong upon first taste and have some raisin/fruitiness that comes through in the roasted malts. Very rich but smooth. 

Not too overwhelming and has a nice body. The finish is nice and not too strong considering the 9% ABV. Unfortunately this isnt a session beer for me also because of the alcohol. 

Id like to try more of this if I can and enjoy this baltic porter style so I was quite happy with this beer and look forward to other Duck-Rabbit offerings.

12 oz bottle from ucusty, thanks Dave. Pours a pitch black with a small tight coccoa colored head. I was expecting your run of the mill burnt roasted aroma but was nicely suprised with lots of sweetness. Aroma of dark fruit, fresh tobacco, rum and chocolate coverd cherry liquour candy. Oily slick body with very light carbonation. Flavor is sweet like the aroma with lots of cherry, chocolate and tobacco. Once again the Duck-Rabbit is quacktastic.

From a 12-oz. bottle--Poured a thin black body with a small almost non-existent head.  Briny, sweet, and slightly metallic.  Very bright and somewhat true to style.  Quite interesting, though I think the hype let me down a little.  This beer still ruled!

Bottle from DMRz, thanks!!!  Mahogony in color this poured almost no head and what it did faded quickly.  There were aromas of chocolate, black licorice, fig, rock candy and roasted malts.  In the mouth it was concentrated with nice acidity running throughout and flavors of chocolate, fig and smoke lingering at the end.  Very balanced this was quite engaging right from the start.

bottle.  outstanding... it actually borderlines on being an impy stout... dark as night... little head.  aromas of liquorice, chocolate and roasted malts.  great palate.... the alcohol and liquorice hits the front of the tongue, while the sides are soft with chocolate and malts...  nice strong finish... great beer!

Bottle courtesy of drewbeerme.  I drank this one at close to room temp.   Will try again cooled and may re-rate if waranted.  Pours black with a minimal tan head.  Nose is coffee, roasty malts, and dark chocolate. Palate  has fruity aspects like a Belgian, with roasted malt, milk chocolate and caramel.  Creamy mouth feel  with a dry, slightly bitter aftertaste.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2008 Bottle courtesy of drewbeerme -- thank!

Pours a dark black, coarse tan head. Big tar and chocolate aroma, some vinous notes; flavors of chocolate, tobacco, teriyaki, spice, (off-tasting) raisins. Unfortunately this one is marred by the sour milk that kp and others have noted.

Nice mouthfeel, but theres a mix of spice and sour milk on the finish that leaves me rather tired of the beer before my glass is empty. Something of a letdown.

Bottle thanks to alexsdad06.  Almost black pour with very small brown head.  Roasted malt with notes of chocolate.  Flavor is of dried figs, with some chocolate and hints of coffee.  Very smooth texture with a dry finish.

Black pour, small brown head. Flavor is pretty sugary sweet with lots of dark chocolate, licorice and caramel. Roasted malt and some coffee in the finish. Still very sweet lots of sugar in this one with a semi hoppy aftertaste. Medium bodied with a cloying sweetness. Not bad but not up to the hype.

12 oz. 06 bottle.  Pours opaque blackish-brown, with reddish highlights and a modest, easily rejuvenated, finely carbonated brown head.  Sweet aroma includes dark chocolate, brown sugar, licorice, figs and a touch of smoke.  Flavor is dominated by soft cocoa, deeply roasted malt, dark fruit tang, and some sourness. Nicely balanced bitterness with a long dry finish featuring more chocolate and smoke.  Smooth and a bit chalky, with a full body and moderate carbonation.  Alcohol very well tempered.  Great, big beer...I think its all been said here.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2008 07 Bottle shared by Crosling, but thanks to DragonStout for sending me one I can keep.  Way different than I expected, and honestly, much better than I expected also.  Poured a deep brown color with a thin tan head that diminished to a ring.  Aroma of chocolate and roasted malts along with a sweet fruitiness peaking through also.  Flavor of roasted malts with light chocolate that is offset by a slightly tangy flavor, with undertones of sweet fruit that leads into a lightly smoky, dry, chewy finish.  Slick and full on the palate.  No alcohol is apparent.  Good beer, thanks for sharing Nick.

Thanks to emacgee for the bottle.  I guess Im in the minority on this one.  It has a nice aroma, kind of like plum and tobacco, the tan colored head dissipated really fast.  I really am not digging the taste of this one.  The alcohol comes on very strong and tastes like leather wrapped in licorice.  The mouthfeel is decent with good carbonation, but the finish is very dry, kind of like a merlot.  I dont think Id try this one again.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2008 12 oz. bottle courtesy of Zinister.  2007 vintage. Pour is deep black with a 1/2 inch deep tan head. Head fades quickly to just a small swirl on top of the glass. Aroma of roasted malt, tobacco and some old worn leather.  Taste is a really nice blend of the roasted malt with smoke and tobacco. Some licorice and soy in the taste as well. Really quite a bit going on in this one. The finish has the acidic bite that I love in an Imperial / Baltic porter.  Nice full palate.  Integrates the alcohol really well.  I had been a bit underwhelmed by the regular Duck Rabbit line up, but this is really good.  Thanks for holding one of these back for me Mike.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2008 Dark, dark pour with thin, brown, and very temporary bubbly head.  Creamy, sweet, malty aroma. Tastes of malty sweetness at first backed by bitter burnt cocoa, hints of chicory and anise.  Also hints of chocolate covered cherries?  Some sourness at the end.  Great balance of bitter and sweet.  Long finish.

Havent had other baltic porters, and it took me a few to get used to it, in part because the thin palate surprised me. Im told this is true to style. This was a very  complex and challenging beer for me, and I encourage haters to be patient and perhaps try again.  I was won over...

Re-rate: trying a fresh &#40;two-week old?&#41; bottle now, and its so rewarding.  Fuller, more creamy mouthfeel than last time I tried.  Every bit as complex as before.  I like this beer better every time I try it.  I bought two sixers thinkng I might trade one of them... I think I just might drink these myself...

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2009 Pours black, with a creamy brown head. After the head settles, the beer itself looks marble! Minimal lacing, and it gives off an amber hue. Aroma is coffee, cream, and licorice in a very nice combination. Flavor is just as complex: chocolate, toffee, slight coffee. Tastes almost like candy, but is never sticky or too sweet, it really strikes the perfect balance. Warms you up as you drink, and gives a slight coffee aftertaste. This one lives up to the hype, and I cant wait to try more of Duck-Rabbits offerings!

I dont see the hype around this! It taste like  bacon grease or pork rinds...Unless I had a funky bottle or something? Strong alcohol presence on the palette. Funky finish and an annoying cloying aftertaste of well for lack of better words bacon grease..I was somewhat disappointed by this one after it being rated 100...I had one and dont care to try it again..even from me . a huge porter and stout fan...this one just doesnt do it..
Pours black with brown highlights with very little brown head.  Aroma of smoke, burnt and sweet  malts.  Taste is the same with some bitter chocolate hitting the middle pallete.  Dry finish.

Bottle courtesy of cbkschubert.

Pours a deep black with a thin head that quickly disappears. Aroma of malt, chocolate, and maybe a touch of fruit. Taste is very good, with Chocolate, rasins, smoke,   molasses and a slightly sour taste that is balanced by the sweetness. 9%.......Id never expect this beer to be so strong wow! Very good baltic porter, and a very good overall beer.

When I take a whiff of this beer, I get a nose full of sweet smelling malts.  It makes me want an Oreo cookie really badly, because I can imagine instantly from the smell that the cream and chocolate flavors would compliment this beer very well.  It poured very black with a good bit of tan head.  The flavor was like burnt chocolate chip cookie dough without the chocolate chips.  It has a strangely comforting taste, like a middle school home ec project gone wrong, turned into a slick, tasty beer.  I really enjoyed this beer and it just makes me giddy...maybe its just the high abv...

UPDATED: APR 27, 2009 bottle 2007 courtesy of ucusty... almost viscous dark brown pour topped by a small brown head with purple and orange tints. the head fades quickly to a thin film. the aroma is fruity, sour, chocolate, wood, coffee, licorice, malt powder, something meaty and a bunch of sweetness. alcohol jumps out and singes my nose. the flavor is all sugar and alcohol... not cloying but enough to hide the nuances. along with all the sugar theres also hints of chocolate, smoke, dark raisins, vanilla and a huge dose of unpleasant sourness. it finishes surprisingly dry and leaves behind a fruity coffee/astringent aftertaste. medium bodied with a light mouth feel from the high level of carbonation. 7/4/7/3/16=3.7



2006 bottle by way of kenb... thick brown pour with a brownish orange head which fades to nothing rapidly. licorice and malt powder dominate the nose. sweetness and chocolate aromas play a secondary role. the licorice really becomes noticeable as does a molasses note. the unpleasant sourness has faded a bit but it still makes itself known. nice dry finish with chocolate in the aftertaste. this is notably smoother than the fresh bottle but im not sure how since theres nothing in the bottle. its had a chance to mesh and settle down?7/4/8/4/16=3.9

Pours coffee black with a decent head that reduces rather rapidly to a thin ring of lace. Aromas are powerful with chocolate and roasted espresso. Full nectar with very lively effers that create an almost creamy texture. It has the consistantcy of chocolate milk. Chocolate malted sweetness followed by a moderate roast component. Some leather, molases, and tar can be spotted in the distance. The finish is long with sweet coffee and a touch of sour. Overall: this brew is thick and very rich. It coats the palate and sticks like glue.Decent balance. The only thing that bothers me is a faint rootbeer essence.

Courtesy of Degarth. Pours deep dark with dark brown edges and tan foam ring of foam. The aroma is a bit of roasty malts, bigger burnt malts follow shortly after along with chocolate malts, coffee grounds and a mild earthiness. Really nice aroma but missing the dark fruity esters that are a typical contributor to the Baltic Porter style. The taste is thick and rich and velvety. I get roasty malts, burnt malts, coffee and chocolate malts that seem very much like an Imperial Stout. There is a sweetness that runs underneath all the roasty malt notes. Very enjoyable but misses the style in flavor and aroma.

Sample Hotshots Feb Indy tasting - Aroma is roasted chocolate malts, smoke and a real earthy peat smell that blends in with some vanilla.  Pours black with red highlights, a ring head and not much lacing.  Flavor is intense (and I have had a lot of samples by this time), strong and burley.  Chocolate, some coffee bitterness, black licorice, vanilla extract, prune and smoke.  Palate is mouth wateringly sticky.  Wow, this beer is not for the weak of heart.  I like it!

This beer is slightly over hyped, personally I think there are better examples of the style.  Still having said that it is still a very delicious beer, but having said that as well, I could only drink one.  I thought that it was very fresh tasting, very clean chocolate flavors, with an annoying hop bitterness.  Grainey, albeit chewy mouthfeel, with some dark fruits and licorice rounding out the flavor.

Bottled.  Thanks to Justin for adding this to the 2/9/08 sesh.  Bomb!  Dark chocolatey licorice with a unique dash of something hard to describer - "hay and a harvest full of toasty biscuits"?  Hard for me to put a finger on - but it was awesome.  All this surrounded by an earthy green jacket.  Really an eye opening aroma.  Flavor was a notch below the marvelous nose - succulent smokey chocolate and a hint of sweet vanilla.  Mouth was smooth but lacking a load of stick that I like - pleasant.  Definitely a stand up brew and worthy of its spot.  Regarding the numbers, I right there with you hapjy...whats new huh?

Bottled, Beer #3 in the evening of epic tastings with jarspag on the 2/9 Death Metal. Pitch black, velvety pour with transparent maroon edges and some reddish bubbles and surface swirls. The aroma is fantastic! Chocked full of licorice, toasted biscuit, anise, black cherry and chocolate liqueur. Some floral hops are noticeable as well. The flavor is a complex blend of sweet dark fruits, roasted chocolate malts with an espresso undertone. Some tangy citrus makes a statement in the finish, with more lingering sweet liqueurs and burnt wood. The palate is chewy and soft, with a good bitterness and a touch of acidity. Nice!

Courtesy of Degarth. Dark brown or black pour, I cant tell which, but its completely opaque. Dark brown head that is about 2 fingers thick comes to the top and stays a while. Nice retention and some sheet lacing. Finally resolves to a ringing of foam that never leaves. Nose of coffee, huge roasted malts, chocolate - Belgian and milk and then really more coffee/roasted notes. Doesnt smell like a Baltic Porter to me at all. Really missing any of the fruity notes that that style usually features. Flavor is very similar, this tastes like an Imperial Porter, and probably would be if RB had such a style. Tons of chocolate and sweet dark malts, but also a huge amount of roastiness and coffee grounds. Alcohol is very well hidden in both the aroma and the flavor profile, I wouldnt have guessed this was 9%, probably more like 7%. Chewy, full bodied, sweet palate. Finish is incredibly long, milk and dark chocolate, coffee grounds and beans, roasty malts throughout. Great beer.

Pours black with a fine, moderate, tan head. Aroma is very soy sauce like, with some minor metallic qualities. Very smoky flavor. pretty heavy mouth feel. Clingy smokiness at the end. Rather warm beer. 

2006 Vintage, thanks to radiomgb!

Thanks Harry. Couldnt believe I got to have this. Black, black, black with a creamy, coffee, malt-spice aroma. Bitter-chocolate cream flavour with a sour finish, so much is going on here, but incredibly balanced. Fantastic wonderful cream notes in the finish too. Magic

Not really what I was expecting, not being very familiar with the baltic porter style.  Definitely malty, sweet, and a bit fruity.  Very good brew once I wrapped my head around it.  I will probably get this again to give it more attention.

Thanks MuenchenerKindl for the opportunity to sample this one 
12 oz poured into the Duvel tulip produced a finger of tan head on top of a jet black body. The head subsides to a beautiful lace and a nice film around the glass 

The aromas of sweet malts and roasted coffee as well as some smoke 

Sweet, malt, cream dark fruits and anise very complex flavors a nice balance for your taste buds  

Mouthfeel is full and smooth; yes it could use a little more carbonation  

Great beer to sit, sip and enjoy slowly. Filling so I dont think I do more than one in a sitting but I do want more. First beer I had from Duck Rabbit cant wait to try some more of their brews

Maybe Im not as big of a fan of big dark beers as I once thought.  This is a nice beer for what it is though...  jet black, not much head.  Aroma is roasted malt, with a salty soy sauce character.  Flavor is roasty and salty.  The sweetness is there, but it comes and goes.  Mainly comes on strong and finishes dry.

Thanks for sharing another gem Yaniv!  Dark dark brown black with decent tan head, thinning rather rapidly.  Lightly creamy acidity.  Chocolate.  a bit of floral hops.  Really smooth, truly surprising.  Smooth subdued body with fine bubbles and perhaps a bit of something in it like chalk?  Not bad, just full.  Shallow caramel sweetness with a bit of acidity reigning it in.  A bit of restrained creaminess.  Some roast, alcohol, floral hops.  Rather surprised by the lingering alcohol and associated warming.  Roasty acidity.  This is really more like a sophisticated little imperial stout thinner and more balanced on the sweetness than an even sweeter usual baltic porter.  A nice beer, one to keep an eye peeled for.

12oz bottle from ucusty, thanks D.   Aroma has notes of dried fruits, roast malt, and tangy dark chocolate.  Average sized brown head that mostly disappeared and left little lace.  Very dark brown black hue.  Flavor is a little sour and sweet and finishes slightly roasty and slightly bitter.  Palate is med/full bodied and soft.  Alcohol is there but well hidden.  A very good beer.
A lot like Duck-Rabbits Barleywine, but sweeter, with some dried-fruit and chocolate notes. Alcohol well-disguised. This is some silky-smooth stuff.

Scored a SIX PACK from Total Wine in Huntersville, NC.  Pours a nice dark brown color with a small head.  Aroma is cocoa and some roasted notes.  Taste starts out roasted then is lightly bitter with some cocoa and floral notes.  Wonderful beer.

12 ounce bottle shared with Illini08. Thanks! Poured a dark brown color with a very small head that disappeared quickly. The aroma of this beer was extremely interesting. I was definitely not expecting what I smelled. At first there was an overwhelming smell of floral. As the beer warmed I could sense some chocolate and coffe hints. The taste was also very interesting. Tasted floral with chocolate and coffee hints coming at the end. Left a nice bitter aftertaste in my mouth. This was an awesome experience and I would love to try this one again!

Thanks, Sam! My Duck-Rabbit tour continues. Nice to have a really big American beer with balanced complexity, instead of excessive hops. Bottle pours black with brown head. Nose of bittersweet chocolate, espresso, tinges of smoke and toasted walnuts. Sweetish, roasty flavor, only mild bitterness. Finish and aftertaste uphold that triumvirate nicely. Flat-out delicious.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2008 Trade from illinismitty. Pours dark brown with no head. Nice complex aroma of chocolate and dark fruit. Nice sweetness with enough bitterness at the end to let you know the hops are there. Very nice. Thanks Sean.  Re-rate - Managed to get ahold of some more of this. After trying a couple more bottles, I have to bump it up a little. Re-re-rate - Put some in the basement for a month. Liked it better fresh. It seemed more roasty, more sweet, after it sat for a while.

12 oz bottle from Emacgee.  Almost black in color with a medium tan head.  Aroma: alot of chocolate, light notes of roasty coffee, caramel.  Taste is initially a big blast of chocolate and heavily roasted malt, giving way to caramel sweetness and light fruity esters.  Medium to full bodied with only a hint of alcohol perceived. Some lingering roasted malt bitterness in the finish.

Bottle. Pours black with a tan ring for a head that leaves some lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, dark fruit, caramel, and alcohol. The taste is at first intensly roasty then gives way to sweet malt, caramel, coffee, and warm alcohol. Full mouthfeel with soft carbonation, moderate bitterness, and a bit of dark malt tannin. Very good.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours with no head, looks like thin wine.   Aroma is primarily of alochol with raisin, prunes and chocolate.  Palate is smooth and rounded with good carbonation.  Flavor is full of prune with dark roasted coffee, chocoatle and an awkward sweetness.  Overall, found it poorly balanced and unrefined.

Bottle: Very dark pour with a bubbly tan ring for head. Meaty aroma with tons of mocha roast. Some underlying phenolics are there, and booze notes. The flavor has lots of booze and roast, but its balanced. Some dark chocolate and mocha, and a slightly tart booziness. A solid Baltic Porter.

(thx thebeercellar) jet black pour, not much of a head. A sweet, almost coffee smell, but not quite. A heavyly roasted, oily soy, and tarty choc taste. Medium body with a dry roasted slightly bitter finish. This beer caught be a little of guard, its unique, and not what i was expecting. A good beer!

Fresh winter 2007 vintage.  This brew pours a very dark chocolate brown body.  A small, foamy tan head settles pretty quickly to just a thin rim, leaving behind minimal spotty lacing.  The aroma is intensely malty and rich.  Dark chocolate, roasty caramel, nougat, coffee, and dark fruits all emerge in well transitioned layers.  The nose is really inviting, despite mild alcoholic fumes.  The flavor follows suit, with malt after malt building upon one another.  It tastes like figs steeped in melted dark chocolate, all filtered and added to a roasty, creamy coffee.  Finishes medium long, roasty and bittersweet.  The body is full, smooth, and viscous.  Its almost silky, and perfectly carbonated.  Awesome beer.  Not quite living up to Koff Porter, which is the king of the Baltics in my opinion, but it is damn good nonetheless.
Dark pour with little head.  Very strong smell of alcohol.  Chocolate, coffee, and many other flavors.  Tingley on the tongue and very complex.  A nice warming porter.

Bottle from quagmite.  Thanks, dude! Absolutely killer Baltic.  Man, this thing is amazing.

Jet black with not much of a head.

Smells really dark and rich and has a fairly prevalent alcohol aroma also.  I like it.

Tastes every bit as dark and rich as it smells and the alcohol is evident in the taste as well but it only adds to the flavor of this beer.  Amazingly complex.  I taste everything from chocolate to coffee to Whoppers!  No kidding!

I wish I could get this on a regular basis but it came on a trade from quagmite!  Thanks for this gem!

Pours a very deep, dark brown almost black with a coffee colored head.  Strong malty aroma with lots of chocolate and coffee with hints of tofee, nut and sugar.  Rich, malty flavor with dark chocolate, coffee, toffee, sugar cane, alcohol ad dark fruit.  Very smooth and creamy up front with a warming alcohol snsation in the finish.  Excellent.

Pours a deep, dark, burnt caramel black with a minimal, quickly receding brown head.  Aroma of coffee bitter, burnt toast, yeasty alcohol, and some hints of pit fruit (especially cherry).  Really nice smokey malts, dark roast coffee dominates flavor along with the heavy alcoholic tinge.  Palate is a hilite, very smooth despite strong alcohol.  A really tasty brew.  These guys truly are dark beer specialists.  Alas there is now a barleywine on the market...  If only I lived in eastern nc still.  I feel like I remain one step behinid this fantastic brewery.

Poured a dark mahogany brown / black color with a small, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roast, vanilla, cocoa, floral hoppiness, and smoked malts.  Taste of dry, bitter roast, vanilla, nuts, smoke, cocoa, and alcohol.  The rating is an average of both years, the 07 was hoppier though thinner, while the 06 really came together nicely, was creamier, and not overly hoppy.  Thanks to Tom and Steve for letting me try these!

This is the 06 version just taken out of the cellar.  Balck in color with an attractive chocolate colored head that doesnt hang around for last call.  Roasted and boozy in the aroma but in the best of ways.  Rich roasted malt flavor complemented by some dark fruits and molasses.  What sets this beer apart from others is the rich coffee like finish and the soft velvet like mouthfeel.
This one is worth seeking out.
I finally got this and was not disappointed,a dark rich and roasty porter with a nice smooth finish,alcohol was well hidden and i would try this again if i could get.CHEERS!

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2008 It is about time that I rate this beer, I have been lucky enough to get a few of these in a trade which I am always happy to get this beer so thank you to everybody that sent this to me. Poured dark brown to black with a brown head. aroma a lot of roastyness going on molasses, honey, chocolate, some alcohol, dark fruits. flavor, this didnt let me down the roasted malts brown sugar with a nice bite of alcohol was just what I was expecting, than came some coffee and the dark fruits. I want more

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2008 12 oz from Brawleys.  Pours very dark with a small brown head.  Aroma of roasted malts, fruit, coffee, and chocolate.  Alcohol is lightly present in the aroma.  Taste is of sweet with malt, molasses, chocolate, and coffee.  Alcohol is not present in taste or finish.  Body is medium with minimal carbonation.  Finish is dry.  Very drinkable and nice.

12 oz. bottle from slob.  Pours ebony color, opaque with a moderate reddish brown head that leaves light lacing.  Roasty malts, significant herbal aromas, prunes, coffee, hints fo chocolate and a bit of licorice.  Sweet and rich in the flavor, roasty malts, bitter chocolate, warming alcohol, herbal flavors along with coffee and yeast.  Medium to full body, and light carbonation.
Black of color with a brown head. An aroma of blue sheese, nuts and chocolate. A flavor of chocolate, nuts and notes of dark fruits.

Pours a murky dark brown colour with a small tan head. Nose is earthy, roasted malts mild coffee and copper. Initial taste pours over the palate with a creamy coffee. Smokiness, roasted malts & mollasses make up the background character. Cocoa is also present in the mid palate. Finishing with dark chocolate and mild coffee. Chalky dry finish that leaves your mouth nearly complete parched. Alcohol is well masked. Medium to full body. Palate duration gets cut short with heaping stop from the chalkiness. Good head retention and some lacing of the glass.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2008 Pours like a strong impy with deep brown color and a dark tight bubbled head. Nose is strongly soy. This is my first Baltic Porter, and I dont think its for me if this is one of the best. Taste is dry and heavy, reminiscent of a beef stick. The mouthfeel is pretty good, but overall, I wouldnt go to much trouble to find this one.
DARK DARK DARK! Took me a couple of sips to get used to this beer. Pours oil black, and tastes of a mix of roasted malts and chocolate. Definitily one to just sip on and enjoy!
yummy. dark oily pour. nice lacing. small head. creamy chocolate and roasted coffee with black cherry. oily smooth coating mouthfeel. very tasty. alcohol is present and warming but not overwhelming.

bottle.  Awesome, awesome, awesome.  aromas of chocolates, roasted malts, some hops.  alcohol was extremely well hidden.  finish duration lasted for what seemed like minutes.  Not sure what else to say but this was by far the best beer made by this brewery and one of the best beers.

Thanks to my bro, through Ross, for this one. Pours black with a diminishing mocha head.  Aroma is licorice, blackberry, and a milky chocolate (ie. Nesquick).  Taste is rich with chocolate undertones, malty, molasses, slighly carbonated yet very silky smooth.

(Bottle (best by 6/07) via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=3 target=blank>Ty5592, thanks Ty!, cellared for 9 mos. after trade) Just a freakin treat!...Pours very, very dark brown with a thin brown head that recedes to almost nothing. Rich, pungent aroma of molasses along with some dark brown sugar. Hints of prunes, raisins and licorice dancing around. Wow this smells great!. Mouthfeel is full and thick. Carbonation is low and loose. Very lightly oily. Very light weepy lacing. Flavor is monstrously rich, roasty molasses with some brown sugar, licorice and malty dark fruit elements. No alcohol apparency. Awesome.
Nice nose. Blackest black color. Silky smooth finish and a nice sweet malty backbone. Yummy.
Bottle. Thanks to lb4lb Thanks. Poured a very rich black with a thin tan head. Aroma is coffe, chocolate, and malty. Taste is malty in the face with a coffe finish.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2007 Bottle. [thank you, BierKönig - I know I still have to give you a 95 Chimay Bleu for it :o)
[Vintage 2006]
Poured in my tulip glass. As it pours, it looks deep brown, but as it settles like oil in my glass, it becomes inpenetrably pitch-black. A medium creamy head sits firmly on top with a cappucino hold to it. Great laces as I swirl the beer gently in my glass, anticipating the first whiff, and after that, the first sip! Aroma is oaky, heavily roasted with a great touch of dark chocolate mixing well. The alcohol is evident, but only enhances the deep, dark and powerful aromas. There is some degree of tobacco and port as well. Mouthfeel is light, but still excessively creamy, with a sluggish, mild carbonation - only prickling lightly on my tongue. Wow, what a dense, creamy and mildly stunning degree of chocolate theres in this beer! Coffee, tobacco, warming viniousness. Extremely well-balanced between the bitter, roasted, sweet and vinious tones. Really, really wonderful. And thank you, Jeppe!

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2008 Pours black. Thats about all there is to say about the color, this stuff is dark. Theres a beige head that fades pretty rapidly leaving just a thin ring. The initial aroma of dark, bittersweet chocolate is noticeable as soon as I opened the bottle. The mouth feel is thick and quite smooth. Theres a moderate about of carbonation to tingle the tongue as well. Initially the flavor is that of dark chocolate. The alcohol provides a warming sensation on the way down. The alcohol is well played in this one. It is not overbearing nor unpleasant. As the beer warms, roasted coffee flavors begin to emerge, along with some dark fruit. There are some faint bitter hops detected in the aftertaste, along with roasted coffee.

12oz Bottle

Recieved this long sought after beer from my Secret Santa, thanks again Tayner. Duck-Rabbits Baltic Porter pours as black as the ace of spades. Theres a hint of light peeking through if directly backlit. A one-plus dark brown head rose on the pour but fell rather quickly to a skimming. The head could have stuck around a little longer but besides that its a really good looking porter.

This beer smells big of freshly brewed black coffee. Its the most coffee Ive come across from a porter. Dark chocolate plays a big part in the aroma as well. The maltiness present is some dark doughy bread. The coffee dominates. If you ask me this turns out to be a great combo.

Big coffee upfront fades slightly and combines with the dark chocolate to create a great flavor combination. The doughy malts join the coffee and chocolate mid-palate and while all these flavors work through to the swallow dark fruit makes its appearence. This is one of best, if not the best, Baltic style porters I have ever had. 

Mouthfeel has just the right amount of heft for the heavy flavors. Good viscosity as it coats the tongue with each sip. The carbonation is sluggish and lets the beer works its way through slowly. The alcohol will leave your cheeks feeling a little arm.

This is a perfect beer with which to sip away these cold Winter evenings. This beer is a sipper for sure and the abv wont let you drink too many but Id drink these till I couldnt anymore.

This is my second offering from Duck-Rabbit and one of the best Baltic style porters I have yet to sample. This is a beer not to be missed. If you see it pick some up.

12/16/07

Assertive roast, mild licorice and hint of black cherry, along with easily perceptible alcohol in the nose.Just shy of stout-like obscurity - almost black.  Thin khaki head with good persistance.  Sweet - very lactic (slightly sour) prominant roast character, and noticeable bitterness. Again - Im thinking hint of black cherry - combination of the esters, roast, and hint of sour.  Very complex.  Very silky, full moutfeel.  Velvety - nice.  Overall - a nice brew - Baltic . . . nah, too complex and way too much roast - Baltics are sweet - slightly caramelly malt liquors.  This belongs in the Imperial Robust Porter category.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2008 Bottle. Very dark brown with a light brown head that quickly goes down to a slight brown layer on top of the beer. Big, roasty, sweet nose...chocolate, coffee, and figs. Very involved flavor of caramel, hops, plums, and coffee. Nicely balanced, leaves the mouth feeling quite clean for this complex and strong of a beer. A perfect winter beer that warms you up without much burn. My favorite beer from this great brewery, and perhaps my favorite beer period. I’m rerating after aging some for nearly a year since it improves in depth, balance, and finish with some time behind it.

Bottle, courtesy of alexanderj.  Dark brown pour, thick looking, thin tan head dissipates quickly.  Lots of chocolate in the aroma, roasted and smoked malt, and some lactic acid.  The flavor is both bitter and sweet, mostly chocolate, caramel, coffee, some burnt malt in the finish.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2008 Bottle from ucusty. Dark oil black with a thin brown head. Awesome mix of burnt and roasted malt with some chocolate as well. Some noticeable alcohol as well. Very strong and flavorful with roast, smoke, chocolate, coffee, and some light dried fruit followed by a nice bitterness and pleasant alcoholic notes. Creamy mouth-feel with a dry bitter finish. Fantastic!

Bouteille 12oz, courtoisie de Hogtownharry. De couleur noire-rouge et opaque. Nez fruité (raisins sucrés, traces de prunes), de malt rôti aux petites notes fumées, moyen dalcool, léger de café et légèrement épicé (réglisse noire, notes de cannelle) avec des notes de chocolat noir et de sucre brun. Moyenne-ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture riche, moyennement sirupeuse et crémeuse. Goût très fruité (raisins sucrés aux petites notes vineuses, moyen de cerises noires, notes de prunes et traces de figues) accompagné dun léger goût épicé (léger de réglisse noire, traces de cannelle), des notes de vanille et des traces de crème (petites notes lactiques) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût moyennement amer de malté rôti (notes brûlées et traces de fumée), moyen de chocolat, léger de mélasse et avec des notes de sucre brun et des traces de caramel. Parallèlement, lon retrouve un goût dalcool réchauffant jusquen finale avec un léger goût de café et de houblon herbeux. Post-goût long, moyennement amer de rôti, dalcool, de houblon herbeux, léger de chocolat noir et de café ainsi quun goût fruité (moût de raisins et de cerises).

12 oz bottle from trade with limesmut.  Pours dark brown/black with thin light-brown head which dissipated quickly.  Aroma is smoke and fruit, but alcohol comes through strongly.  Flavor is raisin, smoke and noticeable alcohol.  Mouthfeel is medium and sticky with alcohol burn and dry aftertaste.  Very interesting brew.  Definitely one to sip when on a cold night.

Pours very dark, with ruby edges, and a decent tan head with lacing.  Aroma is chocolate, slight bit of caramel, and cream.  Flavor is similar, with a decent alcohol burn and a lovely malt balance.  A bit of bitterness from the roasted malts.  Very good effort.

Had pretty much all the Duck-Rabbitt beers, and I got to say that this is probably the worst.  I would take the Milk Stout and Russian Imperial over this in a heart beat.  To alcohol heavy taste wise.  Overall the Duck-Rabbitt has a good product, but the best thing about this beer was the cool hat that the duck was wearing.
I will be honest, this is not the kind of beer I usually enjoy.  It is extremely dark and full of licorice, coffee, and raisin flavor.  That said, I really did enjoy it.

Dark black with a tall creamy brown head.  Strong sweet aroma of fruits, raspberry and chocolate.  Flavor is interesting.  A definite roasted bitterness hides behind a strong fruity sweetness up front.  Some cream and chocolate flavors mix in as well.  Delicious.

Pours about as dark as a porter can get, only faint ruby highlights and a thin cocoa brown head which quickly receded to a thin film.  Absolutely enticing nose, very rich raisins with hints of cinnamon and nutmeg spices, dense alcohol fruitiness, very warming even on the nose.  Very syrupy on the tongue, with almost no effervescence.  On the palate the flavor unfolds in a number of directions, starting out treacle before expanding with deep yeasty fruits like plum and currant before melting down into one of the longest finishes Ive ever had, one of rich milk chocolate with hints of spices and yeast.  Hops seem predominantly to add hints to the complexity, but never really come to the front.  The best american baltic porter hands down.

12 oz. bottle from Secret Santa. Pours a jet black with almost no head at all.  Aromas of black coffee, licorce and alcohol assualt the nose. Mouthfeel is thick, heavy and oily. Flavors of soy, dark fruits, brown sugar and alcohol. As advertised, this is a sipping beer. Very warming on the palette and in your tummy. This was BIG beer. I loved it and will leave it on my wants list hoping to get more.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2012 Wow what a difference a few years on the palate makes! A delicious beer. When I get a Baltic porter THIS is what Im looking for! Nice strong malty and licorice aroma. Both of these flavors come into the flavor. Very thick and dark. While I still hate licorice I love the nuances of it in Baltic porters. Nice and bitter in the aftertaste. Fantastic beer. Damn the old me!

Original rating: AR7 AP2 T4 P2 OA8 TS 2.3********************
Allow me to explain...this rating is based on my personal preference. Thanks, Secret Santa for this top rated beer. Aroma was big...slight coffee, dark licorice and alcohol. Pour was a flat black with a tan head that popped up and left. Taste was flat, hot and thick. Strong licorice with hints of chocolate and vanilla. Burnt malt on the tongue and in the aftertaste. The big problem for me is this black licorice taste. Very strong alcohol burn. Once I got the point (as the label says) that it should be sipped slowly, I was convinced not to pour it out. Im not knocking the beer as Im sure if you like these big dark ones, you cant get better.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Black colour with a brown head. Roasted malty aroma with notes of coffee and hints of sweetness from alcohol and vanilla. Roasted malty flavor with fruity and vanilla sweet notes. Light alcohol sweet finish. Complex and balanced.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2010 Bottle shared with, and thanks to Eric. Pours a dark brown with a decent light brown head. The aroma is nutty, burnt malt and smoke. The taste is amazing: dark fruits, maybe raisin, dark cherry, a tartness, some really deep burnt malts, maybe some soy sauce related flavors. Just amazing. Little to no hint of alcohol, a really smooth but substantial beer. I could drink this all day. This is what beer should be: unique, well made, and taking a stand. Re-rate: bottle a few years old. Very sour at first. Rich dark fruits, milky. As I said before, very unique. Wonderful.

Lasting tan head stays 1cm high over the close to opaque black body. Obviously very well extracted roastiness complements the strong fruitiness, mostly raisins, blackberries and plums. Quite drinkable. Its chocolate hints joyously evade any acidic pretence. Just a generous, warming imperial porter that works well and supplies gentle vinous undertones as well as a mild smokiness. Full-bodied, medium carbonation. Excellent balance all-around. Lovely beer.

Smoky aroma.  Nice motor oil black pour.  Smoky flavor with taste of dark fruits.  Also roasted malt flavor present.  Mild alcohol burn in the finish.   As it warms the alcohol presence is felt.  Was expecting to be let down by all the hype but it definitely lived up the expectations.

I drank this with Drink4Satan and it has a nice black color to it with no head at all. The aroma was a little nulled but i could pick up some roasted malt and some mild bery fruits. The taste is very smokey with hints of fruits in the finish as well as some roasted malt.

Kudos to elmatador00 for this one. Pours out black with a ruby-hued tan head that fades completely to a ring and leaves no lacing. Nice aroma of roasted malt, candi sugar, berries, sweet soy sauce, licorice, and brandy. Wonderfully roasty and smokey flavour with dark fruits, sweet soy and an alcoholic finish with some bitter hops balancing the sweet, complex malts. Soft, tingly carbonation and full body with a long and drying palate duration.
bottle. it has a black color with a medium head. the aroma is of dark fruits. the feel of it is deep and strong. texture is smooth. quite complex.

Aroma is very nice dark fruit, coffee, molassess, dark chocolate.  Taste follows suit and is very well layered, complex, slightly dry.  Just fantastic.  However, it is too salty and soy for me to truly enjoy.  The finish is more salty.  Very, very good beer in every other aspect.  Creamy, complex, just plain good.

Absolutely lives up to the hype! Wonderful nose of dark fruit, mocha, toffee and Candi sugar. Wonderful full and rich mouthfeel that is big yet ever so subtle. Dark chocolate covered dried cherries come to play with a very soft earthy roast.  Beautiful finish that makes me wish I had a lot more.

First rating, no idea why Ive waited this long to do this.

2007 edition. Poured into an imperial pint glass -- black as night, minimal head (might be because I served it a little cold).

Incredibly strong, rich aroma - roasted coffee, chocolate. Reminds me of an Imperial Stout. 

Taste is just as strong. Nice bitterness, lingering malty feel. Alcohol is definitely present but not in an overwhelming way.

Ive been looking for this beer for two years - glad to finally try it. Strong, indeed.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2008  Pours a dark brown, with light brown at the top and bottom. Little head that is light tan. Very alcoholic and thin mouthfeel, almost as thin as a 150 proof liquor. This beer stings every surface in your mouth as you drink. It really tastes like the Milk Stout with a shot of bourbon in it.  Hints of milk and roasted prunes and raisins, not much traditional coffee, chocolate, toffee are non-existent. This beer is in no way whatsoever creamy or malty or balanced, it is super astringent feels like a beer/liquor hybrid.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2008 12 oz. Opaque black with a medium-sized, lasting head. Chocolate and char aroma. Tastes are similar: very strong roasty malt flavors: cocoa, coffee, char and molasses. Strongish alcohol notes in the young samples, but faded with a month or so of aging.. Palate is smooth and medium-bodied. Maybe not to style description (too roasted), but who cares? Awesome brew.
very roasted and the alcohol comes through in a fancy way where its noticeable but not bad... a little too strong and direct for my liking to be a top beer but good nevertheless

Pours deep brown/black with a smallish head,the nose is heavily scented with coffee and soy sauce, lots of smoke in the flavor with some chocolate and coffee malt, long roasty finsh.  Good beer, very flavorful.

Pours a dark chocolatey brown with a light, cocoa colored head that went down quickly.  It smalls of rich malts, coffe, and chocolate.  There even seems to be a hint of something similar to soy sauce.  The beer is extremely thick and creamy in the mouth, with light carbination.  The overwhelming flavor is chocolatey roasted malts.  The flavor is very intense.  This is a very heavy beer with a lot of flavor.  Great to drink in front of the fire on a cold day.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2007 Bottle from turdfergeson - thanks man!  Darker brown pour with a small head.  Nice roasty aroma with a pleasant helping of smoke, coffee, and dark chocolate in the nose.  Flavor is dry and roast with some nice chocolate in there.  Flavor cant match some of my favorite Impy stouts, but the mouthfeel is pretty darn nice.  Stinging, tingly feel with a smoothness thats hard to match.  Definately a best in style winner.  Brilliant beer!

What can I say other than this was truly great. Tried with 5 other porters and this easily stood out. Several people said it was the best beer they had ever had. I agree. Pours nearly black with thick luxurious light brown head. Left nice lace. The aroma has tons of roasted coffee, hints of toffee and caramel.
